103
Criminological research, particularly research directed to the question of the
treatment of offenders, continues to expand. Most of it is financed by the
Home Office and the Scottish Home and Health Department by means of
grants amounting to about £100,000 a year, although a certain number of
research grants are also made by charitable foundations. Much of the work is
undertaken by the Institute of Criminology at Cambridge University, which
also provides a postgraduate course in criminology, and courses in criminology
for people engaged in work relating to the treatment of offenders or the
administration of criminal law. Other academic bodies now providing courses
in criminology for students and carrying out research in this field include the
universities of Durham, Reading, Oxford, Manchester and Southampton;
the London School of Economics, and University College in the University
of London; and the universities of Glasgow, Edinburgh and Strathclyde in
Scotland.
The Home Office Research Unit, which also serves the Scottish Home and
Health Department, carries out a large programme of research of its own,
concentrating mainly on projects of direct interest to the home departments,
the results of which are given practical effect in administrative policy and
legislation. The unit also plays a central part in the allocation of Home Office
grants for research, and in the provision of technical advice, information and
facilities for other research workers in this field.
In addition to research, special inquiries into particular questions are con¬
ducted, as necessary, by advisory bodies or specially appointed committees.
Reports have been issued on such matters as corporal punishment, the non-
residential treatment of offenders under 21 years, and the organisation of
after-care for discharged prisoners. An inter-departmental committee is now'
sitting to consider the revision of the criminal statistics.
THE POLICE SERVICE
The police service of Great Britain is organised in a system of locally
administered forces subject to the influence and eventual control of the Home
Secretary in England and Wales and the Secretary of State for Scotland in
Scotland. In Northern Ireland the police force is controlled by an Inspector
General, who is responsible to the Minister of Home Affairs.
There are 148 regular police forces in Great Britain: 117 in England and
Wales1 and 31 in Scotland. Each of these forces (between which there is close
and constant co-operation) is responsible for a separate police area. In
England and Wales the forces are defined according to area of responsibility
as: county forces; county borough forces; combined forces, which are forces
whose area of responsibility extends over two or more counties or county
boroughs; the Metropolitan Police Force, which is responsible for an area of
approximately 15 miles radius from Charing Cross, but excluding the City of
London; and the City of London force. In Scotland there are county forces,
burgh forces and combined forces.
In England and Wales and Scotland police forces vary considerably in size
according to the area and population which they serve. Thus the Metropolitan
Police Force has a strength of approximately 19,000, while that of the smallest
force in Scotland is 20.
1 The Home Secretary has announced amalgamation schemes to reduce the number of
police forces in England and Wales from 117 to 49.
104
Police
Authorities
and Chief
Constables
Central
Authority
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The actual strength of the regular police force in Great Britain is approxi¬
mately 80,000, including women. This is below the desirable figure, but the
improvement in recruitment shown in recent years has been maintained.
In addition to the regular police forces, there are the River Tyne police, the
police forces maintained by certain public services, such as the statutory
transport authorities, the Service and departmental constabularies, and the
special constabularies attached to each regular police force.
For each of the regular police forces there is a police authority with the duty
of securing the maintenance of an adequate and efficient force. In the counties
of England and Wales the authority is a police committee and in the county
boroughs a watch committee. Both are committees of the local council and
consist of councillors and justices in a proportion of two to one. Combined
police authorities, which also consist of councillors and justices, contain
representatives from each constituent area covered by an amalgamation scheme.
The police authority for the Metropolitan Police Force is the Home
Secretary. In the City of London the Court of Common Council is the police
authority, although it usually appoints a standing committee to deal with all
police matters on its behalf.
In Scotland the police authority for the counties is the county council; in
the large burghs it is the town council; and where there are combined forces
there is a joint police committee.
Police authorities provide the buildings and equipment needed by their
forces and, subject to the approval of the Home Secretary or the Secretary
of State for Scotland, fix the authorised establishment. They also appoint
the chief constable and the assistant and deputy chief constables in their area,
subject to ministerial approval, and may retire them in the interests of efficiency,
if the Home Secretary or the Secretary of State for Scotland agrees. Police
authorities must also keep themselves informed of the way in which chief
constables deal with complaints from the public against police officers. In
the Metropolitan Police District the chief officer of police and his immediate
subordinates are appointed by the Crown on the recommendation of the
Home Secretary.
Chief constables are responsible for the direction and control of police
forces, but are answerable to the police authorities for the efficiency with
which they are used.
The Home Secretary and the Secretary of State for Scotland have a general
duty to exercise their powers to promote the efficiency of the police. They
are empowered to retire a chief constable in the interests of efficiency, to
call for a report from a chief constable on any matters relating to the policing
of his area, and to require co-operation between forces on any police matter.
Uniformity in the conditions of service and in the administration of the
police is achieved through detailed police regulations which are made by the
Home Secretary and the Secretary of State for Scotland under statutory
powers. The police regulations cover such matters as organisation, discipline,
pay, allowances, pensions, clothing and conditions of service of the members of
all the regular police forces and of the River Tyne police. Some of these are
first negotiable on the Police Council for Great Britain; the others are dis¬
cussed on representative advisory bodies along with any general questions
affecting the police service.
In his supervisory responsibilities the Home Secretary is assisted by Her
Majesty’s Chief Inspector of Constabulary and ten inspectors. Eight of the
Police Officers
Police Cadets
Civil Staff
LAW AND ORDER 105
inspectors are each responsible for a certain number of forces, and must be
satisfied of their continuing efficiency through annual inspection, ad hoc visits
and consultations when particular problems arise. The inspectors report to
the Home Secretary on the condition of all the forces, with the exception of
the Metropolitan Police Force. The Secretary of State for Scotland is similarly
assisted by Her Majesty’s Chief Inspector of Constabulary in Scotland and
one other inspector.
All police authorities receive a government grant equal to half their net
expenditure except the Common Council of the City of London, which
receives only one-third. The Home Secretary and the Secretary of State for
Scotland are empowered to withhold the grant, in whole or in part, permanently
or for such time as they may determine, if they are not satisfied that a police
area is efficiently policed, that a force is properly maintained and administered,
or that the rates of pay or allowances are as prescribed or approved by them.
There are in Great Britain regular police officers, who usually serve for
25 years or more and thereafter retire on pension, and special constables, who
are volunteers performing short periods of duty without pay in their spare
time from their normal occupations.1
In general, entry to the regular police force is open to men between the
ages of 19 and 30. Women entrants in England and Wales must be between
the ages of 19 and 35, and in Scotland between 20 and 30 years old. Men
over 30 years old, and women over 35, may, however, be appointed on the
recommendation of the appointing authority in special circumstances approved
by the Home Secretary in England and Wales. In Scotland the Secretary of
State may approve appointments of both men and women over 30 years old.
The standard police ranks in Great Britain, except in the Metropolitan
Police District, are: chief constable, superintendent, inspector, sergeant and
constable. Intermediate ranks may also be adopted in areas where varying
degrees of responsibility make them necessary. In the Metropolitan Police
District the chief officer is the Commissioner of Police of the Metropolis.
He is assisted by a deputy commissioner and four assistant commissioners.
Next in rank are commanders, then deputy commanders; the other ranks
are the same as in the rest of the country. In the City of London the ranks are
the same as in the provinces, except that the chief officer is the Commissioner
of Police and the second in command is an assistant commissioner.
No member of the police service may belong to a trade union, since it is a
basic principle of the service that its members must not only be free from
political bias, but must also be seen to be free of it. All ranks, however, have their
own representative associations which can make representations to ministers or
to police authorities on matters of interest or concern to their members.
Police cadets are recruited by most forces from among youths between 16 and
18 years of age. They have no police powers but are given some training in
police work, partly as useful preparation for subsequent appointment as
constables and partly to give them sufficient insight into police duties to
enable them to decide whether or not they wish to make a career in the police
service. Some forces also recruit girl cadets.
A number of police authorities employ civilians as shorthand-typists, switch¬
board operators, mechanics, canteen staff and cleaners, in order to release
uniformed personnel for police duties.
1 In Scotland the employment of special constables, other than in emergencies, is
subject to strict limitations.

BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Traffic wardens are employed in a growing number of areas to help the
police in dealing with the problems created by parked vehicles. In specially
designated areas traffic wardens issue fixed penalty tickets which give motorists
who have committed certain parking offences an option to pay their fine to the
clerk of the appropriate court instead of having their cases tried.
Every police officer in Great Britain is an independent holder of a public
office. His powers as a constable, whether conferred by statute or by common
law, are exercised by virtue of his office; he is not a servant of the police
authority. Chief officers of police in England and Wales have a vicarious
liability for any wrongful act committed by their subordinates in the
performance of their functions as constables.
The many and varied functions of a police officer as a constable range from
the protection of persons and property, road or street patrolling and traffic
control to criminal investigation and the apprehension of offenders.
All police forces have their own criminal investigation departments, and
many have other specialised departments, including motor patrols, river
police (in districts which include long stretches of navigable waterway), a
mounted branch (for maintaining order and safety in large crowds), and police
dogs.
During recent years a number of common services have been provided by
the central government departments for the benefit of all forces; they
supplement those provided by the police authorities for their own use and
by communal arrangements made between the forces themselves. The most
important of these services are: training services, which in England and Wales
provide ten residential training centres and a central police college and in
Scotland a central police college with courses of recruit training and higher
training; a forensic science service in England and Wales which provides
seven laboratories (in addition to the Metropolitan Police Laboratory) for the
use of regional groups of forces; wireless depots, which in England and Wales
supply and maintain wireless equipment for the police; and central and
provincial criminal records which are available to all forces. Regional crime
squads, consisting of teams of experienced detectives from several forces are
employed to investigate major crimes involving inquiries in more than one
police area. Arrangements are also made for everyday assistance by one force
to another.
The Home Office Police Research and Planning Branch, headed by one of
Her Majesty’s Inspectors of Constabulary and staffed by senior police officers
and scientists, is charged with the planning of police methods, the develop¬
ment of new equipment and the study of new techniques throughout Great
Britain. Its current programme covers various aspects of criminal investigation,
traffic policing, establishments (force strengths), recruitment and wastage in
the Service, vehicle replacement, the evaluation of equipment requirements,
and the application of computers to police work. A considerable amount of
the work in which the Branch is engaged involves the use of operational
research techniques.
Services provided by the Metropolitan Police Force for other forces include
(i) the publication of the Police Gazette,1 which contains particulars of people
wanted for crime and details of stolen property, and is supplied without
1 The Scottish Criminal Record Office in Glasgow is responsible for the publication
of the Scottish Police Gazette.
POLICE IN
NORTHERN
IRELAND
LAW AND ORDER 107
charge to the police forces of the United Kingdom and to certain other Com¬
monwealth and foreign forces; (2) the organisation and control of the special
branch of the criminal investigation department at New Scotland Yard,
whose duties include the physical protection of royalty, some ministers, and
distinguished foreign visitors; and (3) the carrying out of extradition orders
made by the courts. The Metropolitan Police Force is also available, on
request, to assist any other police force in England and Wales in criminal
investigations. Similarly, the services of the Fraud Squad, run jointly by
the Metropolitan Police Force and the City of London Police, are available
throughout Great Britain for the investigation of serious company frauds.
The National Central Bureau, which handles the business of the International
Criminal Police Organisation (Interpol) on behalf of Great Britain and the
British dependencies, is part of the Metropolitan Police Force. For certain
of these services, the Metropolitan Police Force receives an additional
Exchequer grant.
The Royal Ulster Constabulary comes under the direction of the Inspector
General, who is responsible to the Minister of Home Affairs. It undertakes
the policing of the whole of Northern Ireland, its cost being borne by the
Northern Ireland Exchequer.
The strength of the Royal Ulster Constabulary is approximately 3,000. The
Inspector General has, under his immediate command, a deputy inspector
general, a commissioner for the City of Belfast, and a county inspector for
each of the six counties. The area is further sub-divided into districts, each
district coming under a district inspector and each sub-district under a head
constable or a sergeant. Conditions of service and pay follow closely on the
lines of the police service in Great Britain, and the general duties pertaining
to the various ranks are much the same. Although the more senior ranks bear
different titles, the ranks of head constable, sergeant and constable are broadly
equivalent to the three junior ranks in the police service of Great Britain.
The Ulster Special Constabulary, which may assist the Royal Ulster
Constabulary on special occasions, also comes under the direction of the
Inspector General. In the main, this force is a part-time body of some 10,500
part-time members with a small nucleus (no) of full-time personnel for
organisation and training purposes.

4
Collective
Defence
DEFENCE
Britain’s defence policy has two purposes: to guarantee the nation’s security
and to contribute towards peace and stability in the world as a whole. These
purposes are inseparable. Information about defence policy and the armed
forces is provided annually by the Government in a Statement on the Defence
Estimates.1 Policy provides for closely integrated well-trained, highly mobile,
all-regular forces equipped with the most modern weapons and organised on
up-to-date lines; and for a central strategic reserve maintained in Britain,
with means of transport, including airlift, to take it rapidly to the scene of
any emergency.
It is hoped that in the long run the security of Britain, like that of every
other country, can be assured by general and comprehensive disarmament
under the United Nations. Meanwhile, Britain is working for limited measures
of disarmament and arms control. To discourage the further proliferation of
nuclear weapons Britain aims at internationalising its nuclear strategic forces
and also seeks international agreement to check the conventional arms race.
World peace and stability can be promoted in the short run by strength¬
ening the peace-keeping powers of the United Nations. While this must
remain the principal objective, Britain must, until the United Nations is able
to exercise responsibility for maintaining world peace, accept responsibility
for its own defence and that of other countries to which commitments have
been made. This is done through a system of collective defence based on
international treaties and agreements.
Britain maintains forces in three areas of the world as contributions to the
collective security alliances of which it is a member—the North Atlantic
Treaty Organisation (NATO) and the Western European Union (WEU), the
Central Treaty Organisation (CENTO) and the South East Asia Treaty
Organisation (SEATO). It also has commitments arising from bilateral
treaties and Commonwealth responsibilities to assist in the defence of certain
countries, and, as a member of the United Nations, has accepted an obligation
to provide, in certain circumstances, armed forces for maintaining international
peace. All of Britain’s commitments are consistent with its obligations under
the United Nations Charter.
The following limitations on the use of military force by Britain are part
of the policy for defence described in the 1966 Defence White Paper.2
First, Britain will not undertake major operations of war except in co-operation
with allies. Secondly, Britain will not accept an obligation to provide another
country with military assistance unless that country is prepared to provide
Britain with the facilities necessary to make such assistance effective in time.
Finally, there will be no attempt to maintain defence facilities in an indepen¬
dent country against its wishes.
Under the North Atlantic Treaty 1949, Britain is committed to assist any
member country (13 European countries, the United States and Canada) in
1 Defence policy is under continuing review; this chapter describes the position in
September 1966.
8 Statement on the Defence Estimates, 1966. Part I. The Defence Review, p.7.
DEFENCE
109
the event of armed attack against one or more of them. A similar commitment
arises from the Brussels Treaty 1948. Under the revised Brussels Treaty 1954,
Britain is committed to maintain an army of 55,000 men and a tactical air
force on the continent of Europe, subject to safeguards allowing for review and
temporary withdrawals. Although Berlin is outside the North Atlantic
Treaty area, Britain and its allies accept that an attack on Berlin would be
equivalent to an attack on the treaty area. Britain’s contribution to NATO
includes over three-quarters of the operational and reserve fleets, a considerable
proportion of the Royal Air Force (RAF) front-line aircraft including the whole
of Fighter Command and the deterrent force of V-bombers, RAF Germany,
nearly all Coastal Command, and the British Army of the Rhine. The British
Polaris submarines now under construction (see p. 117) will be assigned to a
NATO Commander and when fully operational in 1969-70 will take over
responsibility from the V-bombers for Britain’s contribution to the NATO
nuclear force. A further contribution is the provision of facilities for a depot
ship in the Holy Loch (Firth of Clyde, Scotland) for the United States
Polaris submarines.
Under an agreement between the British and United States Governments
signed in i960, a joint Ballistic Missile Early Warning Station has been built
at Fylingdales Moor, Yorkshire, completing the chain of three early warning
stations that would supply information about missile attacks to western
defence headquarters. The others are in Thule, Greenland, and Clear,
Alaska.
Under the Baghdad Pact 1955, which gave rise to CENTO, Britain is com¬
mitted to co-operate with Iran, Pakistan and Turkey for security and defence.
There are also obligations arising from bilateral agreements (in which the form
of commitment varies) towards countries including Malta, Cyprus, Libya, the
Federation of South Arabia and certain unfederated States in the same area,
Bahrain, Qatar, Muscat and Oman, the Trucial States and Kuwait. Britain
makes annual contributions towards the defence ‘infra-structure’ of the
CENTO region, keeps a RAF nuclear bomber force in Cyprus expressly for
the defence of the region and provides various military training facilities.
Under the Manila Treaty 1954, which established SEATO, Britain is
committed to act in the event of an attack against any of the parties to the
treaty, which include Pakistan, the Philippines and Thailand. There is also
a bilateral agreement with Malaysia under treaties of 1957 and 1963 (which
continues to be recognised by Singapore) for Britain’s assistance with external
defence, and a further responsibility for the protection of the Sultanate of
Brunei. In the SEATO area, Britain provides training facilities for military
personnel and, in particular, has built a strategic airfield in Thailand with the
help of Australia and New Zealand. Britain maintains forces in Malaysia,
including those in the Commonwealth Far East Strategic Reserve which
comprises the Commonwealth Brigade and associated naval and air units,
all of which are drawn from Britain, Australia and New Zealand. Singapore
provides bases for all three armed Services.
Although ties of sentiment and historical association have led Britain to
respond from time to time to requests for armed support from independent
countries of the Commonwealth, Britain’s formal defence obligations to the
Commonwealth (apart from specific agreements) are confined to its remaining
colonial responsibilities. This involves a responsibility for the external defence
and internal security of such territories as Gibraltar, Aden, Swaziland,
British Honduras, Mauritius, the Seychelles, the Falkland Islands, Hong
Kong and the other dependencies.

Organisation
Supreme responsibility for national defence rests with the Prime Minister
and the Cabinet, under the ultimate control of Parliament. Defence problems
and their implications for foreign and economic policy are dealt with on the
Cabinet’s behalf by the Committee on Defence and Oversea Policy, under
the chairmanship of the Prime Minister.
In 1964 a unified Ministry of Defence, under a Secretary of State, was set
up, absorbing what were formerly four separate departments—the Ministry
of Defence, the Admiralty, the War Office and the Air Ministry. The
Secretary of State for Defence is assisted by three Ministers of Defence for
the Royal Navy, Army and Royal Air Force respectively, who have a
particular responsibility for the management of the individual Services but
who also assist the Secretary of State in any general defence matters which
he delegates to them. The Minister of Defence for the Army has particular
responsibility for matters concerning administrative organisation, rationali¬
sation, and the control of defence lands; the Minister of Defence for the
Royal Navy is concerned with co-ordination on personnel and logistic
questions; and the Minister of Defence for the Royal Air Force is concerned
with co-ordination of research, development and production, and for the
defence budget as a whole: he is also responsible for general oversight in the
field of strategic exports.
Command and administration of the armed forces is vested in the Defence
Council, under the chairmanship of the Secretary of State. The members of
the Defence Council are the three Ministers of Defence, the Chief of the
Defence Staff and the Chiefs of Staff, the Chief Scientific Adviser and the
Permanent Under-Secretary of State. The Defence Council deals mainly with
major defence policy. The principal military advisers to the Government are
the members of the Chiefs of Staff Committee, which comprises the Chief of
the Defence Staff as chairman and the Chiefs of Staff of the three Services.
The Committee is responsible to the Government for professional advice on
strategy and military operations and on the military implications of defence
policy.
The management of the three Services is delegated to Admiralty, Army and
Air Force Boards of the Defence Council, of each of which the Secretary of
State is chairman, although the appropriate Minister of Defence normally acts
for him. Unified control of policy and management has made possible further
rationalisation of Service administration and operation and the whole structure
of defence organisation is being re-examined.
The Royal Navy has nine specialist branches: Seaman, Communications,
Engineering, Fleet Air Arm, Electrical, Supply and Secretariat, Medical,
Shipwrights and the Regulating Branch.
The Corps of the Royal Marines, which is part of the Royal Navy, is a body
of men trained for service on sea or land. Its official existence dates from
1664. The present-day functions of the corps are: to provide personnel for
Commandos; to provide crews for minor landing craft and certain other
parties required for amphibious assault; and to supply for Her Majesty s ships
detachments which take part in the routine duties, including guard duty, and
provide emergency landing parties.
The Army is organised into some 30 arms and services1 which include the
Household Cavalry, the Royal Armoured Corps (the historic Cavalry Regi-
1 These arms and services include the women’s corps.

ments and the Royal Tank Regiment), the Royal Regiment of Artillery, the
Corps of Royal Engineers, the Royal Corps of Signals (which provides land
and wireless communications), the five regiments of Foot Guards (the Brigade
of Guards), the Infantry of the Line (grouped into brigades and regiments),
the Army Air Corps (which operates light aircraft on reconnaissance and
undertakes aerial observation and liaison work), the Royal Corps of Transport
(which operates all types of logistic vehicles from locomotives to aircraft), the
Royal Army Medical Corps, the Royal Army Ordnance Corps (responsible for
most equipment and stores), and the Royal Electrical and Mechanical
Engineers (responsible for most repairs).
The specialist branches of the Royal Air Force are the eight Home
Commands (see p. 112).
Defence accounts for about one-fifth of all central government ordinary
expenditure. The cost of the defence programme for 1966-67 (excluding home
defence) was estimated at £2,172 million, or 6-6 per cent of the gross national
product. Britain’s nuclear strategic forces account for less than 5 per cent of
this total. Net expenditure in foreign exchange for the maintenance of British
forces abroad and other military purposes was estimated at £293 million for
1966-67, and constitutes a heavy burden on the country’s balance of payments.
The Federal Republic of Germany agreed in 1965 to relieve this burden by
placing in Britain contracts for military (and some civil) goods to the value of
£171 million in the three years ending 31st March 1967. British proposals
for obtaining a complete off-set of the foreign exchange costs of the British
Forces in Germany have been put to NATO and WEU, and meanwhile
consultations are continuing.

by a single commander, who may belong to any one of the three Services; he is

The home and overseas commands of the Services are:
Portsmouth, Plymouth, Scotland (Rosyth) and Northern Ireland, and the
Commander-in-Chief, Home Fleet. British naval forces in the North Atlantic
and Mediterranean area are assigned to NATO. Naval command in the
Middle East rests with the Flag Officer, Middle East, and in the Far East
with the Commander, Far East Fleet. Smaller naval forces operate under the
Commander-in-Chief, South Atlantic and South America Station, and the
Senior Naval Officer, West Indies Station.
Eastern, Northern, Northern Ireland, Scottish, Southern and Western

Gibraltar; Malta and Libya; Cyprus; Middle East Land Forces and Far East
Land Forces.
Bomber, Fighter, Coastal, Transport, Flying Training, Technical Training,
Maintenance and Signals Commands1; Royal Air Force, Germany (Second
Tactical Air Force, assigned to NATO); Near East Air Force; Air Forces,
Middle East; Far East Air Force.
The basic principle of Britain’s deployment is to retain in overseas theatres
the minimum forces consistent with commitments, and to hold ready in
Britain a Strategic Reserve, together with the air transport necessary to
reinforce at maximum speed to anywhere in the world. Of a total force of
421,000 (plus 32,000 in locally enlisted forces) the broad division between
service personnel based in Britain and overseas (including Germany) is as
follows:
Britain, 258,000; Europe, 63,000; Mediterranean and Near East, 22,000;
Middle and Far East, 69,000; elsewhere, 9,000.
The present deployment of the forces is summarised below.
Ships on home sea service, including destroyers, frigates, submarines and
coastal minesweepers. Their main tasks are to carry out training, trials and
fishery protection. They also have to meet certain NATO commitments.
The Army Strategic Reserve; certain other front line units and skeleton
headquarters, which can be sent anywhere in the world in any emergency;
training and maintenance units.
Royal Air Force bomber, reconnaissance and tanker forces of Bomber
Command; air-defence forces of Fighter Command; strategic and tactical
transport squadrons and ground-attack squadrons of Transport Command;
maritime reconnaissance squadrons of Coastal Command; squadrons of the
Royal Air Force Regiment.
A corps of three divisions in the Federal Republic of Germany and a brigade
in Berlin.
A tactical air force, including light bomber, reconnaissance and air-defence
squadrons; fighter reconnaissance aircraft; and support helicopters.

Destroyers, frigates and minesweepers, supplemented from time to time by
other major units of the Fleet.
Small Army garrisons in Gibraltar, Malta and Cyprus; units in Libya
(shortly to be reduced in size in agreement with the Libya Government);
1,000 men in the United Nations force in Cyprus (about a fifth of the total).
Light bomber, reconnaissance and tactical transport squadrons and air-
defence forces; flight of helicopters for United Nations in Cyprus.
Aircraft carriers and commando ships, operating as necessary between the
Middle East and Far East Commands, covering the seas east of Suez.
Normally, three of these ships have been operating in the area at any given
time. The frigates and minesweepers on the station spend much of their time
in the Persian Gulf. They are supported from Bahrain and Aden. A Royal
Marine Commando is stationed at Aden.
The Commander-in-Chief has under his command 17,500 troops, most
of whom are stationed in Aden and Bahrain. Air Force units in Aden include
ground-attack, fighter-reconnaissance, tactical transport and maritime-
reconnaissance squadrons, and a squadron of the Royal Air Force Regiment.
At Bahrain, there are ground-attack and tactical transport squadrons. An
Army battalion is at present based in Swaziland.
In addition to ships mentioned in Middle East section above, there are many
destroyers (some with guided missiles), frigates, submarines, coastal mine¬
sweepers and support ships; two Royal Marine Commandos and two Royal
Marine special boat sections; ships of the Royal Australian Navy and Royal
New Zealand Navy, attached to the Fleet.
The Commander-in-Chief has under his command at any one time over
40,000 troops, of whom about 14,000 are Gurkhas and about 6,000 are men
enlisted in Malaysia, Singapore and Hong Kong. Australia and New Zealand
also contribute troops to the Commonwealth Brigade; the end of Indonesian
confrontation of Malaysia is permitting withdrawals from this theatre. British
and Gurkha troops are serving in Eastern Malaysia and Brunei. A substantial
garrison, including a Gurkha brigade, is maintained in Flong Kong.
Light bomber squadrons of the Royal Air Force; reconnaissance aircraft;
air-defence force, including Bloodhound Mark 2 squadrons; ground-attack
and medium- and short-range tactical transport squadrons; Royal Air Force
Regiment squadrons; V-bombers deployed on rotation. Units of the Royal
Australian Air Force and Royal New Zealand Air Force also form part of the
Far East Air Force.
A small naval force, normally of frigates, sometimes carrying a detachment of
Royal Marines. The ice patrol ship HMS Protector operates in the Falkland
Islands and Antarctic during the southern summer. There is one infantry
company in British Honduras.
Royal Navy submarines are based in Canada and Australia to assist in
anti-submarine training for the Royal Canadian and Royal Australian
Navies.
Defence policy provides for a force of about 400,000 professional servicemen,
with the highest possible proportion in effective combat units, backed by an
equal number of civilians. The forces consist entirely of regular volunteers.

Entrants to the non-commissioned ranks of the three Services are given
basic training, and further training is given during the course of their careers.
Young servicemen have the opportunity to read for the General Certificate of
Education ‘O’ level (see p. 156). Trade and technical training, though
primarily designed for Service purposes, leads in many cases to nationally
recognised qualifications; completion of many Service trade or technical
courses followed by experience is recognised by trade unions as a qualification
for membership by men who have left the Services.
Men may qualify for the rank of commissioned officer in several ways, with
some differences between the three Services. Commissions may be granted
for short, medium or long terms.
Promotion from the non-commissioned ranks is possible in all three
Services. In the Royal Navy and the Army the normal method of entry is
through cadetship in the Britannia Royal Naval College, Dartmouth, or the
Royal Military Academy Sandhurst. This is followed by specialist training
which may include degree courses. The RAF trains cadets for long-term
commissions at the RAF College, Cranwell, Lincolnshire, but the majority of
DEFENCE
115
entrants to the flying and executive branches take Direct Entry Commissions
(of medium length). There is special provision in the three Services for the
entry of men with appropriate qualifications including doctors, dentists and
other graduates.
Selected officers of all three Services who have had previous staff training or
have been to the Royal Naval Staff College, Greenwich (London), the Army
Staff College at Camberley (Surrey), or the Royal Air Force Staff Colleges at
Bracknell (Berkshire) or Andover (Hampshire) go to the Joint Services Staff
College at Chesham (Buckinghamshire), where particular attention is paid to
the inter-Service aspects of staff work. A few specially selected and more
senior officers from the Services, the Civil Service, and from other Common¬
wealth countries are sent to the Imperial Defence College in London.
Considerable training is done through Joint-Service and inter-allied exercises,
on which increasing emphasis is being placed. Inter-allied exercises take
place under the auspices of the three regional alliances.
Women’s The three women’s services, the Women’s Royal Naval Service (WRNS), the
Services Women’s Royal Army Corps (WRAC) and the Women’s Royal Air Force
(WRAF), are integral parts of the Navy, Army and RAF respectively. Service
women serve alongside servicemen in Britain and overseas. Nursing services
are provided by Queen Alexandra’s Royal Naval Nursing Service, Queen
Alexandra’s Royal Army Nursing Corps and Princess Mary’s Royal Air Force
Nursing Service.
Resettlement A Regular Forces Resettlement Service assists regular officers and servicemen
to find civilian employment on leaving the forces (see Chapter 16, Labour).
Joint Service
Training
Reserve and
Auxiliary Forces
Royal Navy
The Royal Naval Reserve (RNR) consists of volunteer reserves—serving at
sea in the Merchant Navy or the fishing fleets or in civilian employment
ashore—who carry out training in time of peace to meet the Navy’s mobilisa¬
tion requirements. Other reserves include the Royal Fleet Reserve, composed
of certain ex-regulars; the Royal Marines Reserve; and the Women’s Royal
Naval Reserve. The Royal Naval Auxiliary Service, a civilian organisation
composed of men and women volunteers, is responsible in time of war for
minewatching duties around the coast and the waterways, and other duties.
Army There are two main regular reserves, the Regular Reserve and the Long Term
Reserve.
The Regular Reserve consists of men who have completed the Colour
portion of their service with the Regular Army but who are retained on a
Reserve to complete a total engagement of 12 years; as such they are liable to
recall to the Colours.
The Long Term Reserve (LTR) was created by the Navy, Army and Air
Forces Reserves Act 1964. All men who join the Regular Army are transferred
to the LTR on completion of their Regular and Regular Reserve service.
They remain in the LTR until the age of 45 and are liable to recall in an
emergency.
The Territorial Army and the Army Emergency Reserve (both volunteer
forces) are being replaced (under plans described in a White Paper,
Reorganisation of the Army Reserves, 1965) by a new Territorial and Army
Volunteer Reserve (T & AYR), comprising sections I, II and III. Part of the
reserve, to be called the Special Army Volunteer Reserve (T & AVR I), will
consist of volunteers from the Regular Army Reserve and from T & AVR II;
Royal Air Force
Cadet Forces
WEAPONS AND
EQUIPMENT
Production
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
they will be an ‘ever-ready’ reserve, liable for six months’ service in emergency
at the discretion of the Secretary of State for Defence. T & AYR II will
consist of locally recruited ‘independent’ units (T & AYR IIA) and nationally
recruited ‘sponsored’ (more specialised) units (T & AYR IIB), both liable for
call up after Section A of the Regular Reserve. T & AYR I and T & AYR II
will be known as the Volunteers. T & AYR III, the Territorials, will be a
military home defence force (see p. 124).
The Royal Auxiliary Air Force consists of two maritime headquarters units
and a maritime support unit. The units are raised and maintained by local
Territorial and Auxiliary Forces Associations and functionally controlled by
Coastal Command. In addition the Royal Auxiliary Air Force General List
comprises officers specially selected for service in war appointments.
The Royal Air Force Reserve consists mainly of officers and airmen who
have served in the Air Force. It includes the Royal Air Force Volunteer
Reserve, whose members, like the officers, airmen and airwomen of the Royal
Auxiliary Air Force, have a liability to carry out training on a part-time basis.
University air squadrons (established at 17 universities) form part of the
Royal Air Force Volunteer Reserve.
The Royal Observer Corps is a predominantly civilian and voluntary
organisation, administered by Fighter Command. Its present strength is some
18,000 men and women whose principal task would be the measuring and
reporting of radioactivity in the event of nuclear attack. Some i,tjoo under¬
ground operations posts have been built for the Corps.
Cadet Forces provide pre-Service training for boys and, in addition, aim to
teach good citizenship.
The Combined Cadet Force (CCF) contingents are based on schools in
which education is continued to the age of 17 or over, and normally take boys
for three years between the ages of 14 and 18. During this time they receive
training in the Royal Navy, Army, or Royal Air Force sections of their choice.
There are also the Army Cadet Force (14 to i8|) which has ‘open’ detach¬
ments in towns and villages and ‘closed’ detachments in schools that do not
have CCF contingents (boys who have left school may join ‘open’ detach¬
ments), and the Air Training Corps (14 to 20). The Sea Cadet Corps, although
not a pre-Service organisation, helps boys between the ages of 12 and 18 who
wish to make their careers at sea.
The Ministry of Aviation (see p. 49) was responsible for the supply to the
Services of aircraft, guided weapons, nuclear weapons and certain radar and
other electronic equipment. The Ministry of Defence is responsible for the
procurement of other weapons, stores and equipment.
A substantial part of the equipment used by the Services is developed and
produced in Britain, some by private industry on a contract basis and some
by the Royal Ordnance Factories, the Royal Dockyards and other establish¬
ments operated by the Ministry of Aviation and the Ministry of Defence.
Production of nuclear warheads is undertaken by the Atomic Energy
Authority (see p. 206) under contract with the Ministry of Aviation. In some
cases—particularly where development costs would be disproportionately
high—aircraft, weapons and other equipment are bought from overseas.
Conversely, British defence equipment has been adopted by allied and friendly
nations: for example, the United States, the Federal Republic of Germany,
Denmark and Sweden are using the British 105 mm. tank gun, and British
DEFENCE
II?
early warning radar equipment has been adopted by several countries and
by NATO.
Britain also undertakes manufacture in collaboration with other countries.
One example is the United States Bullpup short-range air-to-surface guided
weapon which is in service with the Royal Navy and is being manufactured in
Europe under a NATO international agency. Others are the manufacture, in
collaboration with France, of the Jaguar and the variable geometry aircraft
(see pp. 121—2).
Research and
Development
Establishments
Nuclear-
Powered
Submarines
Missile Testing
Nuclear
Weapons
Research and development are undertaken at a number of specialised
establishments. Among the most important of those belonging to the former
Ministry of Aviation (see p. 49), are: the Royal Aircraft Establishments,
Farnborough and Bedford; the Royal Radar Establishment, Malvern, and the
Aeroplane and Armament Experimental Establishment, Boscombe Down,
Wiltshire. The Navy Department’s two research establishments carry out
research on ships, maritime equipment and weapons and also on certain kinds
of electronic equipment on behalf of all three Services. They are at Portsdown
(near Portsmouth), where the design and development of ship-borne gunnery
and guided missile systems are carried out, and at Portland (Dorset), where
all aspects of work on underwater detection are co-ordinated with work on
underwater weapons. Research establishments controlled by the Army
Department include the Royal Armament Research and Development
Establishment, Sevenoaks, Kent; and the Fighting Vehicles Research and
Development Establishment, Chobham, Surrey.
Much experimental work has been carried out by the Navy and the Atomic
Energy Authority on nuclear propelled submarines (see p.120), and a nuclear
submarine power unit prototype is in operation at Dounreay (see p. 208). The
Royal Naval College, Greenwich, has a low-power training reactor which
provides facilities for basic education in nuclear engineering and research.
Guided missiles are tested at the Ministry of Aviation’s research establish¬
ments, and guided and ballistic missiles at the Woomera range set up in
Australia under the Joint United Kingdom/Australia Guided Weapon Project.
Service firing trials of air-to-air and surface-to-air missiles are carried out at
Aberporth and at the Army gunnery range in Anglesey; a range for testing
surface-to-surface missiles has been set up on South Uist in the Hebrides.
Research into nuclear weapons began in Britain during the second world
war. It was continued, as an allied project, in the United States where the
first atomic bomb was produced. After a subsequent period of independent
development in both countries, collaboration was resumed in 1958, when an
agreement was concluded which made possible the exchange of information
on the design and manufacture of nuclear weapons. This was supplemented
by a further agreement in May 1959, which contained provisions to enable
Britain to buy from the United States component parts of atomic weapons
and weapons systems other than actual warheads, and to make possible the
exchange of nuclear materials between the two countries.
Britain’s present nuclear programme is based on an agreement of 1963
under which Britain buys from the United States a number of Polaris missiles,
to be fitted with British nuclear warheads, for submarines to be built largely
by Britain.
In 1963 Britain, with the United States, the Soviet Union and many other
countries, signed a treaty prohibiting testing of nuclear weapons in the
atmosphere, outer space and under water.

COMBAT FORCES The six groups of combat forces are described below:
Nuclear The nuclear strategic forces are the V-bomber force of Royal Air Force
Strategic Forces Bomber Command which will initially be augmented by the Polaris Fleet of
the Royal Navy (including headquarters, bases and facilities for their control
and support). Their cost in 1966-67 is estimated at £105 million. Their role is
to contribute to the nuclear strategic forces of the West, which exist to deter
any nation from mounting a nuclear attack against Britain or its allies. To
achieve this, the nuclear forces must be seen to be able to inflict an unaccept¬
able degree of damage on any nation contemplating a nuclear attack. At
present Britain’s nuclear strategic force is the V-bomber force and this is
assigned to NATO. Britain has proposed the formation of an Atlantic Nuclear
Force in which NATO’s strategic nuclear power would be controlled in a way
that would both meet the legitimate requirements of the non-nuclear members
to play their part and remove any incentive for the dissemination of nuclear
weapons. Under this proposal, Britain has offered to internationalise the bulk
of its nuclear strategic forces, including the entire Polaris submarine fleet, by
committing them irrevocably to NATO for the duration of the alliance.
Equipment
The V-bomber force comprises Victor B2 squadrons and Vulcan B2 squadrons,
equipped with either Blue Steel stand-off bombs or free-fall weapons.
Various modifications including a terrain-avoidance radar are being introduced
in all aircraft to permit them to operate below effective cover of enemy defence
systems. Squadrons not equipped to use the stand-off bombs are being re¬
equipped with a new nuclear weapon, which can be effectively and accurately
delivered from a very low level. A proportion of the force is always kept at
readiness. In addition to their nuclear strike role, V-bombers can carry
conventional weapons and, in an emergency, can be deployed rapidly for
operations in other theatres.
The first Polaris submarine is expected to be operational by 1968. The
force will ultimately consist of four submarines, two of which will always
be on patrol at a time. Each submarine will carry 16 long-range missiles.
Construction of the submarine base on the Gareloch (north of the Clyde
Estuary) should be completed on time in 1968. When the Polaris submarines
come into service they will take over the strategic role of the V-bombers,
which will then be used to supplement the FmA aircraft (see p. 122) in the
strike role.
European
Theatre Ground
Forces
Equipment
The European theatre ground forces consist of the BAOR and a brigade in
Berlin. Their role is to deter aggression in all its forms and to fight if deterrence
fails, in co-operation with NATO allies. Their cost in 1966-67 is estimated at
£173 million.
The Chieftain main battle tank is succeeding the Conqueror and Centurion
tanks; it incorporates many new features in protection and mobility. Two
armoured car regiments are equipped with the Vigilant anti-tank guided
weapon mounted on the Ferret scout car. Its successor will be the Swing fire.
The field artillery supporting the general war ground forces is receiving several
new weapons, including the British Abbot self-propelled 105 mm. gun (which
has good cross-country mobility, range, fire-power and protection for its
crew) and the American self-propelled 155 mm. Mi09 and 175 mm. Mi07
guns. Missile regiments equipped with the Honest John free-flight rocket and
the 8-inch howitzer provide surface-to-surface tactical nuclear support for the
ground forces, and medium-level air defence is being greatly improved by the
DEFENCE
Royal Navy
General
Purpose
Combat Forces
Equipment
119
introduction of the Thunderbird guided weapon system. The new tracked
armoured personnel carrier is increasing the mobility and protection of the
infantry, who are also being provided with improved chemical and nuclear
defensive equipment. A portable version of the Vigilant anti-tank guided
weapon is in service with selected infantry battalions. A semi-automatic
multi-coloured trunk system for communications in the combat area will be
introduced in BAOR.
The naval general purpose combat forces are the ships of the Fleet1 other than
the Polaris submarines; the Fleet Air Arm (aircraft carriers, naval aircraft,
air personnel and shore naval air establishments); the Royal Marine Com¬
mandos ; and support ships and overseas bases, dockyards and supply depots.
Their role is to help to keep the peace and to protect and further trade
and other British interests; in an emergency to be ready to safeguard the
use of the sea and to support the Army; and to make an effective contribution
to the forces of NATO, CENTO and SEATO. Their cost in 1966—67 is
estimated at £309 million.
The two commando ships HMS Albion and HMS Bulwark, the two assault
ships HMS Fearless and HMS Intrepid, and the Royal Marine Commandos
are the amphibious forces. Commando ships are equipped with Wessex Mark 5
helicopters and landing craft. The Wessex carries both homing torpedoes and
dipping sonar (sound navigation and ranging) submarine detection equipment.
The commando troop-carrying version is armed with the SS 11, a French anti¬
tank guided missile. The United States Sioux helicopters are coming into
service.
Assault ships are also equipped to operate helicopters. A Landing Force
Headquarters can exercise command control from the ship until it takes up
position ashore. The ships can land troops with supporting arms and transport
and the landing craft, operating from a dock space at the stern of the ship, can
unload tanks, vehicles, equipment and stores across open beaches.
The carrier force, at present HMS Hermes, HMS Eagle, HMS Victorious
and HMS Ark Royal, is to be continued as far as possible into the 1970s as
the most important element of the Fleet for offensive action. The carriers are
equipped with the angled flight deck, the steam catapult, the automatic air¬
craft positioning device and the mirror and ‘Audio’ landing aids (all British
inventions). HMS Eagle also has Action Data Automation (ADA) giving
command and control facilities in advance of any system at present known.
The main strike and fighter strength is provided by the Buccaneer, Sea Vixen
and Scimitar aircraft, all fitted with the United States Bullpup air-to-surface
guided missile. The Buccaneer Mark 2, a long-range low-level strike aircraft
with an advanced weapon system, is gradually replacing the Scimitar. The
Sea Vixen Mark 1 carries the air-to-air missile Firestreak, but this is being
replaced by the Mark 2 which has an improved weapon system incorporating
the Red Top air-to-air missile, giving increased effectiveness against high¬
flying and supersonic targets. Eventually the United States Phantom, powered
by Rolls Royce Spey engines, will replace the Sea Vixen. The Whirlwind
Mark 9 helicopter is in service for search and rescue duties and the Wessex for
anti-submarine work.
In 1966 there were 145 ships in the operational Fleet (including 4 aircraft carriers,
2 commando ships, 1 cruiser, 6 guided missile destroyers, 9 other destroyers, 39 frigates
ancj 35 submarines) together with 32 engaged on trials and training and 45 support ships
and auxiliaries.

Army General

BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
In the long term, the strike reconnaissance and air defence functions of the
carrier will be taken over by aircraft operating from land bases (see p. 122) and
close anti-submarine protection of the naval force will be given by helicopters
operating from ships other than carriers—for example, commando and assault
ships, cruisers, destroyers and frigates. Strike capability against enemy ships
will be provided by land-based aircraft and by a new ship-borne surface-to-
surface guided missile (see below).
Nuclear power propulsion has revolutionised the submarine, enabling it
to operate submerged for prolonged periods at sustained high speed. Two
are now in service (HMS Dreadnought and HMS Valiant) and will eventually
be joined by three more. Twelve Oberon class submarines, the most advanced
conventional-powered submarines in the world, are now in service and the
thirteenth and last will enter service in 1967. They are armed with a new type
of homing torpedo, backed by a complex fire system. Other operational
submarines include eight of the Porpoise class.
The Tiger class cruisers have fully automatic armament and the latest
control equipment. They are being converted to carry anti-submarine
helicopters. Destroyers and frigates, which constitute the largest part of the
Fleet, are the main surface protection against submarines and against enemy
surface and air forces. Of eight County class guided missile destroyers planned
for the Navy, four are in commission; two more to join them shortly are
equipped with the Seaslug Mark 2 surface-to-air missile and ADA. All the
ships carry a Wessex helicopter. For the future a new, more powerful class of
guided missile ship is on order—the Type 82 destroyer—to be equipped with
the surface-to-air guided weapon Seadart, the Ikara anti-submarine weapon
and new Anglo-Dutch radar. A small surface-to-surface guided weapon is to be
developed for use against missile-firing ships. Leander class frigates have
advanced anti-submarine equipment including variable-depth and medium-
range sonar and mortars, and like the Tribal class frigates they can carry Wasp
anti-submarine helicopters.
Support-ships replenish the Fleet and offer it maintenance and repair
facilities. They include submarine depot ships, equipped with workshops
and plant to support a squadron or more of submarines, a heavy repair and
maintenance ship and mine counter-measures support ships, all manned by
naval personnel. Ships of the Royal Fleet Auxiliary Service provide afloat
logistic support such as fuel, food, ammunition, stores and spare gear. These
ships fly the Blue Ensign and are manned by Merchant Navy officers and
seamen. The dockyards at Portsmouth, Devonport, Chatham and Rosyth
provide the Navy with major supplies and repair facilities in Britain. Singapore
and Gibraltar are the main dockyards overseas.
Army general purpose combat forces consist mainly of the ground forces
deployed outside Europe to meet Britain’s treaty obligations and other
commitments; the Strategic Reserve; and other front-line units in Britain.
The British component of these forces totals some 78,000 troops; there are
also about 14,000 Gurkhas together with other forces locally enlisted in
Malaysia, Singapore, Hong Kong and Malta. Their cost in 1966-67 is
estimated at £212 million.
The Strategic Reserve consists of two infantry brigades and one parachute
brigade with armoured-car, artillery and engineer support. It is capable of
undertaking operations ranging from internal security and counter-insurgency
to limited war and is available to support BAOR in the event of general war.
It is completely air-portable. Ground forces overseas have a variety of roles,

121
Equipment
Royal Air
Force Combat
Forces
Equipment
including protection of Britain’s overseas bases, internal security duties and
support of commitments. The largest group is in the Far East. Special Air
Service troops are highly specialised forces which can act independently and
react quickly to unforeseen contingencies.
The introduction of the light-weight rifle and light-weight sleeping equipment
and rations in the Far East has helped to lessen the infantryman’s load; a new
manpack radio has been issued. Other equipment now proving its efficiency
includes the remotely-controlled anti-personnel mine, the radio homing
beacon and the Green Archer mortar locator. The General Purpose Machine
Gun is replacing the Vickers and the Bren in infantry battalions. Equipment to
improve the Army’s ability to fight by night is being issued. Mobility is
being increased by improved engineer equipments that enhance the Army’s
power to cross natural and artificial barriers and by deployment of the
Stalwart high-mobility load-carrier. Following trials of hovercraft by the
Joint Service Hovercraft Unit in the Far East, the Army is forming a Hover¬
craft Unit, equipped with four Westland hovercraft modified for military use.
The introduction of the Sioux helicopter has greatly increased the Army’s
power of reconnaissance. Scout helicopters are used to carry patrols, casualties
and urgently needed stores. The Canadian fixed-wing light aircraft Beaver is
used for liaison purposes. The faster and more advanced Landing Ship
Logistic (LSL) is superseding the Landing Ship Tank (LST) for support
operations.
The Royal Air Force combat forces comprise all the front-line formations
and units except the V-bomber, transport and tanker forces. They fall into
five main categories: air defence, ground attack and fighter reconnaissance;
light bomber and tactical reconnaissance; maritime reconnaissance; head¬
quarters, bases and general training establishments; and general support,
including the Royal Air Force Regiment, which is responsible for protecting
bases. Their cost in 1966-67 is estimated at £229 million.
Fighter squadrons are equipped with Lightning Mark 2 and Mark 3 supersonic
aircraft, which carry Firestreak or Red Top air-to-air missiles. The Lightning
is fitted with a computer to aid bomber interception. In the long term, the
Lightning's successor will be the Phantom. Air defence is also the function of
the Bloodhound Mark 2 surface-to-air missile. Air defence squadrons are
controlled by ground radars. New military radars and centralised data-
handling equipment are being installed in Britain as part of the integrated
plans for air defence and national air traffic control. Overseas, new transport¬
able radars are supplementing static radar. The ballistic missile early warning
station at Fylingdales (see p. 109) would provide warning of a missile attack on
Britain and so enable the V-bombers to be alerted and despatched. It also
detects, tracks and identifies objects in orbit.
The ground attack and short-range Army support aircraft is the Hunter
FGA9; its weapons include cannons and rockets. Phantoms and the British
P.112J vertical take-off and landing aircraft will replace the Hunter in 1968 and
1969 respectively. Later, a strike version of the Anglo-French Jaguar light-
strike and trainer aircraft will release Phantoms to replace the Lightnings.
Overseas fighter-reconnaissance squadrons are equipped with Hunter FR10
aircraft.
Light bomber forces are assigned to NATO in a primary role of nuclear
strike, but they can also use conventional weapons to meet Britain’s require¬
ments outside the NATO area. Squadrons are also declared to CENTO and
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
SEATO. They are all equipped with Canberra aircraft, which can carry the
AS30 guided missiles. The United States’ FmA aircraft will be introduced
by January 1970 as a Canberra replacement, and will be supplemented by
Y-bombers until the introduction of the Anglo-French variable geometry
aircraft in a tactical strike-reconnaissance role in the mid-1970s.
Reconnaissance forces comprise the Canberra PR7 and Victor Mark 2 air¬
craft. Maritime-reconnaissance squadrons in Britain are equipped with
Shackleton Mark 2 and Mark 3 aircraft and squadrons overseas with the
Shackleton Mark 2. In addition to their reconnaissance functions they can also
be used for attacking surface ships and submarines, and as transport aircraft to
supplement Transport Command. The Shackletons are being modernised and
are due for replacement by the HS801 (derived from the Comet 4C) in 1969-70.
Air mobility forces are made up of the strategic and tactical transport forces,
tanker aircraft to refuel combat aircraft in flight, and communications aircraft.
Their cost in 1966-67 is estimated at £135 million.
The strategic transport force at present consists of Britannia and Comet
Mark 2 and Mark 4 aircraft. The Belfast and YC10 are being introduced.
Tactical transports include the medium-range Hastings and Beverley aircraft
(to be replaced by the United States Hercules in 1967) and the Argosy. The
short-range tactical transports are the Pioneer and Twin Pioneer aircraft and
the Belvedere, Whirlwind and Wessex helicopters. The Andover Mark 1
short-range military freighter is coming into service. The Victor tanker
aircraft can refuel two or three aircraft at the same time. The Basset {Beagle
B 206) and Andover C Mark 2 aircraft are now in use for communications.
HOME DEFENCE
The second world war showed the importance of having trained and organised
bodies of men and women ready to mitigate the effects of enemy air attacks
on the civil population; and the Civil Defence Act 1948 recognised that a
permanent system of civil defence was an integral part of the country s
defence plan. At the same time, the main defence objective, made imperative
by the development of nuclear weapons, is not to prepare for war but to
prevent it. • • 11 •
Expenditure and other information on home defence is given annually in
the Statement on the Defence Estimates (see p. m). Home defence expenditure
by civil departments in 1966-67 is estimated at ^i9'7 million.
The Civil Following a nuclear attack there would be enormous and immediate devasta-
Defence tion: there would also be millions of survivors in need of help. The civil
Programme defence programme is designed to ensure as many survivors as possible and to
safeguard their well-being by making the best use of essential supplies and
services after an attack.
Warning of Attack The United Kingdom Warning and Monitoring Organisation exists to warn
the public of the threat of air attack and fall-out. Warning would be given by
sirens and other devices from 18,000 points throughout the United Kingdom
and by BBC broadcasts. Information about nuclear bursts and radioactive
fall-out would be collected by the Royal Observer Corps. The Organisation
would also provide civil and military authorities in the United Kingdom (and
neighbouring NATO countries) with a scientific appreciation of the predicted
path and probable intensity of fall-out.

Dispersal and
Shelter
Supplies and
Communications
Organisation
Civil Defence
Regional
Organisation
A scheme has been drawn up for the voluntary dispersal from the larger towns
of people who would be at a special disadvantage in times of enemy attack—
some 43 per cent of the population of the dispersal areas. These are mainly
children and their mothers, expectant mothers and those disabled, aged and
infirm people who are dependent on others taking part in the dispersal scheme.
It would be impossible to provide protection by shelter within any area of
complete devastation caused by nuclear explosion, and beyond the country’s
resources to provide specially constructed underground shelters all over the
country as a protection against blast, heat and fall-out. Nevertheless, protective
shelter against some of the effects of nuclear explosions could be provided
relatively simply for most households and advice on this is given in civil
defence publications.
Plans have been made for safeguarding essential supplies of food, electricity,
gas and water and for maintaining the functioning of ports, shipping and rail¬
ways. Provision is also being made for stockpiling, storing and distributing
oil and emergency medical supplies. Special attention is being given to
safeguarding telephone communications and broadcasting.
of Civil defence planning in Britain is the responsibility of a number of ministers
each of whom undertakes the duties which, in war time, would represent a
natural extension of his peace-time functions. The central Government has
enlisted the assistance of local government authorities, of industry and
commerce and of public bodies of many kinds, including voluntary organisa¬
tions such as the Voluntary Aid Societies and the Women’s Royal Voluntary
Service, for the local execution of the plans.
In England and Wales the Home Secretary co-ordinates the work of
government departments in home defence planning and supervises the civil
defence activities of the police and fire services, the Civil Defence Corps
and the Industrial Civil Defence Service. Other government departments have
direct responsibility for the civil defence applications of the services which
they control; for example, the Ministry of Health is responsible for the hospital
and first-aid services (including the National Hospital Service Reserve) and
the Post Office for telecommunications.
In Scotland the Scottish Home and Health Department deals with questions
corresponding to those dealt with by the Home Office in England and Wales,
and is responsible for such matters as the hospital and first-aid services.
In Northern Ireland the Civil Defence Act (Northern Ireland) 1950
places responsibility for civil defence matters on the Ministry of Home Affairs,
which may arrange for other departments to undertake some functions on its
behalf.
Co-ordination of government activity in war time would be undertaken in
the nine civil defence regions in England by Regional Commissioners, who
would assume full responsibility if control by the central Government were
disrupted. Similar arrangements would apply in Scotland and Wales.
Northern Ireland would be under one central control.
In England and Wales the regions are divided into two or more sub-regions
in each of which the main government departments, the police, fire service
and public utilities would be represented, so that effective government
would continue if communications with the regional headquarters were cut
off. Below sub-regional level, control is based on administrative counties and
county boroughs and, within counties, on county districts. The purpose of this
system of control is to direct life-saving operations after attack and to provide
124
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The Fire
Service
The Police
Role of the
Armed Forces
a framework of civil administration to marshal and co-ordinate the use of
available resources to the best advantage for the continued survival of the
community.
In time of war the fire brigades maintained by local authorities would be
brought under central control and formed into a National Fire Service, which
would be expanded by the mobilisation of such members of the Auxiliary
Fire Service as were available for whole-time service. The strength of the
Auxiliary Fire Service in March 1966 was 13,096.
Auxiliary firemen are trained by officers and men of the regular brigades.
In addition, both regular and auxiliary firemen receive special training in
emergency fire-fighting at the Home Office Fire Service Training Centre at
Moreton-in-Marsh, Gloucestershire. Auxiliary firemen perform stand-by duty
at fire stations to enable them to respond, with regular members of the brigade,
to calls to fires and take part in exercises involving the control and operation
of large numbers of pumping and other fire-fighting appliances. Auxiliaries
are expected to do 50 hours’ standard training before taking advanced training
to qualify for a bounty of £10 to £15, according to rank; those not wishing to
qualify pass into the Auxiliary Fire Service Reserve and are required to attend
a minimum of one annual exercise or parade.
In time of war the police would continue to be responsible for the prevention
of crime, for the maintenance of law and order and for the control of essential
service routes. They are also likely to have duties in connection with dispersal,
care of the homeless and other specialised civil defence tasks. In all these
duties they would have the aid of the Special Constabulary.
The Secretary of State for Defence plans the part to be played by the armed
forces in home defence. In addition plans for a military home defence force of
between 20,000 and 30,000 men (T & AYR III, the Territorials, see p. 116)
were announced in 1966. This will supplement military units in the United
Kingdom, assist the police in the maintenance of law and order, and act in
support of the civil authorities in the event of a general war.
