COAL
The National
Coal Board
Pattern and
Trends in
Supply and
Demand
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
for coal in 1947, for electricity in 1948 and for gas in 1949; each consisting
of a chairman and from 20 to 30 unpaid members appointed from nominations
put forward by interested bodies selected by the ministers as representing
consumers. In the electricity and gas supply industries councils and commit¬
tees have been formed on an area and district basis; for coal there are councils
at national level only.
Coal has been worked in Britain for over 700 years and an organised coal¬
mining industry has been in existence for over 300 years, some 200 years
longer than in any other country. British coal exports dominated the world
market until about 1910. By 1913—the peak production year—the industry
was producing 287 million tons of coal, exporting 94 million tons and
employing over a million workers. Economic depression in Britain and
mounting competition in overseas markets caused a decline during the inter¬
war years (1919-39) and both inland consumption and exports fell substan¬
tially, bringing a reduction in the number of pits in operation. Measures were
introduced to rationalise production in larger and more efficient units. During
the second world war the industry came under the control of the government.
In 1947 the coal mines passed into public ownership by means of the Coal
Industry Nationalisation Act 1946, which set up the National Coal Board as
a statutory corporation to manage the industry.
The National Coal Board (NCB) consists of a chairman and between eight
and eleven members appointed by the Minister of Power. The NCB has the
exclusive monopoly to extract coal in Great Britain, but is empowered to
license private operators to work small pits and open-cast sites. It has no
monopoly in distribution, and retail sales remain largely in private hands, but
it has, however, some retail depots and makes bulk sales to large industrial
consumers.
The NCB is responsible for the day-to-day running and the commercial
management of the industry, but is answerable to the minister (and through
him, to Parliament) for its efficiency. The minister has power to issue
directives on matters affecting the public interest, and to authorise borrowings
to finance capital investment.
The 483 collieries in operation at the end of March 1966 were grouped into
37 areas, which are the basic units for commercial management. The areas
in turn are grouped into eight geographical zones which roughly correspond
to the main coal-bearing regions; in each zone, a senior resident executive of
the NCB is responsible for co-ordination and for certain common-user
services. Plans to amalgamate the areas will reduce the total to about 17 by
1969-70.
Coal consumption in Britain increased by an average annual rate of nearly
4 million tons between 1947 and 1956; inland sales fell sharply between 195
and 1959 and large stocks of coal accumulated at pit heads. Growing competi¬
tion from oil, increasing efficiency in the use of coal and reduced requirements
of the gas, steel and other industries have contributed to the fall in demand.
Since 1963 undistributed end-of-year stocks have been maintained at about
18-20 million tons. The fall in consumption is shown in Table 15.
Nearly two-fifths of total output is consumed by the electricity authorities
and over one-quarter by domestic and industrial users together. Coke ovens
and the gas industry are other large users. Consumption by the electricity
industry has increased by one-quarter since 1961 to 69 million tons in 1965,
INDUSTRY
Production and
Manpower
TABLE 15
Coal
Statistics,
1950-65
267
whereas the requirements of all the other main classes of consumer have
declined. In the case of domestic users this fall has been slightly offset by
increased purchases of solid smokeless fuels.
Coal exports have fallen heavily since the second world war due mainly,
at first, to increased internal consumption and, later, to keener competition.
Exports fell from the post-war peak of 19 million tons in 1949 to 3-8 million
tons, valued at £19 million in 1965. The principal markets are the Netherlands,
France, the Federal Republic of Germany, Belgium, Norway, Denmark, the
Irish Republic and Sweden.
It has been estimated that Britain’s workable reserves of coal will last for
about 200 years at current rates of consumption. Howrever, the very fact that
the British industry was developed so early has meant that many of the best
seams of coal are now worked out; every year coal has to be mined from deeper
and thinner seams and productivity can be maintained only by a high level of
re-equipment and constant modernisation.
The main coal-bearing areas are: (1) the Yorkshire, Derbyshire and
Nottinghamshire field, which produces about 48 per cent of the total output,
(2) the Durham and Northumberland field, (3) the South Wales field, and
(4) the Scottish field. Other important coal-bearing areas are those of Lanca¬
shire and the West Midlands (Staffordshire and Warwickshire).

According to forecasts by the Ministry of Power, the fall in coal consump¬
tion shown in Table 15 is likely to continue, but requirements may be
stabilised at about 170-180 million tons in 1970. The NCB plans to improve
the competitive position of coal by restricting production to the most efficient
pits. Between 1966 and 1969-70 about one-third of the pits are scheduled to
be closed and the total labour force will fall by 22 per cent to about 333,000
colliery workers. Productivity has risen by over 25 per cent since 1961, and
three-quarters of output now comes from new or reconstructed collieries,
some with a daily output of 6,000 tons and a few of up to 8,000 tons; at
mechanised faces output averages 6-7 tons per shift as compared with 3-8 tons
268

Investment and

Structure
Research
at non-mechanised faces, the average for all faces being about 5J tons. In 1965,
output per manshift at NCB mines rose by nearly 4 per cent to i-8 tons, with
35,000 fewer workers. Among measures contributing to higher productivity
are new designs for loading and mechanical handling, improved layouts for
pit-bottoms and the extension of horizon mining. Experimental remotely
controlled longwall faces have proved successful at two Midlands collieries
and are to be installed in others. The Bevercotes colliery in the East Midlands
is the first in the world to be planned as a fully mechanised and automated
pit from the coal face to the surface.
The National Coal Board raises capital, including working capital, by borrow¬
ing directly from the Exchequer. At present there is a statutory limit of
£750 million on such borrowing, but borrowing above £700 million must be
authorised by Order in Council. Within these limits the Board may, with the
permission of the Minister of Power, borrow temporarily (by way of overdraft
or otherwise). The greater proportion of investment, however, is financed
from internal resources.
Capital expenditure by the industry totalled £462 million from 1947 t° 1955
and about ^790 million in the nine years 1956 to end-March 1964. At the end
of the 1964-65 financial year the total capital debt to the Exchequer amounted
to about £960 million. In 1965 a fresh study was made of the NCB’s capital
structure, and legislation was enacted to effect a capital reorganisation,
involving the writing off of ^415 million of the existing debt. As a result, the
total debt to the Exchequer at the end of March 1965 was reduced to £545
million.
Under the nationalisation statute, the NCB has been required to break even
on its current account (taking one year with another) after meeting all proper
charges including provision for reserves. It has made surpluses in some years
and deficits in others. In certain areas, such as Scotland, Lancashire and Wales,
deficits have been persistent, and profits from the areas of high productivity,
for instance, the Midlands, have been inadequate to cover the losses sustained.
By March 1965 the accumulated deficit on the current account had reached
3^91 million which was included in the ^4I5 million to be written off (see
above). Interest payments and depreciation provisions will be reduced as a
result of this writing off.
To assist the redeployment of manpower and the elimination of uneco¬
nomic colliery capacity, the 1965 Coal Industry Act authorises the Ministry
of Power to make grants, with contributions on an equal basis from the NCB,
to meet expenditure up to a limit of £30 million over the five years to
igyi.
The NCB has three research organisations: a Coal Research Establishment,
at Stoke Orchard, near Cheltenham, Gloucestershire, providing facilities for
fundamental research; a Mining Research Establishment, for the investigation
of underground problems, at Isleworth, Middlesex; and a Central Engineering
Establishment for developing new machines and testing equipment, near
Bretby, Derbyshire. In 1959 the Board set up a new department concerned
primarily with the further development of new processes for making smokeless
fuels. In 1947 the NCB took over the Coal Survey, a national organisation
for surveying coal resources within Britain; it has 7° laboratories in the various
coalfields.
A number of autonomous research associations receiving grants from the
NCB and the Ministry of Technology include the British Coal Utilisation

Research Association, the British Coke Research Association and the Coal Tar
Research Association. Much of the work of other bodies, such as the Safety
in Mines Research Establishment (SMRE), is closely related to the Board’s
problems; the SMRE carries out research on explosions and fires, pneumo¬
coniosis, engineering and metallurgy.
The petroleum industry in Britain dates back to 1850, when Dr. James Young,
a Glasgow chemist, succeeded in obtaining lamp oil and lubricants from
natural mineral oil occurring in the Derbyshire coal measures. The Scottish
shale deposits, yielding similar products, were first worked in 1858 and ceased
production in 1962.
Sources of crude oil within Britain meet only 1 ton in every 800 of total
United Kingdom requirements, the remainder being imported from overseas.
Annual production of crude oil from indigenous oilfields now totals about
80,000 tons. Prospecting for crude petroleum has so far led to the establishment
of several small oilfields, notably in Nottinghamshire (Eakring, Egmanton
and Bothamsell), in Leicestershire (Plungar), in Lincolnshire (Gainsborough)
and in Dorset (Kimmeridge).
Seismic prospecting in the North Sea has been going on since 1962. Under
the Continental Shelf Act 1964, the Minister of Power, by a system of licensing
for exploration and production, controls those activities in the areas over the
Shelf appertaining to the United Kingdom. Britain’s share of the North Sea
shelf amounts to about 100,000 square miles. Licences covering about 42,000
square miles were issued in 1964 and 1965 (a few being in the Irish Sea).
Drilling, wdiich started in 1964, has proved the existence of four fields of
natural gas capable of commercial production. A substantial field of natural
gas was also proved in 1966 in North Yorkshire, near Scarborough.
British and British-Dutch oil companies have been responsible for developing
the oil resources of many countries to mutual advantage, especially in the
Middle East, Far East and Caribbean areas.
Today these companies produce about one-third of all oil entering into
international trade, with a tanker fleet (partly owned by them and partly on
charter) amounting to nearly a quarter of the world’s tanker tonnage. (United
Kingdom registered tanker tonnage is nearly one-seventh of the world’s total.)
In 1965 the United Kingdom imported 66 million tons of crude oil valued
at £431 million, the largest single item among imported products; approxi¬
mately 22 per cent came from Kuwait, the other largest suppliers being Iraq,
Libya, Venezuela and Nigeria in that order.
Deliveries of petroleum products for inland consumption in 1965 totalled
slightly over 67 million tons, having risen by more than half since i960. An
outstanding feature has been the continued rapid advance in the use of black
oils. Fuel oil consumption (excluding refineries) has been expanding at the
rate of over if million tons a year since i960 and totalled about 27 million tons
in 1965. Demand for gas and diesel oils (excluding that used in road vehicles)
rose by a further 0-9 million tons to 6-9 million tons in 1965. Sales of motor
spirit in recent years, after expanding by half a million tons annually for some
years, increased by nearly 1 million tons to about 10 million tons in 1964 and
to lof million tons in 1965.
A more detailed analysis of deliveries of gas and diesel oils for 1965 shows
that their most important uses were for non-industrial central heating,
270
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Refineries
Oil Pipelines
agricultural tractors and the railways. Electricity generation accounted for about
22 per cent of total fuel oil consumption, excluding that used in oil refineries;
the steel industry accounted for 16 per cent and non-industrial central
heating for a further 10 per cent. Of the remainder, the largest users were
the cement, paper-making, general chemical, glass, engineering, brickmaking
and fishing industries.
Before 1939 three-quarters of the United Kingdom’s supply of petroleum
products was refined overseas, as it was considered more economical to
refine at the source of production. Since the second world war, however,
the industry has come to favour the siting of refineries in the consuming
areas.
By mid-1966 rated refinery capacity in the United Kingdom amounted
to over 70 million tons a year. Of the 18 refineries in operation, four have a
capacity of under 0-2 million tons. The seven largest are situated at Fawley,
near Southampton (11-3 million tons which is being raised to 16-5 million
tons); Stanlow, in Cheshire (9-8 million tons); Isle of Grain (10 million tons)
and Shellhaven (9-8 million tons), both on the Thames Estuary; two at
Milford Haven in Pembrokeshire (6-3 million tons and 4-6 million tons) and
at Llandarcy near Swansea (8 million tons). Other important refineries are
located at Belfast, and on the Firth of Forth (Grangemouth). These, and
other projects in hand or planned (notably on Humberside and Tees-side,
both of which will become important refining areas), will bring Britain’s total
capacity to over 100 million tons a year by the end of 1968.
Output of refined products (excluding refineries’ own consumption) has
risen steadily; from 4 million tons in 1948 to 25! million tons in 1954, 40
million tons in i960 and the record total of 60 million tons in 1965. There is
a substantial external trade in refined products which tends to follow trading
and seasonal requirements and the commercial arrangements of the oil
companies. Exports from Britain, mainly in the form of heavier products
to European countries, were valued at ^108 million in 1965; imports of
refined products including liquefied gases amounted to ^177 million.
Three major oil pipelines are at present in operation in Britain carrying crude
oil from harbours capable of berthing very large tankers to refineries. One in
Scotland (from Finnart on Loch Long to Grangemouth) and one in South
Wales (from Angle Bay, Milford Haven, to Llandarcy) and a third on Mersey¬
side (from Tranmere to Stanlow). Pipelines carry refined products from
refineries to major marketing areas, where the volume transported is sufficient
to justify the capital cost; for example, a complex of lines runs from the
Stanlow, Cheshire, refinery to the Manchester area and another, 78 miles long,
takes petroleum feedstock from Fawley refinery to the £100 million petroleum
chemicals plant at Severnside, near Bristol; others carry refined products
from Fawley to west London and London Airport and from Walton-on-
Thames to London Airport. Construction has begun on a pipeline system
with an initial capacity of 3 million tons a year to feed refined products to the
Midlands from refineries and installations on the Thames and Mersey.
Construction is also in progress of a crude oil line from Stanlow to Heysham,
a refined products line from Stanlow to Haydock and an ethylene line from
the Tees to the Mersey. Meanwhile, parts of the system of pipelines laid
during the second world war are being used by the petroleum distributing
companies. The Pipelines Act 1962 is designed to secure the orderly
development of privately owned industrial pipelines.

Research into problems of petroleum technology is carried out mainly by the
leading oil companies, which have also endowed research at the universities
on a substantial scale. Research centres are situated at Sunbury-on-Thames
(the British Petroleum Company), Thornton, in Cheshire, and Woodstock,
in Kent (Shell), and Abingdon, in Berkshire (Esso). The first of these covers
the full range of petroleum research and development, from geology and
production to product utilisation and petroleum chemicals. In general, the
remainder are concerned with the evolution of new and improved fuels and
lubricants and the development of new uses for petroleum products and of
new products based on petroleum, especially chemicals.
A public supply of electricity was first provided in Britain in 1881, at
Godaiming, Surrey. From its earliest days a measure of public control has
been a feature of the industry and the Electric Lighting Act 1882 authorised
the Board of Trade to grant licences for the establishment of electricity
undertakings by local authorities or by companies (which the local authorities
might compulsorily purchase after a given period of time) to supply consumers
in given areas. By the turn of the century a variety of independent supply
systems had grown up all over the country. In 1919 the Electricity Commis¬
sioners were set up as a supervisory body and to promote reorganisation on a
national scale through voluntary agreement. In 1926 the Central Electricity
Board was set up to construct and operate a national grid inter-connecting
individual power stations, thus co-ordinating generation and transmission.
In 1943 the North of Scotland Hydro-Electric Board (NSHEB) was estab¬
lished as a public corporation to develop the water power resources of the
Highlands. In 1948 all municipal and private undertakings (other than those
in Northern Ireland) were acquired under the Electricity Act 1947 and vested
in the British Electricity Authority and 14 regional boards, except in the north
of Scotland where they became the responsibility of the NSHEB. Two
subsequent Acts (1954 and !957) effected a measure of decentralisation and
gave the industry its present structure. Electricity supply employs about
250,000 people, including 4,700 in Northern Ireland.
In England and Wales, electricity is generated and transmitted by the Central
Electricity Generating Board (CEGB) and distributed by 12 separate Area
Electricity Boards; co-ordination is effected by the Electricity Council. In
Scotland, two boards—the NSHEB and the South of Scotland Electricity
Board (SSEB)—both generate and distribute electricity. In Northern Ireland,
the Belfast Corporation and the Electricity Board for Northern Ireland generate
and distribute electricity, and the Londonderry Corporation distributes only.
The Electricity Council is the central body of the supply industry with
responsibility for general policy and programmes and for advising the
Minister of Power; it is also responsible for a number of common services,
principally capital financing, research and industrial relations. The Council
consists of a chairman, two deputy chairmen, the chairman and two designated
members of the Central Electricity Generating Board (CEGB), the chairmen
of the 12 Area Electricity Boards and not more than three other members.
The CEGB controls the operation and maintenance of power stations and the
main transmission system (the national grid) and supplies electricity in bulk
to the 12 Area Boards. The CEGB consists of a chairman, a deputy chairman
and between six and eight members. Each of the 12 Area Electricity Boards
acquires bulk supplies of electricity from the CEGB and is responsible for
distribution networks and sales of electricity to its area consumers.
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Area Consultative Councils were set up under the Electricity Act 1947
the area of each board to represent the interests of consumers; their chairmen
are ex officio members of their respective Area Boards. The Minister of Power
appoints the chairmen, deputy chairmen and members of the Electricity
Council, the CEGB, the Area Boards and the Consultative Councils; approves
each Board’s capital development programmes and the industry’s research
programme; and approves, in consultation with the Treasury, the boards
borrowing requirements. The Electricity Act 1957 requires each Board, and
not merely the industry as a whole, to pay its way taking one year with another.
The boundary separating the areas covered by the two Scottish Boards runs
roughly from Dumbarton on the Firth of Clyde to Newburgh on the Firth of
Tay. Members of both Boards and of the respective consumer consultative
councils are appointed by the Secretary of State for Scotland, each Board
comprises a chairman and between four and eight members. The Secretary of
State’s responsibilities in relation to the Boards are similar to those of the
Minister of Power.
In Northern Ireland electricity is generated at power stations in Belfast and
at Ballylumford and Coolkeeragh. Those in Belfast are operated by the city
corporation and the remainder by the Electricity Board for Northern Ireland.
Generation at these stations is co-ordinated by the Northern Ireland Joint
Electricity Committee, set up by statute in 1948, which purchases their output
and resells it to distributors—the Belfast Corporation for Belfast and district,
the Londonderry Corporation for the City of Londonderry, and the Electricity
Board for the rest of Northern Ireland.
Generation As Britain has abundant supplies of coal, together with good rail and water
transport for moving it, most of its electricity is produced by coal-fired steam
generating stations. The development of hydro-electricity on any scale is
comparatively recent, water power resources being relatively small and in
remote areas. By the middle of 1966, however, nuclear energy was contributing
a sizeable volume. . . .
The output capacity of the generating stations of the electricity boards in
Great Britain at the end of 1965 totalled 40,708 megawatts (MW), an increase
of over one-third since i960.
In the years i960 to 1964 an annual average of nearly 2,000 MW of
generating capacity was installed, and this rose to a record level of 3>5°0 MW
in 1965. It is planned to commission 20,000 MW of capacity in England and
Wales in the period 1965-68 inclusive. In the north of Scotland it is planned
to increase capacity from 1,331 MW at the end of 1965 to 1,840 MW by i97°-
The South of Scotland Electricity Board’s proposals provide for its total
capacity of 2,700 MW at the end of 1965 to be increased to 5,600 MW by 1970.
Sales of electricity in Northern Ireland (where, of the total installed
generating capacity of 797 MW, 240 MW is in oil-fired and the remainder in
coal-fired thermal stations) amounted to 2,336 million kilowatt-hours in 1965.
Generation by the public supply in Great Britain exceeded 174,000 million
kilowatt-hours in 1965: conventional steam power stations provided 90 per cent
of the total and hydro-electric and nuclear stations about 2 per cent and 7
per cent respectively. The high rate of expansion of output, which has been
a feature of the industry since its earliest years, has been maintained. The
total volume generated increased by 47 per cent between i960 and 1965.
Generation of electricity outside the public supply system is relatively
small—under 20,000 million kilowatt-hours in 1965. The major sources

In the mid-1950s, when a coal shortage seemed likely, programmes for oil¬
firing at conventional thermal stations and for generating from nuclear energy
were introduced. There are 14 oil-burning power stations, or parts of
stations, operating in Great Britain (excluding old stations converted to oil¬
firing to satisfy clean air legislation). They are mainly situated on river estuaries
and thus able to be fed conveniently from oil refineries. A 2,000 MW oil-fired
station is under construction at Fawley, on Southampton Water.
The electricity authorities are the largest consumers of primary fuel in
Britain and, although most of their electricity generation is based on coal, oil
consumption rose from a negligible quantity in 1955 to over 5-5 million
tons in 1962 and to 5-8 million tons in 1965. Average thermal efficiency of
conventional steam stations in England and Wales (that is, the ratio of power
output to the fuel consumed) rose from 20-75 Per cent J947 to 27-32 per
cent in 1964 as new plant was brought into use. The 20 most efficient stations,
containing much of the newest plant, had an average efficiency of 32-98 per
cent in 1964-65.
Striking advances have been made in the design of steam-generating plant.
A cross-compound generating unit with an output capacity of 550 MW came
into operation in 1963 at Thorpe Marsh, near Doncaster. The largest single¬
shaft units of 500 MW, which came into operation in 1966, are at Ferrybridge
‘C’, West Burton, near Retford, and Eggborough, near Selby (for location
see map p. 264). These show substantial economies in capital and operating
costs and in fuel consumption, and larger units of 660 MW are planned.
Station capacities are also increasing. By 1970, ten, each with capacities of 2,000
MW, with four 500 MW single-shaft generating units, will be in service. An
even larger station of 4,000 MW is under construction at Drax, in Yorkshire.
In Scotland, a 1,200 MW station at Cockenzie (1968) and one of 2,400 MW
(four generating units of 600 MW) at Longannet (1971) are under construction.
Large gas turbine units of 55 MW and 70 MW, based on aero jet engines,
have been introduced since 1965 for peak load operation. The CEGB and
South of Scotland Electricity Board have installed 846 MW of such units.

Hydro-Electric
Nuclear Power
Stations
Smaller gas turbines have been introduced at new stations to safeguard the
auxiliary supplies to the large new steam units, and also to provide capacity
for peak operation. Auxiliary units of this kind in service at the end of 1966
will total 330 MW, and by 1970 will exceed 1,000 MW.
Hydro-electric generation is confined to Scotland and Wales, and most of the
water-power so utilised is drawn from high-level reservoirs with their own
natural catchment areas. The setting up of the North of Scotland Hydro-
Electric Board in 1943 marked the beginning of an era of intensive water¬
power development in the Highlands of Scotland. A development scheme was
drawn up by the Board in 1944, showing the water-power resources which it
proposed to examine.
In 1965-66, 2,900 million units were generated by the North of Scotland
Board from water-power, compared with 322 million in 1949. At the end of
March 1966 there were 53 main hydro-electric stations in operation in the
north of Scotland with a total installed capacity of 1,040 MW and the largest—
the Loch Sloy station—had a capacity of 130 MW; the Cruachan pumped
storage section of the Awe scheme, with an installed capacity of 400 MW from
four reversible-pump-turbines, was planned to be in full operation by the end
of 1966. Under construction and survey were 199 MW of conventional hydro¬
electric capacity together with a 1,200 MW pumped storage project at Loch
Sloy. In addition, there are stations generating electricity by water-power in the
south of Scotland (123 MW) and in Wales (473 MW). The latter includes the
360 MW pumped storage station at Ffestiniog, which was completed in 1963-
(In pumped storage schemes electricity generated in off-peak periods is used to
pump water to higher levels from which it descends at peak periods to
operate turbo-generators.) The CEGB is also examining the feasibility of a
pumped storage project on the north coast of Devon.
Some 8 per cent of Britain’s electricity was generated in nuclear power
stations in 1965 and the proportion is expected to rise to 12 per cent in 1980.
Britain has so far produced as much electricity by this means as the rest of the
world put together.
The AEA itself has four mains stations which produce electricity for the
national grid: Calder Hall, in Cumberland (180 MW electrical output);
Chapelcross, Dumfriesshire (180 MW); the Advanced Gas-Cooled Reactor
(AGR) at Windscale, Cumberland (28 MW); and the experimental fast
breeder station at Dounreay (14 MW).
Others are owned and operated by the electricity authoiities. Under the
first commercial programme, originally announced in 1955 ^ut: s^nce tw^ce
modified, nine stations with a total installed capacity of 5>000 MW should be
in operation by 1969, eight of them by the end of 1967* S° far seven (over
3,000 MW) have started operation: Berkeley, in Gloucestershire (276 MW
output capacity), and Bradwell, in Essex (300 MW), were both commissioned
in 1962; Hunterston, in Scotland (30° MW), in 19645 an<^ following year
Hinkley Point ‘A’, in Somerset, and Trawsfynydd, in Wales (both 500 MW);
Dungeness ‘A’, in Kent (550 MW), andSizewell, in Suffolk (580MW), in 1966.
Oldbury, in Gloucestershire (600 MW), and Wylfa, in Anglesey (1,180 MW),
should be completed by 1967 and 1969 respectively. These stations, like
Calder Hall and Chapelcross, are all magnox stations—graphite-moderated,
carbon-dioxide cooled using natural uranium metal fuel elements canned in
magnesium.
Under a second programme announced in 1964 and extended in i905> a
further 8,000 MW of installed nuclear capacity is planned by 1975. The first

275
station in this programme, Dungeness ‘B’, is based on the AGR at Windscale
which uses ceramic uranium dioxide fuel canned in stainless steel, a logical
development of the magnox system. Due to come into operation in 1971 with
a net electrical output of 1,200 MW it will be the most powerful in the world,
and the first in Britain to produce electricity more cheaply on base load than
the best coal stations.
A large prototype fast reactor (PFR) of 250 MW capacity is being built by
the AEA, to be completed in 1971, at Dounreay where in October 1962 the
experimental fast reactor became the first of such type to produce electricity
for public use and to operate at a high power level.
Main electricity transmission lines—the national grid—supply most of the
country. By 31st March 1965, those of the CEGB totalled some 8,800 route
miles (15,200 circuit miles), of which 2,000 miles were operated at 275,000
volts, 6,500 miles were operated at 132,000 volts and the remainder at 66,000
volts and below. In Scotland there were some 3,900 circuit miles of main
transmission lines at the end of 1965, of which 1,050 circuit miles operated at
275,000 volts and the remainder at 132,000 volts. Energy movements on the
grid in England and Wales are controlled through the seven operational areas,
set up for that purpose and distinct from the regions in which the generating
side of the industry is organised; each area has a separate control, and the
operations are co-ordinated by a National Control in London. The grid in
Scotland is operated from the control centres at Pitlochry (North of Scotland)
and at Kirkintilloch (South of Scotland).
To reduce the number of new transmission lines needed to meet the
country’s increasing power demands, most of the new ‘supergrid’ of main
transmission lines now operating at 275,000 volts are, since 1965, being up¬
rated to operate at 400,000 volts. The development of the grid system has
made the British system the largest integrated power network in the world.
Twin cross-Channel cables laid between Dungeness and Boulogne, capable
of transmitting up to 160 MW at 200,000 volts (direct current) have been
in operation since 1961; by this means advantage is taken of the differences
between France and Britain in the timing of peak loads.
In England and Wales the Area Electricity Boards distribute to consumers
electricity acquired mainly from the Central Electricity Generating Board,
supplemented from other sources, such as industrial plants and the nuclear
power stations of the AEA. There are nearly 17 million consumers. Industrial
concerns are the biggest users of electricity. The principal domestic uses of
electricity are for lighting, cooking and for space and water heating, but the
demand for numerous other domestic purposes is rising steadily.
The North of Scotland Hydro-Electric Board has also pressed ahead with
the distribution of electricity to consumers in the north of Scotland. At the
end of March 1966 it had about 428,500 consumers of electricity, many of them
in remote areas, and well over four-fifths of the farms and crofts had a supply
of electricity. At the same date the South of Scotland Electricity Board
supplied 1-4 million consumers, including over 97 per cent of the farmers in
the area.
About 11 per cent of the annual gross fixed capital formation of the United
Kingdom in 1965 was attributable to the electricity supply industry. The
industry in recent years has based its capital needs for five years ahead on an
average annual increase in demand of about 7 to 9 per cent; its plans for the
future are based on an average annual growth of 8 per cent.

Capital expenditure of the electricity supply industry has been expanding
very rapidly: from £242 million in 1956 it rose to £378 million in 1961 and
£584 million in 1965. More than two-fifths of the industry’s capital require¬
ments have been financed from internal resources. The statutory limit to
borrowings by the industry in Great Britain is £4,980 million. The industry
(other than the NSHEB) is required to aim at a gross return of 12^ per cent
on its net assets.
The Electricity Council, in consultation with the Minister of Power, is
responsible for drawing up a general programme of research, comprising:
direct research carried out by the Electricity Boards themselves; sponsored
research undertaken for the supply industry by universities and colleges;
and co-operative research with other organisations, in particular the industrial
research associations to which the supply industries subscribe. The Council
itself is empowered to conduct research. It is advised by the Electricity Supply
Research Council.
The main research establishments of the industry are run by the Central
Electricity Generating Board and comprise the Central Electricity Research
Laboratories at Leatherhead, Surrey, the Berkeley Laboratories in Glouces¬
tershire, concerned with nuclear problems, and the Engineering Laboratories
at Marchwood on Southampton Water. In 1965 the Electricity Council
established a research centre at Capenhurst, Cheshire, at which intensive
research is being undertaken on distribution problems (to supplement the
work undertaken at the Central Electricity Research Laboratories) and on
appliances and methods of electricity utilisation.
Both Scottish electricity boards carry out research and experimental work
either on their own or in co-operation with other electricity authorities. The
North of Scotland Hydro-Electric Board undertakes a wide range of research
and development work, both independently and in conjunction with the
British Electrical and Allied Industries Research Association, colleges of
science and technology, universities and manufacturers. The South of
Scotland Electricity Board has recently extended its own research activities
and is associated with those of the Electricity Council and Central Electricity
Generating Board in England.
Public supply of gas in Britain dates from 1807, when Pall Mall, London,
was first lighted with gas. In 1812 the London and Westminster Gas Light
and Coke Company received a Royal Charter to supply gaslight in London.
In the early years of the industry gas was used almost exclusively for lighting
and was provided by a growing number of company and municipal under¬
takings.
The gas industry in its present form developed in the main during the
period between the two world wars when increasing competition from
electricity had to be met, and by 1939 ^he industry had become mainly a
supplier of heating rather than lighting.
The Gas Act of 1948 brought the industry in Great Britain, in which about
123,000 persons are at present employed, under public ownership and control
on 1 st May 1949. The assets of 991 undertakings, of which 269 belonged to
local authorities, were vested in 12 Area Gas Boards. The central body is
the Gas Council, appointed by the Minister of Power. It is both a co-ordinating
council and, since the enactment of the Gas Act 1965, a trading body,
consisting of a full-time chairman and deputy chairman, the 12 chairmen

of the area boards and up to three other members. Its general duties are to
advise the Minister on questions affecting the industry and promote the
efficient performance of their duties by the area boards. It has also specific
duties relating to finance, labour relations and research.
The Area Gas Boards, which have a large measure of financial and opera¬
tional responsibility and are similar in most respects to the central bodies
of the other publicly owned corporations, are responsible for manufacturing
gas and distributing it to consumers. Each of the Area Gas Boards, appointed
by the Minister of Power, consists of a full-time chairman and deputy chair¬
man, in some cases one or more full-time members, and usually five or six
part-time members, including the chairman of the Area Consultative Council.
There is no common pattern of organisation; each board is fully independent
and has devised its own subordinate structure. Each is required to pay its
way, taking one year with another. The operations of the area boards have
resulted, in the 16 years up to 31st March 1965, in an aggregate disposable
surplus of approximately ^60 million, before taxation.
In Northern Ireland the gas supply industry remains in the hands of a
number of municipal undertakings and statutory and non-statutory companies.
The chief method of gas production in Britain used to be by carbonising coal
but oil-based production is expanding markedly; more than one-third of gas
supplied in 1965 was derived from oil, and 1-5 million tons were used, more
than double the amount in 1962. The gas industry used about 18 million
tons of coal (25 million tons in 1958) and another 25! million tons were
carbonised in coke ovens other than those of the gas industry.
About one-third of the output of gas from coke ovens is sold to gas under¬
takings for general distribution; the remainder is mainly consumed at the
ovens or at steelworks. There are about 13 million consumers, the total having
shown no significant change since 1955. Manufactured gas and gas acquired
from coke ovens and other sources for distribution exceeds 700,000 million
cubic feet annually.
In 1965 the quantity of gas produced in Northern Ireland was about
6,500 million cubic feet, most of it for household use.
Half of all gas is sold by gas boards for household use and the remainder for
industrial and commercial purposes. Total consumption has been rising at an
average rate of over 6 per cent per annum since 1961, after a period when
growth was almost negligible. During the very cold winter of 1962-63 the
rate was even higher. It reached a level of about 3,750 million therms1 in
1965, an increase of about 10 per cent on the previous year.
About 50 per cent of the domestic load is used for cooking and about 25 per
cent for space heating, the remaining 25 per cent being spread over water
heating and other installations. Most homes in Britain are supplied with gas,
except in some rural areas where, owing to difficulties in storage and trans¬
mission, mains gas is not economic, and bottled gas, derived from petroleum,
is widely used.
Gas is used extensively in industries which require the control of temperatures
to a fine degree of accuracy, for example, in the pottery industry and in
certain processes in the manufacture of iron and steel products. In 1964-65
sales of gas to industry totalled 915 million therms.

Production of coke at gas works in 1965 was 7-8 million tons (a fall of one-fifth
in two years) and at coke ovens 17-1 million tons, reflecting on the one hand
the increasing use of oil and on the other a continuing high level of activity in
the steel industry. The gas industry and coke ovens jointly produce about
3 million tons of crude coal tar and over 100 million gallons of crude benzole a
year. These latter by-products yield materials widely employed in the newer
branches of the chemical industry.
Capital
Investment
Lines of
Development
Under the Gas Act 1948, borrowing by the Gas Council and the Area Gas
Boards was limited to £250 million. In 1954 the industry’s borrowing powers
were increased to j£450 million, in i960 to ^525 milli011* in I9^3 £650
million and in 1965 to £1,200 million.
The industry had been spending about £50 million a year on capital invest¬
ment in the period 1955 to 1961 but since 1961-62 expenditure has increased
sharply; in 1965-66 it reached £118 million and £190 million has been
approved for 1966—67. Between vesting day (1st May 1949) the end of
March 1965, about £940 million had been invested in fixed assets.
Considerable integration, by the linking of works for the transmission of gas
through gas grids and long-distance mains, has enabled production to be
concentrated in the most efficient units.
To maintain its competitive position, the gas industry has investigated
new and more economic methods of production and new sources of gas
supply. Although two plants which use the Lurgi method for the complete
gasification of inferior grades of coal have been commissioned, their capital
cost is high. More significant have been the developments in the gasification
of oil. In the 1950s these plants were small, produced gas at lower pressure
and were designed to meet peak-load needs. More recently the introduction
of processes using light distillates in large units producing gas at high pressure
has permitted even greater savings to be made in both capital and running
costs.
The work done in the Gas Council’s Midlands Research Station led to the
introduction of two new methods of manufacture, the Gas Recycle Hydro-
genator and the Catalytic Rich Gas processes, both of which enable a high
calorific value gas to be manufactured entirely from light distillate feedstock
without the need for enrichment from any outside source. The first plants
incorporating these processes were put on stream in 1965* Gas made from
oil and gas purchased from refineries now amounts to over one-third of the
total supply available and the proportion is steadily increasing.
During 1965 deliveries of gas from the Sahara reached their planned level
of 35,000 million cubic feet annually, equivalent to about 10 per cent of total
consumption. A pipeline system distributes the gas from a terminal on Canvey
Island to eight of the 12 Area Boards.
The discovery of productive wells in the North Sea in 1965 and 1966
confirms the presence of natural gas (see p. 269). A pipeline is being con¬
structed to the coast, with the flow for commercial use planned to start by the
end of 1966. Although it is not yet possible to assess the quantities of gas
likely to be available from the North Sea discoveries and also from those in
Yorkshire, they are expected to be substantial. The chairman of the Gas
Council has stated the industry plans to switch over entirely to natural gas
within the next 10 to 15 years.
The Gas Council expects gas consumption to increase by some 10 per
cent a year up to 1970 and therefore substantial expansion is required. The

need to provide additional storage capacity, particularly in underground
reservoirs of porous rock (regulated under the Gas Act 1965), and the strength¬

The Gas Council has a research committee which advises on the initiation
and implementation of research policy. Research organisations comprise five
stations in addition to Watson House at Fulham, London, for the design,
testing and development of appliances. Research is also carried out on behalf
of the Gas Council at Leeds University and at other universities and colleges.
Efficiency in the use of fuel, among both industrial and domestic users, has
been assisted by various bodies representing producers and consumers and
by the technical advisory services of the fuel and power industries.
The Coal Utilisation Council consists of representatives of the National
Coal Board, solid fuel distributors and appliance manufacturers and dis¬
tributors. Originally formed in 1932, it informs and advises domestic users
on the best use of solid fuel, including the choice of installation and the
operation of solid fuel appliances.
A non-profit-making company, the National Industrial Fuel Efficiency
Service, was formed in 1954 sponsored by the fuel and power industries
to promote fuel saving in industry. It provides advice and services to all non¬
domestic fuel users in a variety of forms, from ‘spot’ inspection to full-scale
heat and power surveys and regular visits on a contract basis.
WATER SUPPLY
Britain’s water resources are, with progressive development, sufficient for
domestic and industrial requirements. The sources of water are often distant
from the areas where supplies are needed, however, and water undertakings
are therefore mainly concerned with abstraction, storage, treatment and
distribution. Supplies are obtained partly from surface sources such as
mountain lakes, streams impounded in upland gathering grounds and river
intakes, and partly from underground sources by means of wells, adits and
boreholes. Unlike other public services in Great Britain, such as electricity and
gas, water supply remains in the hands of a large number of undertakings.
The Government has announced its intention of reorganising the water
supply industry under full public ownership; the then Minister of Land and
Natural Resources was responsible for formulating long-term plans to give
effect to this general policy. Ministerial responsibility in England and Wales
is shared by the Minister of Housing and Local Government and the Secretary
of State for Wales; in Scotland it lies with the Secretary of State for Scotland.
In Northern Ireland ministerial responsibility lies with the Minister of
Development.
It was not until the nineteenth century that the provision of water supplies
became a general public service, largely due to the efforts of Edwin Chadwick
and his colleagues who demonstrated the dangers arising from inadequate
water supply and sanitation. The Public Health Act 1848 laid the basis for
a long series of statutes dealing with public health. From the middle of the
nineteenth century onwards a number of water undertakings were set up
to provide water to the expanding urban population, and the water supply
system developed rapidly, although in piecemeal fashion and with some
overlapping and waste.
K
2g0 BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Local authorities have a duty as sanitary authorities to ensure that water
supplies are adequate for the needs of their areas, and they may do this
either by operating water undertakings themselves or by ensuring that other
bodies are providing adequate supplies. Over one-fifth of the water consumed
is supplied by statutory water companies. The householder receives his
domestic water supply at a comparatively small charge, varying in different
areas, which he usually pays by way of a water rate levied, like other rates
on the value of his house. Industrial users are charged according to actual
material consumption. ,
The Minister of Housing and Local Government and the becretary ot
State for Wales have a duty to promote the conservation and proper use of
water supplies in England and Wales and are advised by the Central Advisory
Water Committee on general questions relating to water and organisation of
supplies. Since the passing of the Water Act 1945, some 800 smaller water
authorities in England and Wales have been absorbed by larger authorities or
by the creation of joint boards in order to improve the efficiency of the water
supply industry. In March 1966 there were in England and Wales 138 local
authority water undertakings, 84 joint water boards (including bulk supp y
boards) and one joint water committee, 41 statutory water companies, nine
non-statutory water companies, and one private proprietor with statutory
powers. A number of private proprietors without statutory powers a.so
provide small supplies. ,
The Metropolitan Water Board supplies over 350 million gallons daily to
the 61 million people in the London area. It consists of 39 part-time members
who are the elected representatives of the various local authorities within the
Board’s area of operations, together with one representative each from the
Thames and Lee Conservancies.
Present Supplies Today, piped water reaches over 95 per cent of the total population of England
and Wales and about 90 per cent of the rural population.
Capital expenditure by water undertakings which averaged about £40
million a year in the period 1955-60 is now at a level of £55 million a year.
Interest, together with running costs, is largely met from annual income.
The provision of piped supplies for rural districts has been assisted by
grants under the Rural Water Supplies and Sewerage Acts 1944 to 1965. By
March 1966 schemes costing nearly £100 million had been completed or
were in progress with the aid of grants under these Acts.
The growth of towns in England and Wales has meant increased demands
for water, the needs of industry having grown so much that in many areas
they now exceed domestic demand. The use of water in irrigation of farm
land is also growing. In order that the country’s water resources should be
developed to meet these growing requirements the Water Resources Act 1963
provided for a new administrative structure consisting of 27 river authorities
and a central Water Resources Board; the Act came into full operation in
April 1965. The river authorities, the Thames Conservancy and the Lee
Conservancy Catchment Board have a majority of members appointed
by the county and county borough councils in their areas. The remainder
are appointed by ministers for their knowledge of land drainage, fisheries,
the public water supply, and water in use in industry and in agriculture.
The authorities manage the water resources of river basins, taking over the
functions of the 30 former river boards in respect of land drainage, flood
control, administration of fisheries and prevention of pollution. They are
responsible for assessing water resources and requirements, controlling and
developing resources and securing regulation by a system of licensing.

Scotland
Northern
Ireland
Measurement
of Resources
281
Special arrangements exist for the Greater London area, where the full range
of river authority control is not necessary. The work of the river authorities
is co-ordinated by the Water Resources Board, an expert advisory body which
reports to the Ministry of Housing and Local Government. Its duties include
the review of national water resources and requirements, the encouragement
of the transfer of water between areas according to need, the co-ordination
of proposals of river authorities for capital investment and the initiation of
research. Water conservation is to be financially self-supporting after an
initial period of about five years, the cost being met from charges made to
abstractors and users of water.
In Scotland public water undertakings are carried on entirely by local
authorities, either separately or in combination with each other; they supply
about 97 per cent of the total population. The water problem in Scotland is
broadly similar to that in England and Wales except that there is not the
same need to allocate water between competing interests and less reliance
needs to be placed on underground sources. The Secretary of State for
Scotland has a general duty to promote the conservation of water resources
in Scotland; require local authorities to provide supplies of wholesome water
everywhere in their districts, where this can be done at reasonable cost; and
provide for a uniform system of rating for water throughout the country. The
Scottish Water Advisory Committee advises the Secretary of State on general
questions relating to resources and supplies. The Rural Water Supplies and
Sewerage Act 1944, as amended, makes available to Scottish local authorities
grant assistance up to a maximum of £45 million towards the cost of water
supplies and sewerage schemes in rural areas.
Northern Ireland has abundant supplies of water for both domestic and
industrial consumption. The Water Supplies and Sewerage Act (Northern
Ireland) 1945 made it obligatory for water supply authorities to provide a
supply of wholesome water to houses and schools in their areas where this
could be done at reasonable cost; the Minister of Health and Local Government
may make grants towards the costs of schemes undertaken by these authorities.
Before 1945 only the more densely populated areas had a piped supply,
but progress has been such that even in the thinly populated rural
districts most households have now been, or soon will be, connected to a
piped supply.
Information on the yield, behaviour and quantity of the nation’s surface
water resources is provided in the Surface Water Year Book of Great Britain,
published annually by Her Majesty’s Stationery Office. This publication
contains particulars of the run-off and related rainfall from a large number of
rivers, streams and reservoired areas. The Water Resources Board is responsible
for the gauging, collation and publication of hydrological information: the field
work of surface water measurement is done by river authorities, water
undertakings and other bodies. Detailed studies of the resources and use of
water in specified areas have been published in the series of Hydrological
Surveys which cover approximately half of England and Wales. General
information on rainfall, published annually in British Rainfall, is the res¬
ponsibility of the Meteorological Office, while advice on ground water is the
responsibility of the Water Resources Board. The Hydraulics Research Station
of the Ministry of Technology at Wallingford and the Water Research
Association’s station at Medmenham carry out research into problems of the
282
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Pollution
Structure
design and calibration of gauging weirs and flumes for the measurement of
surface water, and into other hydraulic problems.
Each river authority is responsible for the prevention of pollution of rivers
and certain tidal waters in its area and its approval must be sought before
polluting effluents are discharged. Control of pollution in the tidal Thames
is exercised by the Port of London Authority (see p. 343)- Scotland nine
river purification boards have been set up. The Secretary of State for Scotland
is advised by the Scottish River Purification Advisory Committee on questions
affecting the cleanliness of Scottish rivers. In several ports the petroleum
companies co-operate in the prevention of oil pollution from tankers and
refineries*
The Water Pollution Research Laboratory at Stevenage investigates
problems connected with the treatment of polluted waters, the treatment
and disposal of sewage and industrial waste water, and the effects and
prevention of pollution of surface water and underground water. Research is
carried out with general supervision and advice from the Water Pollution
Research Board.
CONSTRUCTION
The construction industries include firms engaged on the construction,
alteration, repair and maintenance of buildings, highways, airfields, drainage
and sewerage systems, waterworks, docks, harbours and canals, sea defence
works, electrical wiring, heating and other installation work, open-cast coal
prospecting and mining, and structural work connected with thermo-electric,
hydro-electric power stations and telecommunications. The industries employ
i-8 million persons, including all grades, equivalent to some 7 per cent of the
total labour force. Allowing for new work only, and excluding work carried
out on repairs and maintenance, they provide about 9 per cent of the total
industrial product. , . . . . ,
To meet a growing demand for constructional work arising from plans tor
large scale expansion and modernisation, it is estimated that the industries
will need to increase output by about 50 per cent over the next decade.
This will have to be achieved, in the main, by improvements in produc¬
tivity as any great increase in labour resources to meet these demands is
unlikely.
Constructional work is carried out both by private contractors and by public
authorities who employ their own labour. Nearly five-sixths of the work is
done by private firms. Although there are nearly 90,000 firms in the industry,
about one-quarter of them are one-man businesses. At the other end of the
scale are about 200 firms each employing more than 500 operatives, with some
employing as many as 20,000.
Public authorities as a whole employ nearly 370,000 operatives but a very
large proportion of these are engaged on repair and maintenance work whic
local authorities, for example, carry out with their own labour.
Of the total labour force, nearly a million are skilled operatives who have
been trained under the apprenticeship scheme, taking four to five years to
qualify. About one-third of these skilled men are employed on repair and
maintenance work.

Engineering

283
Some firms are vertically integrated, owning quarries and workshops,
mechanised plant and standard builders’ equipment; some undertake responsi¬
bility for projects from initial design to finished building. All but the smallest
projects are generally carried out under professional direction, either by
architects or, in the case of the more complicated civil engineering projects,
by consulting engineers. The functions of the latter, acting on behalf of a
client, embrace advice on the feasibility of projects, the drawing up of plans
and the supervision of the constructional work by the contractor. There are
over 250 firms of consulting engineers in the United Kingdom.
The Ministry of Public Building and Works (see p. 57) is responsible for
all the construction programmes undertaken directly by the Government
(except for roads), including work for the armed services, both at home and
overseas. It is also responsible for co-ordinating research and development
throughout the government service and seeks to influence methods and
techniques in the building industry as a whole.
The National Building Agency, set up in 1964, is a limited company,
financed initially from government funds. The Agency offers advice to clients,
contractors, materials producers and the building professions on the most
modern ideas and techniques and brings clients’ demands together so that
industrialised methods can be more widely used.
The volume of output of the industry has been rising fairly steadily since 1954,
when building controls ended; by the end of 1965 it was running at an annual
rate more than 50 per cent above the 1958 level. The value of work done in
1965 amounted to £3,848 million, of which £546 million represented work
carried out by the labour employed directly by public authorities. Private
contractors carried out the remaining £3,302 million (£2,631 million on new
work and £671 million on repair work).
Some 5^ million houses and flats have been built in Great Britain since 1945;
about 3J million on behalf of public authorities, mainly for renting, and
about 2^ million for private owners, mainly for sale. About 403,000 houses
were started in 1965 and some £1,051 million of housing work was carried out
by private firms, a record for the total volume of housing work. Of this, about
£585 million, or 56 per cent, was for private owners and the remaining £466
million for public authorities. It is planned to build 500,000 dwellings a year
by 1970. Increasing use is being made of industrial methods in housing
construction employing prefabricated components.
Britain was the first country to develop civil engineering as a large-scale
modern industry and the first to provide techniques, finance and equipment
to carry out major civil engineering projects throughout the world. Prominent
figures in the early development of civil engineering included John McAdam,
pioneer in road construction; Thomas Telford, builder of roads, canals,
docks and railways; George and Robert Stephenson and Isambard Kingdom
Brunei, pioneers of railway building.
Among important construction projects in hand in the United Kingdom in
1966 were a drainage and sewerage scheme in Glasgow, costing £3-5 million,
and another at Davyhulme, costing £6-4 million; several major conventional
power stations and nuclear power stations (see p. 274); the £5 million river
Trent tidal reach improvement scheme; the 10-mile Victoria Tube line in
London, costing £57 million; the Great Ouse water supply scheme, costing

£52 million; and the large-scale reconstruction of the centres of some major
cities, such as Newcastle upon Tyne. Projects for road construction, bridges
and tunnels included a further 124,000 miles of motorways under construction
(see p. 350), major road bridges over the river Severn and the Firth of Tay, and
the £12-6 million tunnel under the river Tyne.
British constructional firms have been as active overseas as in the United
Kingdom. British consulting engineers, in particular, have built up a tradition
of knowledge and integrity which has caused their standards to become
international practice and their services to be in world-wide demand.
Among important construction projects by British contractors in hand in
overseas countries during 1966 were: a new township for the Government of
Bahrain, costing £6 million; the £10 million restoration of the Hejaz railway
in the Middle East; electrification projects on the Indian railways (£6 million);
a £2 million rutile mine township and docks in Sierra Leone. British consul¬
ting engineers were engaged on a number of projects where British contractors
were not commissioned for the construction work. Notable examples were
an airport at Baghdad, costing £12-5 million; a £6-5 million main drainage
scheme for Benghazi; construction of two water barrages in West Pakistan
(£27 million); water supply schemes for Hong Kong (£19 million) and Libya
(£6-2 million); a -£16 million iron and steelworks in Tunisia; and construction
of a dam and tunnel for the Tehran water board (£14 million). On certain
projects both the consulting engineers and the contractors were British,
examples being the second stage in the port of Tema construction in Ghana
(£11 million); and the 12-mile Accra-Tema motorway (£3-3 million).
It has been estimated that the total value of work carried out during the
year ending in March 1966 by over 90 British contractors, operating in 96
countries, was £169 million, compared with £160 million in the previous
year, and that the value of new contracts obtained was £190 million, com¬
pared with £198 million in the previous year. Consulting engineers had
projects worth about £i,3<->® million in hand on 1st January 1966.
The Directorate-General of Research and Development in the Ministry of
Public Building and Works is responsible for co-ordinating research and
information services to increase efficiency in the building industry.
Some of the research establishments of the Ministry of Technology (see
p. 58) deal with subjects relating to the construction industries, in particular
the Building Research Station which was set up in 1921, thus making Britain
the pioneer of organised building research, is concerned with research into
all aspects of building.
The Civil Engineering Research Association financed by grants from the
Ministry of Technology and contributions from the industry promotes
research on problems in civil engineering, making use of existing research
facilities of all types.
The Heating and Ventilating Research Association, an industrial research
organisation, deals with problems of heating and ventilation of large buildings.
The major construction firms have research departments working on plant,
materials and methods. Other bodies concerned with research include the
universities and colleges of technology. Most of the producers of primary
building materials have trade associations which maintain research institutions
chiefly devoted to seeking new and more efficient uses for their materials:
the Timber Research and Development Association and the Cement and
Concrete Association are examples.

MANUFACTURING INDUSTRIES
Britain’s manufacturing industries supply a wide range of products, many
of which are of major importance in world trade. Output has increased by
over a third since 1958, and in 1965 was 3 per cent higher than the previous
year. In 1965 this sector spent £1,410 million on fixed capital equipment,
including £385 million on building work and £940 million on plant and
machinery. The number of employees in manufacturing industry (including
the unemployed and those absent from work through sickness and other
causes, but excluding employers and the self-employed) was over 9 million
in June 1965, 38 per cent of the total number of employees.
The employment and production figures listed in Table 17 give an indication
of the relative importance of broad sectors of manufacturing industry.
Expansion has been particularly rapid in electronics, in the newer branches of
mechanical engineering, most branches of the chemical industry and man¬
made fibres. The diagram on p. 259 shows the changes in production between
1958 and 1965 in the major groups of industry.
In the subsequent sections, statistics of employees refer to numbers at
June 1965, and export statistics are taken mainly from the Overseas Trade
Accounts of the United Kingdom.
The metal manufacturing industries employ 637,000 persons. Of these,
364,000 were in the iron and steel industry, 124,000 in the manufacture of
iron castings, 60,000 in the manufacture of light metals, and 87,000 in the

Iron and Steel
copper, brass and other base metal industries. Exports of iron and steel
products and non-ferrous metals in 1965 had an aggregate value of ^402
million.
Britain pioneered the application of coal to the smelting of iron ore from the
seventeenth century onwards and British inventors were responsible for the
discovery of the processes which led to the great expansion of steelmaking
in the second half of the nineteenth century. Today Britain is the world’s
fifth largest steel producing nation. Output of crude steel in 1965 totalled
27 million ingot tons, the highest level ever recorded and 4'6 per cent more
than in 1964, the previous peak year. Capacity utilisation in 1965 was 87-5 per
cent, about the same as in 1964. Between 1961 and 1965 total capacity
increased by over 4 million tons. Pig iron production in 1965 amounted to
the record level of 17-5 million tons.
Net deliveries of finished steel amounted to 20-2 million tons in 1965.
The 4-1 million tons of iron and steel products which were exported had a
value of ^234-1 million; the United States (5631-5 million), Canada (5613-3
million) and Sweden (5612-6 million) were the main overseas buyers.
The main producing districts are: South Wales (25 per cent of total crude
steel output); the north-east of England (18 per cent); Sheffield and district
(12 per cent); Scotland (11 per cent); Lincolnshire (11 per cent), and
Lancashire (10 per cent). South Wales concentrates mainly on the manufacture
of flat products, especially sheet steel and tinplate; the output of the north¬
east coast and Scotland is predominantly of heavy steel products (plates,
sections and rails) although a wide strip mill for sheet production is now in
operation in Scotland; Sheffield is responsible for nearly two-thirds of
Britain’s alloy steel production.
During the period 1950-65 about 561,37° niillion was spent on major
development schemes. Capital expenditure reached a peak in the years
1960-62 of over 36170 million a year on average, due mainly to the strip mill
expansion programme, then fell to 365° rnifficm in 1965, but it is expected to
rise again. The emphasis is increasingly on improving efficiency rather than
raising total capacity. Britain has some of the most modern plant in Europe
and by 1965 steel produced by the converter processes had increased from
8 per cent of total output in i960 to over 23 per cent; steel from electric
furnaces had increased from 7 per cent to 13 per cent; and the share of the
older open hearth process had fallen from 85 per cent to under 64 per cent.
Output per blast furnace has risen markedly in recent years, due both to
an increase in average size and to improvements in efficiency, such as improved
preparation of raw materials, the injection of fuel and oxygen, and the use of
higher blast temperatures. Scientific and technological research is carried out
on a co-operative basis by the British Iron and Steel Research Association
and the industry as a whole now spends some 5612 million a year on research.
Outstanding development projects completed in the last few years include
wide strip mills at new integrated works at Newport (Monmouthshire) and
at an existing works in Scotland; a new plant at Stoke-on-Trent, which is
based entirely on continuous casting for supplies of semi-finished steel; an
advanced unit for the mass production of alloy and special carbon steels at
Sheffield; the world’s largest electric melting shop and a new steelworks in
which a linked three-computer system controls production planning through¬
out, both at Rotherham.
The iron and steel industry has been subject to some form of public
supervision since 1932. In February 1951 ^be greater part of the industry
INDUSTRY
Iron Castings
Non-Ferrous
Metals
287
came under public ownership, but the Iron and Steel Act 1953 established
an Iron and Steel Holding and Realisation Agency, with the duty of returning
the companies to private ownership. Only one company remains under the
control of the Agency.
In a White Paper, published in April 1965, proposals for bringing 13
major steel companies into public ownership were outlined. Their shares and
securities would be vested in a National Steel Corporation and the Iron and
Steel Board, set up under the 1953 Act to exercise a general supervision over
the iron and steel industry, would be dissolved. A Bill to restore public
ownership and control of the main part of the steel industry was introduced
to Parliament in July 1966.
Members of the Iron and Steel Board are appointed by the Government
and it is financed by levies which it has power to make on firms in the industry.
The major trade association in the iron and steel industry, excluding iron and
steel founding, is the British Iron and Steel Federation.
Output of iron castings maintained the record level of 4-1 million tons in
1965. The main users of iron castings are the general engineering industry,
manufacturers of pressure pipes and fittings, the motor vehicle industry, the
building and associated industries and the steel industry. The engineering
industry accounts for nearly one-third of the total tonnage sold and about
one-half of the industry’s turnover.
There are about 1,200 firms in the iron founding industry and the number
of employees is about 124,000. Exports are included in the total of steel
exports in the previous section.
The non-ferrous metals industry is the largest in Europe and as a consumer
of aluminium, copper and lead Britain is second only to the United States
among western countries. Output in 1965 included: aluminium, 36,000 tons
of virgin metal and 185,000 tons of secondary metal; refined copper, 101,000
tons of virgin copper and 151,000 tons of secondary metal; lead, 125,000 tons
of English refined metal; zinc, 105,000 tons of slab metal; and tin, 18,000 tons.
Mining in Britain is confined to the working of lead and tin ores on a small
scale, although detailed investigation is taking place into the possibilities of
a considerable expansion of tin mining.
In 1965 exports of non-ferrous base metals were valued at ^128-6 million.
The main products exported, including semi-finished products, were copper
and copper alloys (^57-3 million), nickel and its alloys (^24-4 million),
aluminium and its alloys (£20-4 million) and tin and its alloys (^12-9 million).
The Federal Republic of Germany (£19 million), Sweden (£9-1 million), the
Netherlands (^8-5 million), the United States (£8 million) and France
{Ll'9 million) were the largest purchasing countries. There were also sub¬
stantial exports of finished products incorporating non-ferrous semi-finished
products and non-ferrous metals in many finished forms.
Nearly half of the industry is situated in the Midlands; other centres
include South Wales, London, Tyneside and Avonmouth. Firms are engaged
in smelting, casting and fabrication by rolling, extrusion and drawing and
the techniques of powder metallurgy and pressure diecasting are also employed.
Some non-ferrous metals, such as nickel, molybdenum, tungsten and
vanadium, are largely used in the making of high speed and other special
steels. New uses for non-ferrous metals with special properties have emerged
with the growth of new industries having particular requirements, as, for
example, production of nuclear energy (uranium, zirconium), jet aircraft

Mechanical engineering comprises a wide range of industries, including all
types of machinery, machine tools, engineers’ small tools, mechanical handling
equipment, construction equipment, industrial plant, ordnance and small
arms, watches and clocks, and scientific instruments. Vehicle engines are
included in the section on vehicles (p. 294). The number of employees is
1-4 million and the volume of production from these industries rose by 42 per
cent between 1958 and 1965. In 1965 £2,063 million was the aggregate value
of the main products of all sections other than tractors, small arms, scientific
instruments and watches and clocks. Exports of non-electric machinery
were valued at £931 million in 1965.
There are over 300 firms, employing 39,000 people, in the agricultural
machinery industry, including three very large firms with more than 1,000
workers. In 1965 output, excluding tractors, was valued at £59‘4 million and
exports were worth £28-9 million; the main overseas markets were France, the
Irish Republic, the Federal Republic of Germany, the Netherlands and South
Africa. The number of self-propelled combine harvesters, forage harvesters,
pick-up balers and grain driers in use has increased in Britain in recent years.
Deliveries in 1965 included 5,200 combine harvesters, 4,700 milking machines,
16,700 pick-up balers and 2,400 grain and grass driers.
The bulk of British tractor output and exports consists of agricultural tractors.
Some 199,000 agricultural and industrial wheeled tractors were delivered in
I9^5> 156,000 (79 per cent) for export. In addition, 29,000 small market
garden tractors, were delivered. Exports of new agricultural and track-laying
tractors had a value of £92-1 million in 1965- Agricultural tractor production
is dominated by two large organisations. Tractors are exhibited at the annual
Royal Smithfield Show and Agricultural Machinery Exhibition in London;
Britain has one of the heaviest tractor densities in the world (see p. 320).
Britain was the birthplace of the modern machine tool industry, and by the
early 1830s had developed to an advanced stage the boring machine and
screw-cutting lathe, as well as other machine tools. The industry s output
today ranges from watchmakers’ lathes weighing a few pounds to machines
weighing hundreds of tons, including transfer lines for motor vehicle manu¬
facture and electronically controlled machine tools giving accuracies of one
ten-thousandth part of an inch.
The value of deliveries of metal-working machine tools rose by 16 per cent
in 1965 to £140-6 million (the highest ever recorded), compared with £122
million in 1964. Exports in 1965 had a value of £50'2 million; and of the
orders on hand at the end of December 1965 (£I04 million), 28 per cent were
for export. India (£6-7 million), Australia (£5’8 million) and South Africa
(£4-8 million) were the main overseas markets in 1965.
The trend in the industry is towards the formation of larger groups although
the high degree of specialisation makes it possible for the small firm to
flourish. The industry is centred mainly in the Midlands, Yorkshire and
Lancashire, and to a lesser extent near London and Glasgow. There are
95,000 persons employed.
The Machine Tool Trades Association of Great Britain is the representative
body of most manufacturers and importers, and is responsible for the
