Britain manufactures a wide range of industrial engines. Deliveries of engines
(including parts) had a value of £110-9 million in 1965 and exports (including
marine and rail traction engines) were worth £29-8 million; in addition,
parts exported were valued at £19-8 million. The total brake horse-power of
the 360,000 internal combustion engines delivered was n-2 million.
Production is concentrated among the large firms in the industry and a
total of 46,000 people are employed.
One of the oldest of Britain’s mechanical engineering industries, the textile
machinery industry, developed rapidly after the introduction of mechanical
spinning and weaving towards the end of the eighteenth century. Its range of
output embraces all stages in textile manufacturing processes. Deliveries in
1965 were valued at £104-2 million and exports (including products of some
associated industries) at £70-9 million. Principal markets were India (£7-1
million), the United States (£6 million), Pakistan (£5-7 million), the Federal
Republic of Germany and Australia.
The industry, which has about 59,000 employees, comprises over 600
firms and is situated mainly in Lancashire, Yorkshire, Northern Ireland,
Dundee, Leicester and Nottingham, makes a wide range of machines and
accessories for the manufacture and processing of yarns and fabrics from all
types of natural and man-made fibres. In the case of bast and leaf fibre
machinery the United Kingdom is still by far the world’s largest supplier.
Almost every industry makes use of mechanical handling equipment; the
products of the industry range from individual units and accessories to
complete operating systems. The value of deliveries in 1965 was £126-7
million (15 per cent more than in 1964), the main products being cranes and
bridge transporters, lifts, escalators, conveyors, elevators and hoists. In
addition, British firms produced 16,100 powered industrial trucks, including
11,800 fork-lift trucks. Exports of mechanical handling equipment (including
industrial and works trucks) in 1965 were valued at £33-3 million. There are
many small firms in the industry; in all, 58,000 people are employed.
Production of equipment extends to almost the whole range of plant required
by the construction industry, including crawler tractors, motor graders,
scrapers, trenchers, dozer equipment, dumpers, excavators and loading shovels,
and crushing, pulverising and screening plant. The labour force numbers
32,000.
The value of deliveries from the industry was £159-5 million in 1965;
by far the most important single item was earth-moving machinery with a
value of £93*9 million, while other important products were crawler tractors
(j£27’7 million), and concrete mixing machinery (£13-2 million). Deliveries
of contractors’ plant for export in 1965 totalled £75-8 million; Spain, France,
Sweden, Australia, the Federal Republic of Germany and South Africa are
important markets.
The office machinery industry has been expanding rapidly and is now second
in size only to that of the United States. In 1965 the value of deliveries of

The manufacture of engineers’ small tools and gauges is an expanding
industry; deliveries increased in value from £55 million in 1959 t° a peak of
£90 million in 1965; the main products were hard metal tipped tools (£14
million), other metal cutting tools (£40-4 million), jigs and fixtures (£17-1
million) and press tools, moulds, etc. (£12-4 million). Export deliveries in
1965 totalled £15-8 million. The industry has a labour force of 67,000 persons.
British industry manufactures almost every type of industrial plant and
steelwork, and i35>ooo are employed in this branch. Of particular importance
are steam-raising boilers, lime and cement kilns, gas and coke oven plant,
sintering plant, metallurgical furnaces and plant, chemical and mineral oil
refining plant, nuclear reactors, water and sewage treatment plant, and
steelwork for bridges, buildings, etc. The industry has several large-scale
enterprises. In 1965 the aggregate value of deliveries was £427-8 million,
one-fifth higher than in the previous year.
British companies delivered water tube boilers to the value of £86-4 million
in 1965 compared with £63-1 million in 1964? shUl boilers and other boiler-
house plant accounted for a further £3^*9 million. Water tube boilers of
advanced design and of large steam-raising capacity are produced for power
stations, whereas shell boilers are used for steam-raising and heating in
factories and buildings. Exports of vapour generating boilers in 1965 amounted
to £13-4 million.
The steelworks plant industry provides, in association with firms producing
rolling mills, almost all Britain’s requirements as well as plant for export.
The value of deliveries in 1965 was £31-9 million; rolling mills and ancillary
equipment accounted for an additional £25-3 million. Exports of steelworks
and non-ferrous machinery and similar equipment (including rolling mills)
were worth £14 million in 1965.
This industry consists of a small number of firms, most of which are
business associates or members of a consortium. Spain, India, South Africa
and Australia are a few of the countries in which British firms are undertaking
large-scale steelworks plant projects.
The manufacture of specialised equipment for the chemical and oil refining
industries has expanded rapidly in recent years. Deliveries of chemical plant
had a record value of £85-6 million in 1965 compared with £53*7 million in
1964. If the whole range of equipment manufactured by British firms for
the petroleum industry is aggregated, Britain ranks second to the United
States as a supplier. The range of chemical plant produced includes distillation
columns, heat exchangers, high vacuum drying equipment, and plant for the

Three major groups of firms, consisting of leading firms in the heavy electrical
engineering, civil engineering, boiler, instrument, and associated industries,
build nuclear power stations for the United Kingdom electricity authorities,
and have built stations in Italy and Japan. The Atomic Energy Authority
grants them non-exclusive manufacturing licences and is working in close
collaboration with them in research and development.
In addition to the mechanical engineering firms described in preceding
sections, there are about 1,750 enterprises whose principal product is a type of
machinery not so far mentioned. The main products include: mining
machinery, printing and book-binding machinery, refrigeration appliances,
space heating, ventilation and air conditioning equipment, pumps and pumping
machinery, industrial valves and cocks, compressors, scales and weighing
machinery, portable power tools, food preparing machinery and many other
types of equipment. The total value of deliveries in 1965 was some £677
million. There are 367,000 workers employed in these industries.
This industry makes a wide range of equipment and appliances, extending
from refrigerators of varying sizes suitable for domestic and commercial use
to industrial refrigeration equipment for cold stores, manufacture of chemicals
and other products, ice-making plant and refrigeration plant for ships.
Important advances have recently been made in the development of acceler¬
ated freeze-drying equipment for the food industry and of refrigerated
transport vehicles. In 1965 886,000 domestic refrigerators were delivered to
the home market and 188,000 were delivered for export. Total deliveries of
refrigerating machinery in 1965 had a value of £53-4 million.
The value of deliveries of space heating, ventilating and air-conditioning
equipment has been rising recently and in 1965 reached £71-5 million.
Exports of air-conditioning and non-domestic refrigerating equipment in 1965
had a value of £8-2 million. The number of houses equipped with central
heating in Britain has risen markedly since i960.
Industrial valves controlling the movement of liquids and gases are a vital
component in many industrial processes, particularly in the chemicals, oil
and electric power industries. A wide range of materials is used, including
plastics and many different metals. The value of deliveries of pumps and
valves in 1965 was ^122-8 million and that of air and gas compressors and
exhausters £41-9 million. Exports of pumps and centrifuges were valued at
£50-1 million and exports of industrial valves at £21-4 million.
The value of deliveries of other major products in 1965 was: mining machinery,
^53-8 million; food and drink machinery, £53-8 million; packaging machinery,
£27-7 million; and other machinery, £305-5 million. Important export
products in 1965 included: food and drink processing machinery, £18-5
million; cigarette-making machinery, £io-6 million; paper-making machinery,
£13-7 million; and printing and book-binding machinery, £5-1 million.
The industry manufactures photographic, scientific, surgical and industrial
instruments; it has a labour force of 139,000 persons. A rapidly expanding
sector is that making industrial process measuring and control instruments—
an essential element of automation in industry—deliveries of which amounted

The present industry is largely a post-war development. It employs about
15,000 people, the great majority skilled craftsmen, and many of its factories
are located on new industrial estates in the older industrial areas, particularly
in Scotland. Sales in 1965 included clocks to a value of ^7-5 million, watches
worth £5-2 million and time switches (£7-5 million); export sales were valued

Behind the firms manufacturing the major products outlined in this section
are nearly 4,000 enterprises, employing 244,000 people, whose main functions

roller bearings, and chains, are important products; exports 01 the former
were valued at j^ii-5 million in 1965) and exports of chains at £7‘2> million.
The electrical engineering industry is engaged in the manufacture and
installation of a wide variety of electrical equipment, including all types of
generating, transmission and distribution equipment; motors; telecommunica¬
tions apparatus; domestic appliances; and specialised laboratory and electronic
equipment. Output of the industry rose 46 per cent between 1958 and 1965.
Exports of electrical machinery, apparatus and appliances in 1965 were valued
at £331 million. Products are exported to all parts of the world; in 1965,
South Africa (^26-5 million), Australia (£24-3 million), the Netherlands
(£15-3 million), India (£14-2 million), and the Federal Republic of Germany
(_£ 14-2 million) were the main markets.
Altogether the industry employs a labour force of 898,000. The leading
organisation is the British Electrical and Allied IVIanufacturers Association
while scientific and technological research on behalf of the industry as a whole
is carried out by the Electrical Research Association.
British scientists and engineers have been responsible for many of the basic
advances in the generation and transmission of electric power. The experi¬
ments of Michael Faraday pointed the way to the production of electricity
as a source of cheap and abundant power; Sir Charles Parsons produced and

patented the first turbo-dynamo, the forerunner of the giant turbo-generating

expansion programme of the electricity authorities in Britain and has built
all types of equipment for overseas countries.
In 1965 the output of electrical machinery was valued at £425 million,
comprising £156-3 million worth of rotating electrical machinery (motors,
generators and rotary converters), £65-3 million worth of transformers for
lighting, heating and power, £173-4 million worth of switchgear and control
gear and £29-9 million worth of other electrical machinery.
Exports of electrical power machinery and switchgear in 1965 had a value
of £86-8 million; generators, motors, converters, transformers and rectifiers
accounted for £49-6 million and the main purchasers were South Africa
(£7'3 million) and Australia (£4-8 million). Switchgear, starting and control
gear accounted for £37-1 million.
Over 600 firms manufacture electrical machinery, including several with
over 7>5°0 employees. The total labour force numbers 234,000. Manufacture
takes place in many areas; among the most important are Manchester, Rugby,
Tyneside, Stafford and Larne (Northern Ireland).
Production of electronic equipment is one of the most rapidly expanding of
British industries. United Kingdom scientists and inventors have made many
basic contributions to electronics—the thermionic valve, the development of
radar (a British firm has fitted over half the world’s radar-equipped ocean¬
going ships), the first public transmission television service, and the ‘printed
circuit’, which has led to far-reaching changes in methods of production in
the radio industry. The industry employs 294,000 people.
The consumer goods sector of the industry is concerned with the manufacture
of radio and television sets and radiograms. The industry is dominated by
several large firms. Output of television sets in 1965 totalled 1-59 million
sets, while the total value of sales was £71 million, almost all of which was in
the home market. Sales of radios, together with radiograms, totalled 2-04
million in 1965 and were worth £22 million.
The total value of deliveries of electronic apparatus in 1965 was £265 million,
including £82 million for export. Indirect exports of equipment incorporated
in other products, such as ships, aircraft and machinery, are also considerable.
The largest sectors of the industry, by value of deliveries, in 1965 were radar
and navigational aid equipment (of which over one-third of the 1965 deliveries
°f £72-7 million was for export) and electronic control equipment (£56-3
million). Other important sectors include radio communications equipment
(£34-9 million in 1965), electronic computers (£34-7 million) and electronic
measuring and testing equipment (£26 million).
The industry produces cables and wires for the distribution of electric power,
for telegraph and telephone networks and for many other purposes; its products
include submarine cables and cables insulated by a great variety of materials.
It is supplying the high voltage cable to carry the rapidly expanding output
of electric power in Britain (see p. 272). The value of deliveries in 1965 was
£213-6 million, 16 per cent more than in 1964. Exports of electric cables,
wires, etc., were worth £30-8 million; the main purchasers were Hong Kong
and New Zealand.
The industry has a labour force of 65,000 persons and includes three firms
with over 5,000 employees.

Britain is the largest exporter of telegraph and telephone equipment. Ship¬

work is done by firms in the industry in co-operation with the Post Office;
in future all new small and medium-sized exchanges installed in Britain will
be electronic (see p. 369). The industry, employing 86,000 persons, is organised
for large-scale operations, and includes several very large firms.
Deliveries of other electrical goods in 1965 included: domestic electrical
appliances, £150-3 million; electrical equipment for motor vehicles, cycles
and aircraft, £86-8 million; batteries and accumulators, £58-5 million;
electric lamps, £31-2 million; and other electrical goods, £126-3 million. By
number, deliveries included: 1-4 million electric blankets, 1-7 million vacuum
cleaners, 0-9 million domestic washing machines and 2*3 million electric

(£4-5 million) and vacuum cleaners (£4-2 million); the main markets were the
Federal Republic of Germany (£2-8 million), Australia, France, South Africa
and the Irish Republic. Exports of batteries and accumulators in 1965 were
valued at £14-4 million. The industry has a labour force of 218,500.
The industries which manufacture vehicles and aircraft provide a significant
contribution to exports; exports of transport equipment in 1965 had a value of
£724 million, accounting for 15 per cent of total exports. The labour force
numbers 1,100,000 and includes: 498,500 in motor vehicle manufacture,
260,000 in aircraft construction and repairing, 224,000 in shipbudding and
marine engineering, 85*000 in the manufacture of locomotives and railway
wagons and carriages, 26,000 in cycle and motor cycle manufacturing, and
6,400 in the making of perambulators and hand trucks.
In both size and value the largest section of the vehicle industry comprises
the manufacture of cars and commercial vehicles. In the last few years
development schemes costing over £200 million have been completed and,
whereas the industry had previously been located mainly in the Midlands
and London areas, manufacturing and assembly plants are now in full
operation on Merseyside, in Wales and in Scotland.
Car and commercial vehicle output is dominated by the five largest firms
(British Motor Corporation, Ford, Rootes, Leyland Motor Corporation and
Vauxhall) who account for over 90 per cent of complete vehicle production;
the balance is in the hands of specialist producers of heavy commercial
vehicles, omnibuses, coaches, limousines and sports cars. The principal trade
association is the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT),
which holds a motor show annually in London and a Commercial Motor
Exhibition every two years. The Motor Industry Research Association
carries out collective research on vehicles and components.
Car output in 1965 at 1-72 million units was the second highest ever recorded.
Exports in 1965 amounted to 625,000 cars with a value of £250-5 million.
The United States (£40-6 million) was again the largest single purchaser;
South Africa (£16-3 million), New Zealand, Australia and Canada were the
other main markets.
Production of commercial vehicles, including chassis, increased from 146,000
in 1946 to 455,000 in 1965. Exports in 1965 of new commercial vehicles
numbered 166,000 with a record total value of £137 million. South Africa

Deliveries of bicycles have declined in recent years, the total in 1965
amounting to 1-7 million. About 75 per cent of British manufacturing capacity

Deliveries of all types of motor cycle were 108,000 in 1965, slightly less than
in previous years. The 1965 total of deliveries included 28,600 mopeds,

The British Railways Board has its own workshops which supply British

carriages and wagons for the British Railways Board, for industrial users
and for export.
Deliveries in 1965 included 154 electric locomotives, of which about half

(£2-6 million) were the largest purchasers.
Almost all the aircraft produced by the British industry today are based on
civil and military applications of the gas-turbine aero-engine, first developed
by Sir Frank Whittle. Turbo-prop aircraft in current production and operation
include the Argosy and Herald and the Hawker Siddeley 748. Two of a
second generation of jet airliners, the medium-haul Trident and the longer-
haul Vickers VC 10, entered airline service in 1964, followed in 1965 by a
third, the BAG One-Eleven, the world’s first jet transport designed to operate
economically on short-haul routes. Other civil aircraft in production include
the Skyvan light transport aircraft, the HS 125 executive jet, the Beagle
range of light aircraft, using piston and turbo-prop engines, and the Islander,
an economical feeder-line aircraft. The Concord, the world’s first supersonic
airliner, is being developed jointly by Britain and France; the first prototype
is expected to fly in the spring of 1968.
The industry produces a wide range of military aircraft. It is also engaged
on work on rockets, earth satellites and other aero-space requirements,
including the Blue Streak satellite launcher. Hovercraft, a new type of
transport vehicle invented in Britain, are being increasingly used throughout
the world; Britain continues to lead in their building and development. The

industry employs about 260,000 people but this number is likely to decline as
a result of reductions in orders for military aircraft.
Exports of aircraft and parts in 1965 had a value of £80-9 million, nearly
double the 1964 level. Leading buyers (who vary considerably from year to
year) included the United States (,£24-7 million), South Africa (j£i i'3 million),
the Irish Republic and Iraq. In addition, exports of instruments were worth
£3-3 million, and tyres ^i-2 million.
As a result of a series of mergers in 1959 and i960, the construction of
aircraft is dominated by two large airframe manufacturers and one helicopter
concern, though there are a few important smaller companies outside these
groups. Besides extensive research work by the industry, research on a
substantial scale on problems of aircraft and their engines is carried out by
the Government, chiefly at the Royal Aircraft Establishment and the
National Gas Turbine Establishment, both at Farnborough, and the Royal
Aircraft Establishment at Bedford. This work is done in collaboration with
the industry and results are made known to manufacturers. In addition, the
National Physical Laboratory undertakes research on aerodynamics.
The British aerospace industry has over 50 collaboration agreements with
overseas governments and companies.
Aero-engines provided some £670 million in export earnings from 1946 t°
1965. In 1965 exports of engines and parts totalled ^55-1 million; major
customers were the United States (£8-5 million), the Federal Republic of
Germany (^7‘i million), France and Canada. Twelve different British jet
engines power 33 types of aircraft currently in production overseas. Nearly
half of the world total of jet and turbo-prop airliners on order or in service
have British power plants. Famous engines in production include the
economical Dart and Tyne turbo-props, the Avon, Conway, Viper and Spey
turbo-jets and the revolutionary Pegasus lift-thrust engine for vertical take-off
and landing (VTOL) aircraft. The power plant for the Concord will be a
further development of the Olympus.
Two companies are responsible for almost all aero-engine production.
The building of large ocean-going vessels is concentrated in four main
areas: the river Clyde in Scotland, the north-east and north-west coasts of
England, and Belfast in Northern Ireland. Numerous yards along the coast
build fishing vessels, yachts, harbour craft and barges, and repair yards and
dry docks are situated in all the large ports. The shipbuilding, ship repairing
and marine engineering industries employ 224,000 workers.
Co-operative research into shipbuilding and marine engineering is under¬
taken by the British Ship Research Association with its headquarters in
London and a research station on the river Tyne. Pametrada, an association
of turbine manufacturers, carries out design and development work on marine
steam turbines.
The report of a government-appointed committee, published early in 1966,
recommended a number of steps for improving the competitive position of
the industry including a reorganisation of its structure.
A gradual fall in tonnage launched from the 1955 peak of 1-5 million tons
was halted in 1964, and 1965 showed a further small rise to 1,073,074 gross
tons. British launchings were the third largest in the world in 1965, accounting
for 9 per cent of the world total, compared with 10 per cent in 1964. Sixteen
oil tankers, totalling 421,000 gross tons, were launched in 1965, including
one of over 90,000 deadweight tons which was the largest ship launched in

Britain. Launchings also included bulk carriers totalling 312,000 gross tons

on hand of merchant vessels of 100 gross tons and over were 321, totalling
3 million gross tons and valued at ^343 million. Of these vessels, 89 of 1-3

Modernisation in British shipyards over the last few years has involved
the replanning of yards, the erection of large prefabrication shops for welding
massive sections under cover, the installation of heavy-lift travelling cranes,
and much other reconstruction.
Although there are many specialist ship-repairing establishments, most of
the largest shipbuilding firms also carry on repair work; about one-quarter
of ship-repairing activity is concentrated in the north-east coast of England
area.
Many of the larger shipbuilding yards maintain or have closely associated
engine building works, building various types of marine slow-speed diesel
engines, usually under licence. One firm also designs engines and there are
two independent builders of large marine diesels. Steam turbines of the
highest powers are also built, mainly to Pametrada design.
The group of industries manufacturing metal products not already described
consists of a large number of companies with a total labour force of 596,000
in 1965; the main groups were tools and implements (24,000 persons), cutlery
(14,000), bolts, nuts and screws (48,000), wire and wire manufactures (46,000),
cans and metal boxes (40,000), jewellery, plate, and refining of precious metals
(28,000), and other metal industries (396,000). The total value of exports in
1965 was about £156 million.
The production of cutlery and flatware is centred mainly in the city of
Sheffield and the industry’s reputation has been built up on the skill of its
craftsmen. Mass-production methods are, however, now extensively used
except in the case of some of the highest quality wares although firms remain
mainly small. The value of sales of cutlery and flatware in 1965 was ^16-2
million, including export sales of £4-1 million.
This industry, located mainly in the Midlands, Lancashire, Yorkshire, South
Wales and London, produces a wide range of domestic utensils, such as
saucepans, buckets and dustbins, mainly from aluminium and wrought steel.
The value of sales in 1965 was £23-7 million, of which £3-2 million were
sales for export.
The manufacture of hand tools is one of the oldest British industries covering
the manufacture of such tools as files, saws, hammers, axes and spades;
Sheffield, Birmingham and other Midland towns are the most important
centres. The value of sales of implements and tools, other than machine tools
and portable power tools, was £39-6 million in 1965, of which ^12-3 million
worth were exported; the totals included sales of hand tools, at home and for
export, valued at £35-5 million and £11-7 million respectively.
The making of jewellery, gold and silver ware and the refining of precious
metals is an industry in which British craftsmen are heirs to a long tradition.
Most of the firms in the industry are small. The law requires that gold and
silver plate shall not be sold until it has been hall-marked at one of the Assay
Offices situated in London, Birmingham, Sheffield and Edinburgh. The

BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Birmingham office, located in the main centre of the jewellery industry, is by
far the most important. The total value of sales of jewellery, goldsmiths’ and
silversmiths’ wares and electro-plated nickel silver wares in 1965 was j£26'5
million, of which £3-6 million was for export.
The chemicals industry, with a labour force of 468,000, comprises the
manufacture of: chemicals and dyes (225,000 employees), pharmaceutical
and toilet preparations (79,000 employees), explosives and fireworks (26,000
employees), paint and printing ink (48,000 employees), oils, fats, soap and
detergents (40,000 employees), synthetic resins and plastics (36,000 em¬
ployees) and polishes and gelatine (15,000 employees). The industry is capital
intensive: the fixed capital expenditure of the industry, excluding mineral
oil refining, amounted to some £1,000 million during the seven years 1958-65
and totalled £257 million in 1965. The value of exports in 1965 was £439
million, or 9-3 per cent of total British exports. Production in the chemicals
and allied industries rose by 58 per cent between 1958 and 1965.
Organic and
Inorganic
Chemicals and
Dyestuffs
The inorganic chemicals industry dates back to the middle of the nineteenth
century; over half of the output of this sector consists of a limited number
of relatively simple chemicals, such as sulphuric acid, caustic soda, chlorine
and ammonia, produced in very large quantities and serving as basic materials
for industry. Sulphuric acid has the largest production of any chemical and
3.3 million tons was produced in 1965. The remaining output of this sector
consists of a very wide range of chemicals of varying complexity. Almost all
inorganic chemicals are consumed in other manufacturing processes and
substantial quantities are used in the manufacture of such products as
fertilisers, detergents, paint, glass and metals. Exports are important; about
one-quarter of output is estimated to be exported directly.
Production of organic chemicals (which include coal-tar chemicals) rose
by 132 per cent between 1958 and 1965. To an increasing extent petroleum is
the raw material used and it is estimated that in 1965 petroleum-based
chemicals accounted for 7° Per cent of the total output of organic chemicals,
deliveries of feedstock for the petroleum chemical plants totalled 3-3 million
tons in 1965 compared with i-i million tons in 1959. The most important
products (by weight) in 1965 were ethylene (529,000 tons) and propylene
(254,000 tons). The main outlets for organic chemicals are plastics materials,
solvents, synthetic rubber, man-made fibres and detergents. Consumption of
dyestuffs is geared to demand by the textile industry; about 37,000 tons of
synthetic dyestuffs were produced in 1965.
Exports of chemical elements and compounds amounted to £106-7 rnillion
in 1965. Exports go to a large number of countries including, in 1965, the
Netherlands (£11-2 million), Australia (£6-6 million), the United States
(£6-4 million), France, South Africa, the USSR and Canada.
The first plastic, Parkesine (later called Celluloid), was produced and
patented in Britain in 1865 by Alexander Parkes; other British discoveries
include polyethylene. Manufacture of plastics is one of the most rapidly
growing sections of the economy. Output of synthetic resins has more than
doubled since 1958 and total production in 1965 was 943,000 tons (an increase
of 8 per cent over 1964), of which 630,000 tons consisted of thermoplastic
resins. .
Expansion in recent years has mainly been in thermoplastic materials, of
which the most important are polyethylene (used in coverings and packaging—

wide range of industrial purposes and consumer goods) and polystyrene
(a cheap non-inflammable material used for toys, light mouldings and many

a versatile material for use mainly in electrical components, mouldings, and

plastics materials is planned. Exports of plastics materials amounted to

The first general purpose synthetic rubber to be manufactured on a com¬
mercial scale in the United Kingdom was marketed in 1958. High styrene
rubbers for shoe soles and flooring, and nitrile rubbers for use where oil
resistance is required, are now in large-scale production, and neoprene rubber is
manufactured in Northern Ireland. Production in 1965 amounted to 172,000
tons, by far the greater part of which came from the styrene-butadiene plant
at Hythe, near Southampton. Exports of synthetic rubber and latex totalled
50,000 tons in 1965.
The development of artificial fertilisers owes much to the pioneer work of
the British scientists, Sir John Lawes and Sir Joseph Gilbert. Two firms
predominate in the production of fertilisers and there are about one hundred
firms marketing compound fertilisers from the principal constituents—
nitrogen, phosphorus and potassium. To encourage use, sales on the home
market are assisted by government subsidies paid to the farmer (see p. 323).
Output of nitrogenous fertilisers (in terms of nitrogen content) has been
increasing and in 1964-65 totalled 599,000 tons, while 443,000 tons (in terms
of phosphate content) of phosphatic fertilisers were produced; production
of compound fertilisers amounted to 2-8 million tons in 1964-65. The use of
ammonium nitrate (35 per cent nitrogen), ammonium phosphate, and, to a
limited extent, urea (mostly 45 per cent nitrogen) is resulting in more
concentrated fertilisers.
The value of exports of manufactured fertilisers, almost all nitrogenous,
was P-2 million in 1965, nearly a third higher than in 1964.
Sales of paint and varnish during 1965 amounted to over 91 million gallons
(including 12 million gallons of emulsion paint) valued at £136 million.
Britain is the largest exporter of paints in the world; exports of pigments,
paints, varnishes and related materials in 1965 amounted to £31 million. The
industry’s indirect contribution to exports in the form of surface coatings
for finished goods is also considerable.
In recent years many improved techniques have been introduced, in
particular the use of important new ranges of synthetic resins and pigments;
quick-drying paints and paints needing only one application have been
developed.
The whole range of drugs is produced in the United Kingdom, including
sulphonamides, anti-malarial drugs, anti-histamine products, anaesthetics,
vaccines, sera, and naturally occurring drugs. Over po million each year
is currently being spent on research.
Notable British contributions to the development of new products include:
the discovery of penicillin by Sir Alexander Fleming and its evaluation by Sir

In 1965 exports of medicinal and pharmaceutical products reached the

Notable discoveries by the British crop protection industry include the
insecticidal activity of BHC (benzene hexachloride), the first selective weed¬
killer, MCPA, and more recently Gramoxone, a non-residual general herbicide
based on paraquat. Sales of pesticides and allied products were valued at

and weedkillers in 1965 totalled ^10-3 million.
Sales of toilet preparations were valued at £91-4 million in 1965, including
export sales of j£I0'9 million; home market sales of hair preparations totalled
£25-4 million. Petroleum is the source of the principal raw material used in
the manufacture of organic surface-active agents in detergents; the other main
constituent, polyphosphates, is derived from inorganic sources. Sales of
synthetic detergents amounted to 350,000 tons in 1965. Production of soap

preparations were valued at £27'5 million in 1965.
The textile industries in 1965 had a labour force of 828,000 persons, including
51,000 employees engaged in the production of man-made fibres: 116,000
were employed in the spinning and doubling of cotton, flax and man-made
fibres, 107,000 in the weaving of cotton, linen and man-made fibres, 180,000
in the woollen and worsted trades, 134,000 in hosiery and knitted goods,
72,000 in textile finishing and 42,000 in carpets. Over half the employees are
women. The total value of textile exports in 1965 was £274 million, about the
same as in 1964. Production of textiles rose by 18 per cent between 1958 and
1965. Considerable reorganisation is taking place within the textile industry,
connected with the increasing use of man-made fibres, which has resulted in
several mergers and the formation of some large multi-fibre, multi-process
groups under the leadership of manufacturers of man-made fibres.
Cotton was Britain’s chief consumer goods industry and cotton piece-goods
its largest export during the nineteenth century. Increasing foreign competition
and the tendency of many countries to set up their own textile industry have
cut progressively into British markets and a global limit will be placed on
imports of cotton goods from low-cost countries during 1966-70.
Output in 1965 consisted of: 485 million lb. of single cotton yarn, 143 million
lb. of spun man-made fibre and mixture single yarn, 252 million lb. of
doubled yarn, 1,015 million linear yards of woven cotton cloth, and 625 million
linear yards of man-made fibre and mixture cloth. In 1965 exports of cotton
yarn and woven fabrics (excluding man-made fibres) amounted in value to

301
Wool
Man-made

^42 million, including woven fabrics worth £31-6 million, for which South
Africa, Australia, the Irish Republic and New Zealand were the most important
markets.
Most of the industry is located in Lancashire, the north-east of the county
being mainly concerned with weaving and the south-east with spinning.
Manchester is the commercial centre and Liverpool is the chief port of entry
for raw cotton.
Legislation to assist the reorganisation of the industry was introduced in
1959. Exchequer funds have paid for two-thirds of the cost of removing
surplus capacity, and also provided grants of about one-quarter towards the
cost of approved re-equipment and modernisation. The reorganisation schemes
were administered by the Cotton Board, a development council, that is a
statutory body with constitution and powers laid down under the authority of
an Act of Parliament. In 1964 the Cotton Board’s functions were extended
to cover the man-made fibre section of the industry.
Scientific and technical research for the industry is carried out by the
Cotton, Silk and Man-made Fibres Research Association.
The wool textile industry, the largest in the world, is the most ancient of
Britain’s staple industries and has been important since medieval times. There
are two main branches—woollen and worsted. While the West Riding of
Yorkshire is by far the most important producing area, Scotland and the West
of England remain famous as specialised producers of high quality woollen
cloth. In recent years an increasing amount of man-made fibre has been
blended with wool.
In 1965 output included 248 million lb. of wool and hair tops and 322
million lb. of woollen yarn. Production of worsted yarn amounted to 228
million lb. and of woven fabrics to 323 million square yards. In addition,
large quantities of raw wool are scoured and cleaned in Britain. Consumption
of raw wool in 1965 was 403 million lb., compared with 518 million lb. in 1959.
Exports of wool yarns and woven fabrics in 1965 were valued at .£88-6 million;
the United States, the Federal Republic of Germany and Canada were the
chief buyers. Raw wool (cleaned or scoured in Britain) and other animal hair
and tops exported had a value of £57-7 million. Research is carried on mainly
by the Wool Industries Research Association. The National Wool Textile
Export Corporation is responsible for assistance to exporters and the develop¬
ment of new markets.
The small or medium-sized business predominates in the industry and there
are only a few large firms. In recent years on the worsted side there has been a
tendency towards the formation of holding companies controlling a number
of subsidiaries which combine all the worsted processes within one organisa¬
tion. Firms on the woollen side are normally organised to include the full
process of manufacture from raw material to finished article.
Man-made fibres produced from cellulose were first made commercially
available in the United Kingdom in 1905, and much of the early development
of viscose rayon and acetate took place in Britain. Large quantities of chemicals
are consumed in their production, which is spread throughout the country;
Northern Ireland is of growing importance. Large firms predominate in the
industry. There has been a rapid expansion of output in recent years, the
1965 record total of 862 million lb. being 4 per cent higher than in 1964 and
37 per cent more than in 1962. Output consisted of 466 million lb. of staple
fibre and 396 million lb. of filament yarn in 1965. Of the staple fibre, 146

Hosiery and

Other Textiles

million lb., and of the continuous filament, 180 million lb., were of fully
synthetic materials.
Two main types of man-made fibres are manufactured in the United
Kingdom: those made from cellulose (such as rayon) and those produced by
fully synthetic processes from chemical substances (such as nylon). Viscose
rayon is still the most widely used of all man-made fibres and output in 1965
totalled 434 million lb. It can be modified to produce a wide range of
different fibres such as Vincel, a formidable competitor to cotton, and Evlan,
specifically developed for the carpet industry. The world’s largest rayon
staple factory is at Greenfield (North Wales), with an annual output of
200 million lb., while other large rayon plants are at Grimsby, Preston and
Wolverhampton. Almost all the rayon in Britain is produced by one company
and its subsidiaries. Triacetate (Tricel), a stronger form of acetate, was first
produced in Britain in 1955.
Production of nylon, the first fully synthetic fibre, in the form of nylon 66,
started in Britain in 1941; another type of nylon (nylon 6) has been manu¬
factured since 1963. Total productive capacity of nylon is planned to reach
about 390 million lb. a year by the end of 1967 compared with about 160
million lb. in 1964. Nylon is used extensively in the manufacture of clothing,
fabrics and stockings, and has many industrial uses.
Terylene, a polyester fibre, was invented in Britain during the second
world war. It is resistant to fading and is particularly suited to blending with
wool. Annual manufacturing capacity totals about 100 million lb. A group
of fibres of growing importance are the acrylic or polyacrylonitrile fibres:
Courtelle (a British discovery) and Acrilan are examples. Synthetic elastomerics
or spandex fibres, which are man-made textile fibres having inherent
properties of stretch and recovery, are now produced commercially. Polythene
(Courlene) and polypropylene (Ulstron) fibres have been developed mainly
for industrial uses.
Exports of man-made fibre yarns had a value of ^37‘2 million in 1965*
and woven fabrics £20-6 million. South Africa (^5’4 million), Sweden
(£5.3 million), the Federal Republic of Germany (£5 million) and Switzerland
were the most important purchasers.
The hosiery and knitwear industry is predominantly one of small scale
enterprises. The industry is widely distributed, with Scotland and the east
Midlands as the two most important centres. Sales of knitted goods were
valued at ^323-3 million in 1965 including £128-1 million worth of outerwear
and £75 million worth of socks and stockings. Exports of knitted clothing
and accessories were valued at £16-9 million in 19651 the largest buyers were
the United States, Canada, Switzerland and Sweden. Exports of knitted
fabrics amounted to £4-9 million. The Hosiery and Allied Trades Research
Association, with laboratories at Nottingham, undertakes collective research.
The linen industry is concentrated in Northern Ireland (the greatest linen
manufacturing region in the world), with most of the remainder in Scotland.
Broadly speaking, the Northern Ireland industry concentrates on yarns
and the lighter types of fabrics, while in Scotland production is largely of
coarse linens and canvas. Northern Ireland manufacturers produced 48 million
linear yards of cloth in 1965, while weavers in Great Britain delivered 27-5
million square yards, including 17-6 million square yards of sailcloth and
canvas. Exports in 1965 included £8-3 million worth of linen fabrics and
£3 million worth of flax yarns and linen thread.

Jute Jute is manufactured on a large scale in Dundee—the centre of the world’s
oldest jute industry—and 18,000 people are employed in all. Jute is used in
the manufacture of carpets, cordage, ropes and woven into fabrics for a wide
range of uses in the packaging of carpet, upholstery, building and motor car
industries. In 1965 127,000 tons of raw jute were used, and exports of jute
fabrics totalled £2-2 million.
Lace Sales of finished lace goods amounted to £21 million in 1965. The most
important lace product is from the warp knitting machines, with sales valued
at £10-8 million. Deliveries of lace products for export were worth £5-4
million in 1965.
Miscellaneous
Textile
Manufactures
In addition to the products mentioned specifically in this section, British
textile firms manufacture a wide range of other goods, including many special
yarns and fabrics, net, household textiles such as blankets, tablecloths and
curtains, and floor coverings other than carpets. Sales of narrow fabrics
(including elastic machinery belting and ribbon) totalled £43-3 million in
1965, including export sales of £6-2 million. Sales of floor coverings of
linoleum, vinyl and other synthetic materials were valued at ^39-2 million
in 1965; just over one-fifth were for export.
Carpets In 1965 total sales of all types of carpet and rugs amounted to 110-9 million
square yards, valued at £159-3 million. Exports in 1965 had a value of £12-2
million; Australia (£3-1 million) was the largest single market.
There are over 100 enterprises engaged in the manufacture of carpets,
including several large firms. In addition to the manufacture of woven carpets
such as Axminster and Wilton, over one-third of total sales by quantity in
1965 were of tufted carpets, a form of carpeting in which the pile, usually
containing a high proportion of artificial fibres, is inserted into a pre-woven
backing. Axminster-type carpets account for over 40 per cent of exports.
The principal manufacturing centres include Kidderminster (in Worcester¬
shire), Halifax and Dewsbury (in the West Riding of Yorkshire), Durham
(in north-east England), Glasgow and Kilmarnock (in Scotland) and several
towns in Northern Ireland. Just over a third of the carpets produced by
quantity are made predominantly of wool and a growing proportion of
traditional woven carpets contain some man-made fibre.
CLOTHING,
LEATHER AND
FOOTWEAR
There are about 624,000 employees in the clothing, leather and footwear
industries. Some 451,000 are in the clothing industry, 112,000 in the foot¬
wear trade and 64,000 in leather, leather goods and fur manufacture. The
aggregate value of their exports in 1965 was £95-3 million.
Clothing The British clothing industry is the largest in Europe and total production
of made-up clothing has increased by 34 per cent since 1958. Consumer’s
expenditure on clothing in 1965 totalled £1,700 million. Exports in 1965,
including knitted goods, were valued at £49-6 million, 13 per cent more than
in 1964, the United States (£9-5 million) was the main purchaser. Exports
of women’s outerwear rose particularly sharply in 1965. Substantial quantities
of clothing are also sent by parcel post.
Although there are some large firms employing mass-production methods
on an increasing scale, the typical firm is small. The principal manufacturing
centres are London, Leeds and Manchester, but several firms are also situated
on industrial trading estates throughout the country. Fashion is important in the
production of haute couture models and throughout the ready-to-wear industry.

BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Leather tanning is one of Britain’s oldest industries. In 1965, 15,800 tons of
sole and other heavy leather and 469 million square feet of upper, lining and
other light leathers were produced. Britain is the world’s leading exporter
in terms of quantity, with exports in 1965 valued at £22 million. The United
States is the largest single market (^4-5 million in 1965), followed by Canada
(£2-2 million), the Federal Republic of Germany, Sweden and Italy.
Tanneries are situated in most parts of Britain, but there are important
concentrations in Lancashire, Cheshire, Yorkshire, the north Midlands and
the London area. Many different types of leather are produced, ranging
from the heavy types for industrial uses, such as machinery belting and car
upholstery, to high quality leather for footwear, leather goods, gloves and
clothing. The British Leather Manufacturers’ Research Association is the
foremost of its type in the world.
The British footwear industry is the third largest in the world. In 1965
manufacturers’ sales of footwear totalled 198 million pairs. Exports of all
types had a value of £ 15 • 3 million; the United States (£ 3 • 5 million) and Canada
were the largest markets.
Factories are located throughout Britain. Some areas concentrate on
production of particular types; for example, the Rossendale Valley region
of Lancashire on slippers, and Leicester and Norwich on women’s and girls’
shoes. The Shoe and Allied Trades Research Association enjoys a world-wide
reputation in all matters connected with shoemaking.
The food, drink and tobacco industries employ 849,000 persons in the
production of a great variety of goods. The value of their combined exports
in 1965 was ^261 million. Exports of alcoholic and other beverages accounted
for ^123-2 million; sugar, sugar preparations and honey for £23-8 million;
cereal and cereal preparations for ^21-9 million; and coffee, cocoa, tea and
spices for £13-i million.
The average weekly household consumption of bread per head of population
in Great Britain, which has been falling, was about 2 lb. 9 oz. in 1965. In
England and Wales particularly, the small ‘family’ type of baker, producing
bread with some mechanical aids, is still found, but the trend towards
concentrating production in large mechanical bakeries has become more
pronounced; well over two-thirds of the bread is made in these bakeries, which
specialise in sliced and wrapped loaves; 4 groups have a dominant position.
In the smaller bakeries production of cake and other flour confectionery is
usually allied to bread production. There are 162,000 employees in the bread
and flour confectionery industry; a further 43,000 are employed in grain¬
milling.
There are 51,000 employees producing biscuits, and annual output has been
well over half a million tons in recent years. Weekly consumption of cakes
and biscuits per head in Britain was over 12-5 oz. in 1965. British biscuits have
gained a world-wide reputation, and despite the problem of import restrictions
in several overseas markets, exports in 1965 were valued at £7'5
The chocolate and sugar confectionery industry, which has 92,000 employees,
is composed of a small number of very large manufacturers and many medium¬
sized and small firms. The main ingredients used by the industry are sugar,
cocoa beans, glucose, milk, nuts and fats. Production of chocolate and
sugar confectionery was 652,000 tons in 1965. Consumption of chocolate and

sugar confectionery in the United Kingdom is far higher than in any other
country, being equivalent to about 7-5 oz. per head per week.
The value of exports in 1965 of cocoa preparations (including chocolate)
was j£io-8 million and of sugar confectionery, £10-2 million. Canada and the
United States were the main markets for cocoa preparations. Over 30 per cent
of total world exports of chocolate and sugar confectionery come from
Britain.
Among the fruit and vegetable products manufactured are jam, marmalade,
sauces and vinegar. The labour force numbers about 73,000. Output of jams
and marmalade, which fell from 329,000 tons in 1949 to about 215,000 tons
in 1956 has since remained little changed, totalling 203,000 tons in 1965.
Strawberry, raspberry and blackcurrant jams are the most popular. Exports
of jams and marmalade in 1965 were valued at ^i-8 million.
In 1965, 625,000 tons of canned vegetables were produced. The British
Navy was using canned foods in 1813, but rapid development in the industry
did not take place until after 1935. Beans in tomato sauce (237,000 tons)
and processed peas (182,000 tons) are the vegetables most in demand as canned
products. In addition, output in 1965 included 97,000 tons of canned and
bottled fruit, and 286,000 tons of canned soup. Apples are the most important
single fruit used for canning, followed by strawberries.
The quick freezing of foods has been increasing in Britain. Nearly 88,000
tons of vegetables and 1,000 tons of fruit were preserved by this method in
1965; peas accounted for over three-fifths of all quick-frozen vegetables.
Sales of dehydrated products, including accelerated freeze dried foods,
which retain their appearance, taste and smell indefinitely, are increasing
steadily.
The industry comprises the curing of bacon and ham, the canning and
preserving of meat and fish, the manufacture of sausages and pies and the
preparation of extracts and pastes. The labour force numbers 85,000. Output
in 1965 included 87,000 tons of canned meat and meat products and 233,000
tons of bacon and ham. There has been a rapid expansion of frozen fish output,
and some 50,000 tons were produced in 1965; small quantities (6,600 tons in
1965) are also canned. Exports of fish and fish preparations had a value of
£10-2 million in 1965 and those of meat and meat products were worth £10
million.
The industries which manufacture beer, spirits, wines, cider and soft drinks
have a labour force of 166,000. Exports were valued at £123-2 million in 1965,
15 per cent more than in 1964.
Exports of whisky (almost all of it Scotch whisky) reached the record level
of 39-7 million proof gallons with a value of £107-6 million in 1965; over half
went to the United States (£54-3 million or 20-5 million proof gallons).
Scotch whisky was first distilled in the fifteenth century. It is blended from
20 or more different types, some from malted barley and some from other
grains. Whisky requires several years to mature, and the 126-5 million proof
gallons (a record) of Scotch whisky produced in the 1965 distilling year will
not be on sale for some years. Stocks of whisky amount to about 450 million
proof gallons, representing nine years’ consumption, of which about one-third
has been in stock for more than three years. About four-fifths of annual sales
are to overseas buyers.

BRITAIN! AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Production of gin in Britain has risen steadily since the early 1950s. The
main distillers are in London and one company accounts for a large proportion
of total output. Although the larger manufacturers also own distilleries abroad,
exports (4-4 million proof gallons) had a value of ^7-9 million in 1965.
There are 90,000 employees in the brewing and malting industry. In recent
years there has been a strong tendency towards the creation of larger brewery
units, partly to secure wide distributive outlets for the products of the large
brewing groups, many of which market beer throughout the country. Bottled
and canned beer consumption, after increasing to nearly two-fifths of total
consumption, has since dropped to about one-third; draught beer, which
includes keg beer (about 8 per cent of total output), accounts for the remainder.
In 1965 29-6 million bulk barrels of beer were produced, the same as in 1964,
and consumers’ expenditure on beer amounted to ^837 million. Exports in
1965 of malt beer were 367,000 bulk barrels, worth ^3-1 million. Firms are
experimenting with new methods, including continuous brewing processes.
The main raw materials used in brewing are malt, hops and some sugar.
Malt is made almost entirely from home-grown barley. Some brewers make all
or part of their own malt, others purchase it from independent maltsters who
also supply distillers, vinegar brewers, and malt extract manufacturers.
British malt is used by brewers throughout the world, and exports in 1965
amounted to 39,000 tons, worth £1-9 million.
The soft drinks industry has expanded markedly in the last decade although
weather conditions can cause a marked drop in demand in some years. Output
in 1965 included 51 million gallons of concentrated liquid, and 240 million
gallons of unconcentrated drinks.
Though there has been some amalgamation in recent years, there are still
several hundred firms supplying regional markets. There are three very large
firms among the 20 or so producing widely advertised brands which are
marketed on a national scale. There is also some degree of specialisation by
firms in the production of various types, such as carbonated drinks, cola-based
drinks, squashes and cordials, tonic waters and ‘mixers’, and comminuted
drinks (in which the whole fruit is used). Sales of canned carbonated drinks
are increasing rapidly.
The tobacco industry manufactures almost all the cigarettes and other
tobacco goods sold in Britain. In 1965 consumers’ expenditure on these
goods amounted to -£1,429 million (of which about 70 per cent was tax revenue)
and, in addition, exports worth £20 million (of which cigarettes accounted for
88 per cent) were shipped to a large number of overseas markets; Kuwait,
Aden and Malaysia were the most important. The main centres of production
are in and around Bristol, Liverpool, London, Manchester, Newcastle,
Nottingham, Glasgow and Belfast. The two biggest manufacturing groups
account for a large proportion of total output. The industry has 48,000
employees.
The tobacco industry used 298 million lb. of unmanufactured tobacco
in 1965 (3-1 per cent less than in 1964), all of which was imported. In 1965
the main sources were the United States, Rhodesia, Canada and India. Total
consumption of tobacco in Britain in 1965 amounted to 255'1 million lb.,
including 220-7 million lb. consumed in cigarettes, 30-7 million lb. in pipe
tobacco and 2-9 million lb. in cigars. In 1965 112,000 million cigarettes were
consumed, 2,400 million fewer than in the previous year; 53 per cent of the
total were tipped compared with 16 per cent in i960.
INDUSTRY
BRICKS,
POTTERY, GLASS
AND CEMENT
Brickmaking
and Refractory
Goods
Pottery
Glass
307
This group comprises the manufacture of bricks, fireclay, refractory goods,
pottery, glass, cement, abrasives, asbestos and other building materials. The
industries have a combined labour force of 362,000, which includes 75,000
in the bricks, fireclay and refractory goods trades, 80,000 in the glass industry
and 66,000 in the pottery industry.
Firms in the industry manufacture such items as bricks, roofing tiles, chimney
pots, fireclay ware and heat-resisting products including furnace and kiln
linings. Brickmaking, one of Britain’s oldest industries, was introduced by
the Romans, and manufacturing methods vary from traditional hand fabri¬
cation to highly mechanised systems. In 1965 about 7,868 million building
bricks were produced in Great Britain, 41 per cent of which were of the
Fletton type, made mainly in the Bedford and Peterborough areas. Refractory
goods (firebricks, silica bricks, magnesite bricks and chrome-magnesite bricks)
are manufactured mainly for home use. Exports of refractory construction
materials in 1965 were worth £5-8 million.
The pottery industry is a long-established and complex industry, largely
located in the Stoke-on-Trent area of Staffordshire. Much of its raw material
is indigenous, such as china clay, ball clay and china stone from Devon
and Cornwall. It supplies nearly all home needs for domestic and industrial
pottery and its exports in 1965 exceeded £25 million. The United States,
Canada and Australia are important markets.
The largest section of the industry, about half, makes domestic pottery,
sub-divided into china, earthenware, stoneware, jet and Rockingham; the
other main divisions are glazed tiles, sanitary ware and electrical ware, and
such specialised industrial products as acid-proof stoneware, porous ceramics
and laboratory porcelain are also manufactured. Among famous makes of
British pottery are Wedgwood, Spode, Royal Worcester, Royal Doulton,
Minton, Coalport and Royal Crown Derby. Total sales of domestic pottery
were valued at £41-5 million in 1965, including export sales of £16-6
million.
The industry employs 66,000 people, of whom 35,000 are women. There
has been considerable re-equipment; gas or electrically fired kilns have
replaced almost all the coal-fired kilns and new decorating techniques and
automatic and semi-automatic machinery have been introduced.
Britain’s glass industry is the third largest in the world. The section of the
industry devoted to the manufacture of plate and sheet glass in their various
forms is organised for quantity production, much of it in the form of the
‘float’ glass process, which was developed in Britain. Its use for internal
decoration and as a finish for internal and external walls has greatly increased
in recent years. Large quantities of safety glass are produced for the motor
industry. Other products include glass bricks, tubular glass (produced on a
large scale), mirrors, lamp and bulb glass, scientific and medical glassware,
glass fibres, and all types of glass container (often made by fully automatic
machinery). A traditional product is hand-made lead crystal glassware of very
high quality, much of which is exported.
Direct exports of glass and glassware maintained the record value of £25-2
million in 1965. Those of glass were worth ^16-3 million, the most important
markets being Australia, Canada, the United States and South Africa. The
figures included £3-9 million of float glass.

PAPER, PRINTING
AND PUBLISHING

BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Collective research is undertaken by the British Glass Industry Research
Association, and much research work is also carried out by the Department
of Glass Technology of Sheffield University.
The cement industry of the United Kingdom is chiefly concerned with the
manufacture of Portland cement. Invented by Joseph Aspdin and patented
in 1824, this material and the methods of its production have been the subject
of continuous technical improvement and intensive research. The capacity
of the industry, which has 18,000 employees, has increased substantially
since the war to meet the growing demands of the building industry and
further expansion is planned. About one-third of production comes from
plants situated in the Dartford-Gravesend district of Kent. Annual output,
which reached 7-7 million tons in 1938, remained at the record level of
16-7 million tons in 1965. One group of companies is responsible for about
three-fifths of total output.
The paper, printing and publishing industries have a labour force of over
643,000 including 98,000 in the manufacture of paper and board, 70,000 in
the production of cardboard boxes and packing cases, 143,000 in the publishing
of newspapers and periodicals and 258,000 in other types of printing and
publishing.
The manufacture of paper in Great Britain was not firmly established until
1678, but records show that some paper was produced as far back as the year
1492. The British paper and board industry is the largest of its kind in Europe.
Total production in 1965 of all types of paper and board amounted to 4-6
million tons, the highest ever. Of this, newsprint accounted for 768,000 tons,
board for 1-3 million tons and other paper for the remainder. Exports of
paper, board and manufactured paper items were valued at £50-5 million
in 1965. A substantial proportion of the export trade is to sterling area
countries, mainly Australia, the Irish Republic and South Africa.
Wood pulp, almost all of which is imported, is the main raw material, but
large and increasing quantities of waste paper are also used and indigenous
timber resources are being developed.
There are a few very large groups in the industry and many medium-sized
and small firms. The large groups hold considerable interests abroad, including
pulp and paper producing mills in the United States, Canada and other parts
of the Commonwealth and Europe. Sales of household paper products,
including facial tissues, have risen sharply to an estimated value of nearly
£50 million in 1965. Sales of cardboard boxes and cartons were valued at
^103 million in 1965 while those of fibre board packing cases totalled £94
million. Wallpaper manufacturing is dominated by one firm; a recent
development has been the introduction of plastic and plastic-coated wall
coverings. Scientific and technological research is conducted by the Paper
and Board Industry Research Association.
The printing industry produces an immense range of goods from national
newspapers and periodicals to books, catalogues and greetings cards. The
industry includes many very small enterprises. Mergers in recent years have
led to the formation of large groups in the newspaper, magazine and book
publishing sections. Four large firms employ more than 7,500 persons.
General printing, publishing, engraving and bookbinding remains essentially
an industry of small firms.

Publishers’ turnover in 1965 amounted to ^104-9 million, of which export
sales accounted for million. Consumers’ expenditure on books, news¬
papers and magazines totalled £312 million in 1964. Popularity of paper-backed
books has increased rapidly in recent years and a third of production is sold
overseas. According to the overseas trade returns, exports of printed matter,
manuscripts and typescripts were valued at ^50-7 million in 1965 including
books (£25-4 million), and newspapers and periodicals (£8-7 million), but
these figures do not include parcel post shipments which are considerable,
possibly as large again as the recorded totals. The United States and Australia
are the most important overseas markets. The Book Development Council
was formed in 1965 to promote the supply and use of British books overseas.
Firms have introduced the latest developments in high-speed printing
equipment, including electronic engraving machines and advanced processes of
photographic reproduction, and are experimenting with typesetting by
computer.
Other manufacturing industries include the timber and furniture group, with
304,000 employees, rubber manufacture, with 135,000 employees, and a group
of miscellaneous manufactures which together embrace some 204,000 employ¬
ees, including 91,000 employees engaged in plastics moulding and fabricating.
Britain’s rubber manufacturing industry is the oldest in the world, dating
from 1819. Macintosh invented waterproof garments, and Dunlop in 1888
devised the pneumatic tyre. Tyres and tubes represent more than half the
total output of the industry but firms also make a great variety of other rubber
manufactures, the most important being rubber footwear, conveyor belting,
cables, hose, and latex foam products.
The British industry is one of the largest in the world. In 1965 its consump¬
tion of rubber totalled 398,000 tons, comprising 184,000 tons of natural
rubber, 180,000 tons of synthetic rubber and 34,000 tons of reclaimed rubber;
the proportion of synthetic rubber used is increasing. In 1965, 206,000 tons
of rubber were used in the production of tyres and tyre products. Tyre
manufacturers include several subsidiaries of United States and other
overseas companies. Tyres and tubes exported were valued at £25-9 million;
this figure excludes large indirect exports on vehicles. Direct exports of all
rubber manufactures (including tyres) in 1965 were worth £46-9 million,
with Australia, Sweden, Denmark and the Federal Republic of Germany as
the main markets.
London is the largest centre for furniture manufacturing, but High Wycombe,
in Buckinghamshire, is an important centre for domestic furniture.
Deliveries of domestic furniture, which have risen 25 per cent since 1958,
had a value of ^157 million in 1965 and exports of furniture were worth
£14-4 million. There are numerous enterprises manufacturing furniture in
Britain (including domestic, upholstered, office, school and other furniture)
with a total labour force of 104,000. The bedding industry employs 19,000
people; sales of new bedding in 1965 were valued at £32-2 million. Many
firms are small but in recent years there has been a tendency towards increased
concentration.
Scientific research and technical information services are provided by the
Furniture Development Council and the Furniture Industry Research
Association. The Council is concerned with the management problems of the
industry and produces an annual statistical and economic review.

The timber industry employs 103,000 people. Britain is mainly dependent
on imported supplies of timber (valued at £220 million in 1965) but sawmill
output of home grown timber totalled 22-9 million cubic feet in 1965* Other
products include plywood (44,100 cubic metres in 1965) and chipboard
(148,000 tons).
Toys, Games The number of people engaged in manufacturing toys and sports equipment
and Sports in Britain is 38,000. Sales of toys in 1965 were worth ^54-9 million and exports
Equipment had a value of £13-9 million. The Federal Republic of Germany, Australia
and the United States were the main overseas markets. The industry estimates
that current annual expenditure in Britain on toys amounts to about ^7 or £8
per child; current trends are towards increased production of small-scale
precision models of vehicles and equipment and greater use of plastics
materials; interest in construction kits is also growing.
The value of manufacturers’ sales of games was £4-1 million and that of
sports equipment £17-8 million, of which £6-2 million was for export.

AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES
AND FORESTRY
AGRICULTURE
Although Britain is a densely populated, industrialised country relying on
imports for half its food supply, agriculture remains one of its largest and
most important industries. It occupies about 800,000 people in Great Britain
or just over 3 per cent of those in civil employment, provides about 3 per
cent of the gross national product, and uses 46 million of the q? million acres
of land.
In Northern Ireland 27 million of the 3-3 million acres of land are in
agricultural use, and the corresponding proportion for employment and
gross output are 13 per cent and 15 per cent.
AND Land used for farming is conventionally divided into improved land suitable
for cultivation (crops and grass) and rough grazing, nearly all of which is
hill or mountain land with a native herbage of coarse grasses, rushes, bracken,
heather or scrub trees. Rough grazing has a low potential output—usually
assessed at about one-sixth of that of agricultural land—but is valuable for
sheep. In England and Wales only about one-sixth of farming land is classified
as rough grazing. In Northern Ireland the proportion is about one-quarter,
but in Scotland it is about three-quarters. In the United Kingdom as a whole
there are 307 million acres under crops and grass. Improved land and rough
grazing together represent 81 per cent of the land area. The rest is mountain
and forest, or put to urban and kindred uses. The area available for farming
is gradually decreasing to meet the needs of housing and industry; however,
the loss is more than outweighed by the increase in output from what remains.
The soils of the country are extremely varied. Many of those in the west
and north, overlying hard rocks, are poor and thin. The lowlands and river
valleys are usually fertile, varying in texture from clay to sandy loam, silt
and peat. Clay soils everywhere necessitate under-drainage, and as all are
constantly leached by rainwater, lime has to be applied at regular intervals.
In hill country the area of improved land is often small, but is usually supple¬
mented by grazing on a comparatively large area of hill land.
For many centuries the bulk of land in Britain lay in estates ranging in size
of from a few hundred acres upwards, comprising farms of varying sizes let to
tenants. Social changes of the past half-century have completely changed the
pattern of rural life in England and Scotland. Estate duties have been a
principal factor in the breaking up of estates. Most surviving estates are still
owned by private individuals or family trusts, but the Crown, local authorities,
and other corporate bodies hold considerable areas. Of the farms sold, many
have been bought by the tenants already in occupation. About half the farms
in Great Britain today are owner-occupied.
There are about 450,000 agricultural holdings in the United Kingdom,
giving an average size of about 100 acres. Slightly over half are part-time
holdings, the occupiers generally having another source of livelihood besides
L
312
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Types of
Farming
Tillage and
Grassland
farming. A recent survey has shown that there are about 220,000 full-time
holdings, and about half the industry’s total output comes from the 42,000
holdings classified as large ‘commercial’ farm businesses. A further 66,000
fell within the category of small ‘commercial’ businesses, which are able to
operate as viable enterprises. Of the remaining 112,000 full-time holdings,
farming is in general on too restricted a scale under present economic
conditions to provide a reasonable standard of living, and amalgamation into
larger units is being encouraged.
Taking full-time holdings only, the average size of holding in England and
Wales is between 135 and 140 acres of crops and grass. In Scotland the crops
and grass area of the 31,000 farms worked on a part- or spare-time basis
averages only 11 acres, but for the 27,000 full-time farms the average is
144 acres.
In Northern Ireland the land is divided into about 67,000 holdings,
practically all of which are occupied by the owner. About one-third of these
holdings are either very small or let in conacre (seasonal lettings for crops or
grazing), so that the number of effective farm businesses is about 43,000 of
which rather more than half can be said to provide a full-time occupation for
the owner. The typical farm size is between 40 and 70 acres of crops and
grass.
Most British farms produce a variety of products; the pattern varies from
farm to farm. In England the farms devoted primarily to arable crops for
sale are in the eastern part of the country, in East Anglia, Kent, Lincolnshire,
and the East Riding of Yorkshire. Potato and vegetable growing on a substantial
scale marks the farming of the Fens (south Lincolnshire and Cambridgeshire),
the alluvial areas around the rivers Thames and Humber and the peaty
lands in south Lancashire. Elsewhere, horticultural crops are widely dispersed
amongst agricultural crops. In Scotland the rich lowlands of the east coast,
the Lothians and a fringe of land around the Moray Firth are also primarily
arable.
Interspersed between these arable areas, and also in the Midlands, the
south-east of England and the north-east of Scotland, there are large tracts
where, although much of the land is kept under the plough, the rearing and
fattening of cattle is an important enterprise. In the south-west of Scotland
dairying is extensively practised, but most of the north west is devoted to
rearing sheep on rough hill land. The parts of England bordering the Pennine
hills and most of Wales are also sheep-rearing areas, though a good deal of
dairying, based on purchased feedingstuffs, is also done there. Dairy farming
is widely practised throughout much of the rest of Britain. In Northern
Ireland mixed farming is practised, the most important products being milk,
fat and store cattle, pigs and eggs, with sheep and stock raising in the hill
areas. Oats and barley are widely grown, mainly for livestock feeding, and the
only important cash crop is potatoes, both ware and seed.
There are three main categories of grassland in the United Kingdom
temporary grass, permanent grass and rough grazing. Temporary grass may
be part of an arable rotation, providing a break of from one to seven years
between tillage crops, or it may be part of an all-grass system where its
advantages over permanent grass are that it can provide early and late season
grazing and often heavier crops.
Since the end of the second world war there has been an increase of about
1 million acres in the area of temporary grass and the total arable area is

313
about 5! million acres more than it was pre-war. In England and Wales about
two-fifths of the 24 million acres of crops and grass (excluding nearly 5 million
acres of rough grazing) is under permanent grass, nearly one-third under
cereals and one-sixth under temporary grass. About three-quarters of all
agricultural land in Scotland is in rough grazing and of the 4-3 million acres
of crops and grass about one-fifth is in permanent and two-fifths in temporary
grass. Excluding about three-quarters of a million acres of rough grazing the
crops and grass area of Northern Ireland is about 2 million acres, of which
about half is under permanent and nearly one-third under temporary grass.
Farmers everywhere are exposed to the vagaries of the weather, of pests and
diseases, and of the market; but over the past 30 years much has been done
in Britain to mitigate these risks. In part this has been effected through the
advance of science, in part through self-help by farmers’ organisations,
but probably in greatest measure by government action. The role of the
Government as guarantor and provider of technical and advisory services, is
described on p. 320.
The steady expansion in productivity which has taken place over the last 25
years is summarised in Table 18. Total cattle and sheep stocks rose steadily
each year between 1953 and 1961, but over the next three years showed a
slight decline and are only now beginning again to increase. The milk-
producing herd reached its peak level in 1962, thereafter suffering a temporary
decline with some recovery in 1965. Numbers of sheep and lambs have
shown a fairly steady increase each year, while pigs and poultry have under¬
gone a considerable expansion over the past decade. Production of wheat has
doubled since the end of the second world war, while barley output at just
over 8 million tons a year is now four times the 1946 figure. There has been
a marked fall in the production of oats, and a smaller but significant drop in
potatoes, a crop whose yield is particularly prone to severe weather fluctuations.
Between 1955 and 1965 output of pigmeat and eggs both increased by about
half and this, together with the increase in beef and milk output, resulted in
higher consumption of feedingstuffs, mostly from home resources. Imports of
concentrated feeds have in fact fallen in recent years, from 6-i million tons
in 1960-61 to 5-7 million tons in 1965-66.
The index of agricultural net output (all holdings) at constant prices has
risen steadily. By 1953-54 if was about 56 per cent above the immediate
pre-war average. Using the average of 1954-55 to 1956-57=100 as basis, it
reached 112 in 1959-60, 125 in 1962-63 and 137 in 1964-65; 139 is forecast
for 1965-66.
Since 1939 population of the United Kingdom has increased by 6 million,
or about one-eighth. In spite of this growth Britain now produces about half
of its total food requirements or two-thirds of all that can be grown in
temperate climates; this latter figure comparing with about one-half before the
second world war. Home production of the principal foods is shown as a
percentage by weight of total supplies in Table 19.
Table 20 shows how the level of the main food supplies passing into
consumption has changed since before the second world war and within the
last decade. The main trends reflected in the table are that consumption of
bulky foods (carbohydrates), such as flour and potatoes, tends to decline,
while that of high-protein foods, such as meat and eggs, continues to increase
with greater availability and rising living standards.
