Britain’s official long-term liabilities have mostly arisen from the second world
war and its aftermath. At the end of 1964 about ^2,500 million was still out¬
standing, of which ^1,849 million was owed to other Governments, the greater
part to the United States and Canada.
The largest item among official external long-term claims is British
Government aid in the form of loans (see p. 413).
Overseas investors in Britain are allowed to repatriate the proceeds of the
sale of their direct investments, including any capital gains that may have
accrued, provided that the investment was made after 1st January 1950.
Earned profits and dividends can be transferred, irrespective of the amount;
transfers of this kind have never been restricted.
Overseas long-term investment in the private sector of the British economy
has increased substantially since the war. According to the Bank of England
estimates the market value of overseas portfolio holdings of British company
securities at the end of 1964 was of the order of £760 million. The book
value of net assets held in Britain (that is, overseas direct investment) by
companies incorporated abroad (except banks, oil and insurance companies)
was about ,£1,850 million, and the approximate book value of the net assets
of United States and European oil companies was some £750 million.
By far the largest proportion of private investment by overseas countries
in Britain is made by United States firms. It has been provisionally estimated1
that the total value of United States direct investments in Britain amounted to
$4.55° million (£1,625 million) at the end of 1964, compared with $847
million (£303 million) in 1951. Just under two-thirds of these investments
were in manufacturing and rather less than a quarter in petroleum; most of the
remainder were in trade and other enterprises.
Private
Investment:
Outgoing
Private investment abroad may take several forms: portfolio investment,
including the raising of loans on the London capital market; or direct invest¬
ment by the establishment of subsidiary companies, by the ploughing back of
profits earned overseas and participation, jointly with domestic capital, in
enterprises overseas.
Apart from the voluntary programme introduced early in 1966 aimed at
curtailing British investment in Australia, South Africa, New Zealand and
the Irish Republic, the United Kingdom imposes no restriction on investment
in the sterling area by United Kingdom residents and about 50 per cent of
Britain’s total supply of private long-term capital abroad and 60 per cent of
its direct investment goes to sterling area countries. Direct investment is
frequently made from a firm’s existing resources. However, borrowers outside
the United Kingdom must normally obtain the consent of the Treasury (which
is advised by the Capital Issues Committee) if the amount borrowed exceeds
£50,000 in any one year. Borrowing by Commonwealth and Colonial
Governments in the London capital market has fallen in recent years, but
averaged about £50 million a year in the 1950s. The market’s facilities have
been made available to the member governments of EFT A. Finance is also made
available by the Commonwealth Development Finance Company (see p. 389).
Investment outside the sterling area is subject to Exchange Control
regulations. Broadly speaking, direct investment is not permitted unless it
promises benefit to the United Kingdom balance of payments in the short-term.
1 United States Department of Commerce’s Survey of Current Business, September
1965.
412
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Britain’s private long-term capital assets abroad include portfolio invest¬
ments which, at the end of 1964, had a total estimated market value of some
^3,600 million.
In addition, there are direct British investments abroad. Bank of England
estimates indicate that their book value, relating to all companies except oil,
insurance and banking, was worth about ^4,100 million at the end of 1964.
The approximate book value of oil companies’ assets at the end of 1964 was
some ^1,300 million. The total value of the overseas interest of British
insurance companies is not known but again according to estimates, the value
of direct investments by these companies at the end of i960 in the United
States alone amounted to about 3^420 million. The British insurance industry
also operates extensively in other foreign countries and throughout the
Commonwealth. The annual survey by the Board of Trade estimated that the
flow of private direct investment abroad by United Kingdom companies
(excluding oil) was about ^272 million in 1965; in 1964, 58 per cent was
directed to the sterling area, some 16 per cent to North America and about
17 per cent to Western Europe. The figures include long-term and short-term
investment and reinvested profits.
Official
External
Assets
Owing to the increase in recent years in British Government aid to developing
countries, inter-governmental loans form the largest item among official
external long-term claims. The total of such loans outstanding at the end of
1964 was 3^515 million and included ^380 million in loans to governments of
overseas sterling area countries. New Government loans (less repayments)
totalled j£n8 million in 1963-64. Amounts owed by countries outside the
sterling area are mostly in respect of advances by the British Government in
the second world war. Other official lending, which amounted to ^149 million
at the end of 1964, includes investments of the Commonwealth Development
Corporation (see below) and the United Kingdom Atomic Energy Authority.
In addition, there are the official subscriptions to, and shareholdings in,
international financial organisations (see below) and the British Government’s
holdings of non-sterling securities. The Government also owns real estate
overseas, such as embassy buildings and military installations.
UNITED
KINGDOM
GOVERNMENT
AID FOR
DEVELOPMENT
Loans and grants to the less-developed countries for economic development,
technical assistance, budget support and emergency relief from the United
Kingdom since 1951 have amounted to ,£1,636 million and in the four years
1962-65 averaged ,£179 million a year (see Table 28). Since the end of the
1950s Britain’s aid programme, which initially was directed mainly to
dependent territories in the Commonwealth, has become world-wide in scope.
In 1965 its cost amounted to nearly ,£200 million. The department responsible
is the Ministry of Overseas Development (ODM, see p. 55).
This assistance takes two forms: financial aid (both grants and loans) and
technical assistance arranged directly with the country receiving help (bilateral
assistance); and contributions to international bodies (multilateral assistance).
In 1965 bilateral assistance totalled ,£ 177-1 million and multilateral assistance
was ,£18-6 million. Bilateral technical assistance accounted for j£3i-7 million,
being nearly twice as much as it was in 1961. The target figure for Britain’s
total expenditure on aid in the financial year 1966-67 is ,£225 million. Most
of Britain’s bilateral financial aid goes to Commonwealth countries.
The terms of aid have been progressively softened over the last few years.
A substantial amount has always been provided in the form of grants. Since
1958 the maturity period of development loans has lengthened from a norm

some cases this has reduced the effective rate of interest payable over the life

nine countries to a total value of over £70 million.
Until the formation of the Ministry of Overseas Development in 1964,
development loans to independent Commonwealth and foreign countries
were made mainly under the Export Guarantees Acts 1949-1964. New
development loans are now being made by the ODM which also administers

Loans under
Export
Guarantees
Acts
Loans under the Export Guarantees Acts are used for the purchase of goods,
equipment and services from Britain and are administered by the Export
Credits Guarantee Department. They usually have borne a rate of interest
equal to the British Government’s borrowing rate plus -25 per cent. (In 1965
this was reduced on new loans to -125 per cent.)
From 1949 to June 1966 agreements with a total value of over £446 million
had been made, of which all but eight had been made since mid-1958.
The total includes 30 loans to India amounting to ^240-5 million, 12 to
Pakistan to a value of ^64-1 million, seven to Yugoslavia totalling £24-6
million, eight to Turkey amounting to £16-9 million and six to Nigeria
4H
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Dependent
Territories
Technical
Assistance
Inter¬
governmental
Organisations
valued at £32-8 million. For the more recent loans, repayment periods are
up to 25 years. In most cases there is a grace period before repayments begin,
and in some a waiver of interest for up to the first seven years. During
1965 agreements to the value of £24-9 million were concluded. These loans
are a declining sector of the aid programme, as a greater proportion of loans
are being negotiated by the ODM, including all those on interest-free terms
and financed from departmental Votes.
The Commonwealth Development Corporation (CDC) (formerly the Colonial
Development Corporation), which is financed from Exchequer funds,
provides capital for development projects in Commonwealth countries. Up
to the end of 1965, the CDC had capital commitments totalling ^133 million,
of which two-thirds were in Africa.
The CDC is empowered to undertake schemes in British dependent
territories and in independent Commonwealth countries in which it operated
before independence.
The Colonial Development and Welfare Acts and the Commonwealth
Development Act are the principal machinery for providing assistance for
development in Britain’s dependent territories: £390 million in grants and
.£125 million in loans have been made available for the period 1946-70. By the
end of the 1965-66 financial year £85 million had been disbursed.
About one-fifth of Britain’s governmental aid contribution is directed to
technical co-operation efforts. Under the Colombo Plan for Co-operative
Economic Development in South and South-East Asia it provided nearly
£7 million in the three years to the end of 1965 for technical assistance, and
about 6,450 people have come to Britain for training under the plan since 1959.
(The United Kingdom’s total economic aid to the area from the beginning of
the Colombo Plan in 1951 to the end of December 1965 amounted to £336-4
million.)
Technical assistance is an important element in the Special Commonwealth
African Assistance Plan (SCAAP); the largest item in the estimated expendi¬
ture for 1965-66 of the ODM on grants and services connected with bilateral
overseas aid was £34 million to the SCAAP. British technical assistance
contributions include technical services, educational and training facilities in
Britain, the provision of specialist advisers, equipment and surveys. In
addition there are contributions for teachers sent to the region under the
Commonwealth Educational Co-operation Scheme. During the academic
year 1964-65 some 68,500 students and trainees from overseas were studying
in Britain, about 52,000 from developing countries. Under the Overseas
Service Aid Scheme overseas Governments can retain the services of trained
and experienced staff (numbering over 10,000 at the end of 1965) until they
can be replaced by local people.
Arrangements are also made for supplying technical assistance under the
Central Treaty Organisation and the South East Asia Treaty Organisation.
Britain’s subscription to the International Bank for Reconstruction and
Development (IBRD) and its two affiliated organisations, the International
Finance Corporation and the International Development Association (IDA)
is the second largest of any country. Britain’s contribution of £47 million to
IDA is being increased by a further £35 million over the three years 1965-67.
Britain’s contribution in 1966 to the United Nations Development Programme
amounted to £4-5 million.
TRADE AND PAYMENTS
415
WHOLESALE
TRADES
INTERNAL TRADE
The internal trade of the United Kingdom can be divided into two broad
categories: trade in raw materials, capital goods and intermediate products
(for example, vehicle components) and trade in consumer goods, involving
the network of distributive trades by which home produced or imported
goods reach the consumer. (The pattern of consumers’ expenditure is outlined
in Chapter 10, The National Economy.)
There have been a number of official statistical inquiries into the distributive
trades. Most recently, during 1963 and 1964, the results of a full Census
of Distribution for 1961 were published by the Board of Trade, covering the
retail and (related) service trades in Great Britain. This census was only the
second of its kind undertaken in Britain; the first, covering also the wholesale
trades, related to I950, A sample inquiry, however, was conducted by the
Board of Trade into the retail and service trades in 1957 and a full-scale
inquiry into the wholesale trade for 1959. Sample monthly and annual
inquiries are also undertaken, covering a few aspects of the distributive
trades; for instance, turnover, stocks and capital expenditure. The first
census of retail distribution and other services to be taken in Northern
Ireland relates to 1965.
Only a proportion of the trade in consumer goods passes through whole¬
salers . sales are also made to consumers through producers’ own selling
organisations (including their own retail outlets and mail order business);
and other sales are made directly by producers to retailers. Wholesale channels
are particularly in evidence in the distribution of textiles, agricultural produce
and foodstuffs. The inquiry made by the Board of Trade in respect of 1959
showed that out of a total of 19,000 business units engaged in wholesale
distribution in Great Britain, over 3,000 dealt in clothing, footwear and
textiles, 2,000 in grocery and provisions, 2,000 in vegetables and fruit, and
over 3,000 in other food and in drink. In addition, there were 8,000 dealers
(wholesale or retail) in coal, builders’ materials, grain or agricultural supplies,
and 7,000 dealers in other industrial materials and machinery. The value of
stocks held by wholesalers and dealers at the end of 1965 is estimated at £2,000
million; expenditure on capital assets during the year was about £165 million.
Methods of wholesale distribution vary according to the type of merchan¬
dise handled. Fish, for example, is auctioned at the ports to port wholesalers
(who sell to inland wholesalers at the main distribution centres) or, in some
cases, direct to retailers, but fruit and vegetables may be sold by growers to
commission agents (who dispose of the produce either to wholesalers or
direct to retailers) or the grower may deal only with wholesale firms. The sale
of some agricultural products is regulated by statutory marketing boards
(see p. 322).
London’s wholesale markets are of outstanding importance in the
distribution of foodstuffs, particularly imported supplies. Covent Garden
handles about i-2 million tons of fruit and vegetables each year; nearly
8,000 tons of meat pass through Smithfield market each week; Billingsgate
is the principal distributing centre in Britain for fish. Other markets in
London include those at Leadenhall (poultry) and Spitalfields (fruit and
vegetables).
The co-operative movement in Britain has established its own wholesale
societies, the two largest being the Co-operative Wholesale Society Ltd.
(CWS) and the Scottish Co-operative Wholesale Society Ltd. (SCWS) to serve
416

the needs of retail societies, membership being restricted to incorporated
co-operative organisations. The CWS had sales of ^488 million in 1964 and
the SCWS had sales of £92 million.
Two kinds of voluntary wholesale chains have developed in recent years
particularly in the food trades. Firstly, local retailers’ buying groups were
formed and later (since 1954) wholesaler-sponsored voluntary chains (groups of
independent traders linked to a wholesaler or a group of wholesalers). Both
kinds benefit from the lower operating costs of large-scale trading without
losing their independence and both are numerically of roughly equal impor¬
tance. The 1961 Census of Distribution showed that about 27 per cent (or
40 per cent in terms of turnover) of smaller grocers—mostly medium-sized
independents and small multiples with not more than nine branches—belonged
to these chains.
Retail businesses in Britain may be classified under three main headings:
(1) multiple traders, that is, organisations other than co-operative societies
with ten or more branches; (2) retail co-operative societies (see p. 417); and
(3) independent retail businesses, including for this purpose the small multiple
stores (that is, chains of stores with nine or fewer branches). Businesses in each
of these categories may own department stores. Other retail outlets include
gas and electricity showrooms owned by the area gas and electricity boards
and mail order businesses (see p. 420). Table 29 shows the number of estab¬
lishments and turnover for some of the main groups of retail business between
1957 and 1965.

A very wide range is covered in the size of retailing establishments. On
the one hand there were ten shops (nine of them department stores) with
sales in 1961 exceeding £$ million or having takings of more than £2,000 an
hour; at the other extreme there were more than 70,000 establishments taking
less than £2,000 in a year. Some of these are market and street traders, whose
volume of business may be very small.
The 1961 census showed that, in comparison with 1957, a larger volume of
trade had been handled by almost exactly the same number of shops and by
much the same number of people. A notable feature was the continued
expansion of the large multiple firms; these showed a further increase between
TRADE AND PAYMENTS
Multiples and
Large Establish¬
ments
Retail
Co-operative
Societies
Independent Shops
Department Stores
417
1961 and 1964 relative to other types of shops. Independent shops, however,
still account for half of Britain’s retail trade.
According to the Census of Distribution there were nearly 70,000 shops
owned by multiples (including multiple departmental stores) in 1961, having
a total turnover of £2,580 million. This form of organisation showed the
largest rise in numbers between 1957 and 1961 and their share in total sales
went up from 25 per cent to 29 per cent. In the food trades their turnover
increased by 42 per cent, compared with 11 per cent for independent retailers
and only 3 per cent for co-operative societies. Large traders of all kinds
(including co-operative societies) accounted for nearly 50 per cent of sales
in food shops as a whole and for 64 per cent of the sales of all clothing shops.
The number of co-operative stores increased slightly between 1957 and 1961
but their share in total retail trade dropped from 12 to n per cent. They
account for a fifth of the turnover of all grocers and a third of the turnover of
all dairymen.
The retail co-operative societies are voluntary non-profit-making organisations
engaged in retail trade and controlled by their members, who are also their
customers. Any operating surplus is returned periodically to members as a
dividend; the amount distributed is proportionate to the value of the member’s
purchases.
Retail co-operatives also sell to the general public, but membership is open
to anyone paying a small deposit on a minimum share, which entitles the
member to an equal voice with other members in determining the policy of
the society. Investment by individual members is limited to £1,000 (less in
some societies). Only a low rate of interest is paid on the shares.
At the end of 1965 there were 804 retail co-operative societies registered
under the Industrial and Provident Societies Act. Amalgamations are slowly
diminishing the number of societies (the total in 1958 was 1,015). By far the
largest single society in Britain is the London Co-operative Society with just
under 1-3 million members and a turnover of over £50 million a year. Total
sales of the retail co-operative societies in 1964 reached nearly £1,070 million
(this figure includes certain activities not covered by the Census of Distribution
figure in Table 29). The approximate average rate of dividend paid to members
in 1964 was 9d. in the £.
Smaller independent shops have been giving ground only slowly in the face
of increased competition from the larger undertakings. The proprietors of
many of the smaller shops often have other means of livelihood. Average
turnover per shop has continued to increase, though by less than for the retail
trade as a whole. None the less, allowing for a 4 per cent increase in prices,
the average small independent shop sold more goods in 1961 than in 1957!
There were nearly 800 department stores in Britain in 1961, having a turnover
of nearly £550 million—about 6 per cent of the total turnover of all retail
establishments. Department stores were defined for the purposes of the 1961
census as having 25 or more persons engaged in selling clothing and at least
four other major commodity groups. Women’s, girls’ and infants’ wear,
haberdashery and other drapery were the most important categories of goods
sold, accounting for over a third of turnover. A firm or a group of firms
frequently owns several department stores. Three groups of this kind owned
145 stores in 1961 and co-operative societies owned a further 210 stores. In
1961 there were 53 stores each with a turnover above £2 million, accounting
for nearly 40 per cent of the turnover in this kind of business.

Out of a total of over 580,000 establishments recorded by the 1961 Census
of Distribution, and shown in Table 30, grocery and other food retailing
groups numbered over 278,000 establishments, and the clothing and foot¬
wear group over 92,000.
Though the total value of retail trade in Great Britain (exclusive of elec¬
tricity and gas showrooms and mail order business) rose by 18 per cent between
1957 and 1961, rates of growth varied appreciably between different types of
trade. The slowest growth between 1957 and 1961 was in the food, drink and
tobacco sector and in clothing and footwear, and in the category including
booksellers and stationers; this trend seems to be continuing. The fastest
growth in specialised shops between 1957 and 1961 was in furniture, general
household goods (other than furniture) and chemists’ and photographic
goods, but the pace has apparently slackened since 1961. Gas and electricity
showrooms’ business has been buoyant since 1957* their combined turnover,
however, is relatively small, amounting in 1961 to slightly more than j£ioo
million.
The aggregate number of shops in Great Britain decreased slightly between
1957 and 1961. There were modest decreases in shops selling groceries,
clothing and footwear, and in the booksellers and stationers group, and a
noticeable fall in the number of confectioners, tobacconists and newsagents.
The highest proportionate increase was in the number of general household
goods shops.

In Northern Ireland, it is estimated that the value of retail sales increased
by 6 per cent in 1965, as they did in 1964, after rising 4 per cent in 1963.
Retail prices, which had previously been rising for some years until 1958, were
relatively stable in 1959 and i960, but again moved upwards between 1961
and 1965" The rise was relatively large in 1964 on account of higher import
prices and increased taxes.
The development of self-service in retail establishments since 1950 has
probably contributed to the notable expansion in sales achieved by the
multiple stores. According to the 1961 Census of Distribution, self-service
sales exceeded ^525 million, two and a half times the level of 1957, and the
average turnover in fully self-service grocery shops was over £,55,000
compared with £13,000 in other grocery shops. About 9,500 stores, of which
9,100 were grocers, were operated wholly or partly on self-service lines
towards the end of 1961, compared with 4,000 in 1957, less than 500 in
1950 and 10 in 1947. By the end of 1964 it is estimated that there were
probably over 16,000 and the number was growing at a rate exceeding 100 a
month.
Supermarkets may be defined as self-service shops with a minimum selling
area of 2,000 square feet and having three or more check-out points. There
were about 750 supermarkets in 1961, according to the Census of Distribution,
of which 506 were owned by multiples, 203 by co-operative societies and
40 to 50 independents. It has been estimated that by the end of 1965 about
2,200 had been opened.
New forms of automatic vending machines have come to the fore since
and an increasing number of coin-operated machines are being installed
in factories and commercial premises as well as in normal retail outlets. The
range of goods sold is widening; in addition to the traditional cigarettes,
sweets and stamps there are now machines selling hot and cold beverages |
prepared foodstuffs, stockings, paper-back books and other commodities
including coal and various solid fuels. Various estimates have been made of
the trade done through automatic machines; about 300,000 machines are in
use, and total sales may be of the order of £20 million to £25 million a
year. Traders who owned and operated automatic vending machines, but were
not otherwise engaged in retail trade, had sales of over £4 million in 1961.
Some 11,700 mobile shops1 were reported in the Census of Distribution for
1961, with sales amounting to £93 million. Nearly a quarter of this turnover
was concentrated in Scotland (where the density of population is lower than
in England) compared with a tenth of all retail sales. Co-operative societies
accounted for 39 per cent of sales through mobile food shops, against 17 per
cent in ordinary food shops. For the most part, mobile shops were concerned
with food sales; about 42 per cent were travelling grocers, and over 28 per
cent and 21 per cent respectively were greengrocers and butchers. Only a
very small proportion (about 6 per cent) were non-food shops, and these
specialised mainly in paraffin supplies and hardware.
Stamp trading—the practice of giving stamps in proportion to the value of
goods sold, which may be exchanged later for a ‘free gift’—has expanded
rapidly in recent years. There are, however, signs that the rate of growth is
levelling off. According to an unofficial estimate made in 1964 they are saved,
on average, by about 36 in every 100 women in Britain, with a possibly
1 Excluding roundsmen and vans selling ice-cream.

higher proportion in the London area, and are given by some 50,000 retail
outlets, the majority of which are food shops and petrol stations. The two
largest stamp companies in Britain claim about 90 per cent of the business,
the rest being shared among a number of small companies. Issuers of stamps
are required by law to mark them with their cash value and redeem them in
cash if so requested. Gifts distributed by the companies had a retail value of
about £8 million in 1965.
A facility which is being extended in Britain is the ‘credit card’. Users are
issued with a card on production of which their signature is accepted on
bills in participating shops, hotels and restaurants. The issuers then meet
the bills and recover from the card-holder through a single account presented
periodically. Normally users are required to pay a regular subscription as
well.
Mail order trading has been one of the most rapidly growing forms of selling
in Britain in recent years, especially in the north of England. Mail order
sales through all channels reached £276 million in 1961. The 1961 Census of
Distribution showed that the sales of specialist retail mail order businesses
had risen from £126 million in 1957 to £227 million in 1961, a rise of 80 per
cent; they showed a further increase of 65 per cent between 1961 and 1965.
Mail order sales in 1961 by large retailers amounted to £12 million, by
manufacturers to £34 million and by wholesalers to £4 million.
An inquiry conducted by the Board of Trade showed that sales by manu¬
facturers direct to the public totalled ^144 million in 1961, compared with
£70 million in 1950. Mail order sales accounted for 24 per cent of the former
total, sales to employees for 11 per cent, and charges for work done for 9 per
cent. Other direct sales, including sales by door-to-door salesmen, accounted
for the balance. Included in these sales were items as various as carpets,
washing machines, brushes, books and soft drinks.
Closely connected with the distributive trades are those trades which offer a
service directly to the public, notably the catering and hotel trades, laundries
and dry cleaners, the garage and motor repair trades, hairdressers and boot
and shoe repairers.
An inquiry undertaken by the Board of Trade relating to 1964 showed
that there were 151,000 establishments primarily concerned with catering
(defined to cover public houses, canteens, and fish and chip shops, as well as
licensed hotels and restaurants, etc.) with a total turnover in that year of
£2,036 million. Hotels and holiday camps (excluding boarding houses and
unlicensed hotels) had receipts of about £286 million, of which £124 million
was from residential accommodation. Nearly half the total turnover of the
catering trades was from the sale of alcoholic drinks.
There were about 1,400 commercial laundry businesses with an annual
turnover of about £67 million in 1961. Between 1961 and 1965 turnover
increased by 19 per cent. Dry cleaning firms in 1961 had a turnover of £40
million which increased by 23 per cent between 1961 and 1965.
An inquiry undertaken by the Board of Trade for 1962 showed that there were
nearly 47,000 businesses in the motor trades in Britain, with nearly 58,000
establishments. Their total turnover amounted to £2,962 million, including
transactions between traders amounting to roughly £6oo-£8oo million.
Traders classified as new vehicle dealers had nearly 14,700 establishments

Other

and accounted for two-thirds of the total turnover. Over 14,000 establishments
were classified as being primarily petrol stations, and 12,600 were also general
repairers.
Takings in hairdressing establishments increased very rapidly between 1950
(^3^ million) and 1961 (£97 million). They rose again between 1961 and 1965
by another 12 per cent. There are about 40,000 hairdressing establishments.
There are some 10,000 establishments specialising in boot and shoe repairs
(excluding repairs handled through footwear shops); they had takings of £25
million in 1961, representing a steady increase since 1950.
Other establishments found in shopping areas and offering a service to the
public include launderettes (over 1,000 businesses were running launderettes
in 1961), licensed betting offices (over 15,000 in 1964) and over 3,500 funeral
director businesses.
The annual expenditure of British industry on packaging was estimated in
I9^5 by the Institute of Packaging at over ^650 million. The expansion of
self-service shops, the growth of sales in the form of branded and standardised
products, and developments in partly prepared foods, for example, ready-
washed vegetables and ready-made cake mixes, have been major factors in
the great changes which have taken place in packaging methods. Paper
packaging, including cartons and boxes, remains the most extensively used
with a turnover of £275 million a year. New uses are being found for tinplate
(output, £110 million a year), especially in sales of soft drinks and beer.
Sales of glass containers reached a new peak in 1964 at 5,000 million units.
The turnover of plastic packaging has shown the greatest rate of growth,
rising from an insignificant level to over ^30 million a year in the last decade;
new uses include crates for milk, sachets for liquids and bottles for detergents'.
Aerosol dispensers, almost unknown ten years ago, were being produced at a
rate of over 128 million a year in 1965, compared with 28 million in 1959.
The rapid growth of sales of household and durable consumer goods, such
as cars, furniture, washing machines, television sets, refrigerators and cookers,
has been greatly helped by instalment purchase. Hire-purchase debt out¬
standing amounted to ^1,189 million at the end of April 1966.1 Of this, about
two-thirds was owed to finance companies and the remainder to durable goods
shops and department stores. There are a large number of hire-purchase
finance companies but a high proportion of the business is done by a small
number which operate on a national scale.
The Board of Trade has powers to regulate the terms of hire-purchase and
credit sales agreements in order to restrain the expansion of consumer credit.
The current terms are: a minimum deposit of 33J per cent on most durable
consumer goods except cars and motor cycles (40 per cent), mattresses and
furniture (20 per cent) and cookers and water-heaters (10 per cent). There is
usually a maximum repayment period of 24 months for most goods except
cookers and water-heaters (48 months).
Hire-purchase in Northern Ireland directly financed by the major finance
houses operating from offices in Northern Ireland amounted in 1965 to over
£i5 million and at the end of 1965 the hire-purchase debt owed to them
amounted to £15^ million.
1 Not included in this total is the debt of £171 million outstanding to certain other
instalment credit retailers.

BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Advertising
and Industrial
Information
Public Relations
About £590 million is estimated to have been spent on all forms of advertising
in 1965. About £281 million was expended on press advertising and £107
million (including tax) was spent on television advertising. The remainder
was divided between other media, such as posters, films, catalogues, window
displays, exhibitions, and free samples and gift schemes. Most of the advertis¬
ing is carried out by advertising agencies, which, in some cases, also provide
marketing, consumer research and other services; their representative
organisation is the Institute of Practitioners in Advertising. The trade associa¬
tion for the industry as a whole, including agencies, advertisers and owners of
advertising media, is the Advertising Association. It was responsible for the
setting up of the Advertising Standards Authority, an independent body whose
objective is the promotion and enforcement of the highest standards of
advertising, in particular through the British Code of Advertising Practice.
Industry and commerce have in recent years paid increasing attention to
improving public understanding of their work and objectives. Public relations
consultancy firms and the public relations departments of advertising agencies
provide general services, apart from the increasing employment by industrial
organisations and trade associations of staff specialists in public relations.
Their professional body, founded in 1948, is the Institute of Public Relations:
not only commerce and industry, but the professions, national associations,
central and local government are represented within the Institute.
Consumer
Protection
The Consumer
Council
Various legislative measures exist in the United Kingdom to protect the
consumer against specific abuses. Non-statutory organisations also exist to
further the consumer’s interest. Weights and measures legislation, one of
the earliest forms of consumer protection, was brought up to date and
extended in scope by the Weights and Measures Act 1963; it is strictly
enforced by qualified inspectors of local weights and measures authorities.
The Merchandise Marks Acts 1887-1953 are designed to ensure that the
marking of goods is both accurate and honest. The purity, hygiene and
description of food are controlled by the Food and Drugs Acts 1955, 1956
and 1958. The Consumer Protection Act 1961 gives the Home Office power
to make regulations to ensure the safety of any class of goods.
The Hire-Purchase Act 1965 and the Hire-Purchase (Scotland) Act 1965
provide safeguards to the consumer who buys goods on hire-purchase or
credit sale terms. The protection extends to agreements up to ,£2,000
although most of the safeguards do not apply to credit sale agreements for
less than ^30. Similar legislation has been in operation in Northern Ireland
since 1st July 1966. As a precaution against fraud, virtually every hire-
purchase agreement on a car is registered with H.P. Information Ltd., a
non-profit-making company whose members are car dealers or finance
companies concerned with car sales; dealers and finance houses can check
with it in confidence.
The British Standards Institution (see p. 261) has established a number of
standards for consumer goods, and the Council of Industrial Design (see
p. 218) helps to foster improvements in the design of consumer goods.
The Consumer Council, financed by a grant-in-aid from the Board of Trade,
was set up in 1963 to concern itself with and promote the consumer’s interests.
Within the limits of its finance and terms of reference it is fully independent
and so is free to criticise government departments and to bring pressure to
bear on other bodies. It is specifically debarred from engaging in comparative
testing of products, from law enforcement action and from taking up
TRADE AND PAYMENTS
Consumer
Associations
Resale Price
Maintenance
423
complaints on behalf of individual consumers. It works in close touch with
the Citizens’ Advice Bureaux (see p. 126).
Advice to its members on the merits of consumer goods is provided by the
Consumers Association (CA), a private body financed by the subscriptions of
members. It arranges tests and makes reports on the quality of goods bought
on the open market and its findings are published in its monthly bulletin
Which ?, issued to subscribers. The Research Institute for Consumer Affairs,
established with a grant from the CA, undertakes research into consumer
goods and services, and publishes reports. There are also a number of local
independent consumer groups, which in 1963 formed themselves into a
national Federation of Consumer Groups. Assistance with certain aspects
of consumer guidance is also given by a number of other private bodies and by
certain government departments. Individual trades and industries have also
taken measures to raise standards of quality.
The practice of resale price maintenance and its enforcement by the cutting
off of supplies was made unlawful under the Resale Prices Act 1964, though
exemptions may be granted on certain grounds by the Restrictive Practices
Court (see p. 262).

Early Trade

Formation of
Ministry of
Labour
Less than 200 years ago, government concern with all aspects of employment
was at a minimum. It was generally considered that it was not a function
of government to ‘interfere’ between employers and employed, and that the
unregulated pursuit of self-interest would of itself produce the best results
for both parties and for the community. The statutes passed in medieval
and Tudor times to regulate the level of wages and the training of craftsmen
were no longer applied, and it was a matter of principle that the new industrial
development based on the introduction of power-driven machinery and the
factory system should proceed without hindrance from any restriction on
the conditions under which workers were employed in the mills and mines.
Even associations of workmen seeking by joint action to improve their situation
were forbidden as a threat to civil peace and individual liberty.
State intervention came first in the sphere of safety, health and welfare. By
the end of the eighteenth century, a reaction had begun in favour of legislation
to protect the workers, especially little children, from excessive toil and
hardship, and the reformers became strong enough to secure the passage of
the first factory legislation in 1802. The first effective Factory Act was that
of 1833 which not only limited the hours of work for children but set up a
national system of inspection to enforce its provisions. Since that date,
legislation extending, strengthening, adapting and consolidating the statutory
protection for employees had been passed at an accelerating rate. (The record
of legislation providing for monetary recompense for industrial injury or
death is part of the history of social security.)
Trade unions ceased in 1824 to be ‘actionable conspiracies in restraint of
trade’, but their activities were still closely circumscribed and they had no
proper legal status, while their development met strong opposition. However,
during the nineteenth century new unions of skilled and semi-skilled workers
grew up, more soundly organised and more acceptable to the public because
their ambitions were more restricted. A number of employers’ associations,
mainly local, were formed during this time, unions and employers learned to
bargain together, and procedures for conciliation and arbitration began to
be agreed. Following the recommendations of a Royal Commission, legisla¬
tion was passed in the 1870s clarifying and regularising the legal status of
trade unions. Today it is customary for employers’ associations and trade
unions to be statutorily provided with representation on advisory committees
and administrative tribunals concerned with labour questions. For workers
in trades with weak organisation, which were unable to secure and enforce
minimum standards of remuneration, the Trade Boards Act 1909 introduced
for the first time in the modern era a state-sponsored machinery to determine
and enforce minimum rates of wages.
In the following year, 1910, the first employment exchanges were introduced.
This move represented the defeat of the concept that unemployed people
were so through unwillingness rather than inability to find work. The
LABOUR
425
employment exchanges provided a nation-wide service for putting employers
in touch with workers and vice versa. In 1917 the exchanges were transferred
to the newly created Ministry of Labour. (The factory inspectorate was
added to its responsibilities in 1940.) This department is today the principal
instrument of the government’s labour policies in Great Britain; in Northern
Ireland employment matters are among the responsibilities of the Ministry
of Health and Social Services. The range of services has extended to take in
special help to particular groups, such as disabled and young people, the
provision and promotion of training, measures to foster good industrial
relations and good personnel management practices, and the administration
or supervision of schemes to give financial benefits to the unemployed, the
migrant worker, the redundant and those in training.
The experience of mass unemployment between the two world wars led
to a new appreciation of the role the government could and should play in
securing for the people the opportunity to work; the first legislation in Great
Britain dealing with structural unemployment was passed in 1934 and provided
inducements to industry to settle in areas of heavy unemployment; in 1944,
in Employment Policy, one of the policy statements issued about reconstruction
after the return of peace, the government committed itself to the aim of
maintaining full employment. Since then, governments in Britain have
accepted an even wider responsibility for securing, without interference
with individual liberty and freedom of choice, an adequate supply of manpower,
in the right numbers, with the right skills, in the right places, as part of its
total concern, in association and consultation with the representatives of
employers and employees, for the development of the whole economy,
nationally and regionally, through the best use of all resources natural and
human.
Growth in
Working
Population
MANPOWER
The total working population of Great Britain at the middle of June 1965
was about 25 million, some 48 per cent of the total population, and included
about 73 Per cent of persons of normal working age (15 years to 59 years for
women, 15 to 64 years for men). About 93 per cent of the men of working
age are today in or seeking gainful work. The remaining 7 per cent consist
mainly of those continuing their education, of the severely disabled and of
some persons of private means. The proportion of women of working age
in or seeking gainful work is much lower, about 50 per cent, as many
housewives either do not wish or cannot manage to take employment outside
the home. Besides those of normal working age, there are probably over a
million older men and women still at work. The great majority of the working
population work for a wage or salary, but 1-7 million are employers or self-
employed.
Northern Ireland, which has 27 per cent of the total population of the
United Kingdom, has 2-2 per cent of its working population. The ratio of
working to total population in Northern Ireland is about 40 per cent, and
farmers and small-holders working their own holdings account for about
one-tenth of the working population.
The rate of increase in the working population has been slackening in recent
years. The reasons include the tendency of more young people to spend
longer in full-time education, and the higher proportion of women who are
marrying, which increases the number who leave employment even if they

of the women at work are married.
The growth of the working population in Great Britain over the last decade
is shown in Table 31. The raising of the minimum school-leaving age from
15 to 16 in 1970-71 is expected to cause a drop in the working population
in 1971-72. Among the requirements of the National Plan (see p. 242) is an
increase in manpower of 800,000 over the period 1964-70. The working
population is not expected to increase by as much as this during the period
even though successful development policies in the less-prosperous regions
will result in larger increases than might otherwise be expected. The ‘gap’
between demand and supply will have to be met by better deployment of
manpower and improved productivity. Married women form the only
substantial reserve and the Government is studying what are the obstacles
to employing those who are willing to work and how these may be overcome.

The present industrial distribution of employees in employment is shown in
Table 32. About 41 per cent of those in civil employment are employed
in the mining and manufacturing industries and only about 2 per cent in

Most industries employ women as well as men though not always for the

underground work in coal mines. The industrial groups in which women are
chiefly employed are: the metal-using industries; the manufacture of textiles
and clothing; the food, drink and tobacco industries; the distributive trades;
and professional and miscellaneous services.

BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The general unemployment rate in Britain as a whole has been among the
lowest in the world in the last 20 years—usually between 1 and 2 per cent.
It has been particularly low in the south-east and Midlands of England, and
consistently higher in those parts of the country which have the greatest
dependence on shipbuilding, coalmining, and certain branches of the heavy
engineering and metal manufacturing industries, notably parts of Scotland
and Wales, and north-east England and Merseyside. These areas have been
the subject of a series of measures of selective assistance to stimulate industrial
expansion; and more recently, counter measures have been taken to limit
expansion in areas of manpower shortage (see p. 255). The general unemploy¬
ment rate in Great Britain at June 1966 was 11 per cent; the area with the
highest rate was Scotland (2-4 per cent).
The total working population of Northern Ireland—including employers and
self-employed but excluding certain unpaid helpers—was about 586,000 in
June 1965 (392,000 males and 194,000 females). The number of insured
employees was about 503,000. The largest productive industries are agricul¬
ture, engineering, textiles and clothing. Most of the agricultural work in
Northern Ireland is done without hired help.
The unemployment rate in Northern Ireland has remained higher than in
other parts of the United Kingdom. In June 1966 it was 6-i per cent of the
insured employees. The Ministry of Commerce of the Northern Ireland
Government has wide powers (similar to those in Great Britain) to assist the
development and diversification of industry. It is using these powers
vigorously in an attempt to improve the situation.
GOVERNMENT EMPLOYMENT AND TRAINING SERVICES
The main Government employment services are provided in Great Britain
through the Ministry of Labour’s country-wide network of some 1,000
offices, which act as employment exchanges. The services in Northern
Ireland are run on similar lines by the Ministry of Health and Social Services
but there are some variations related to the much smaller area of administra¬
tion and the higher rate of unemployment.
The primary function of the employment exchanges is to introduce, free of
charge and without obligation, suitable persons seeking employment to
employers requiring employees, thus providing an efficient service to employers
and job-seekers and meeting the needs of the national economy. Employers
and employees alike remain free to use general or specialised fee-charging
private employment agencies and direct recruitment by advertisement or
personal introduction. The employment exchanges accept on their registers
both those seeking employment (full or part time) and those in work who
desire a change, and every exchange receives particulars of posts vacant and
applicants available in other areas. Local employment committees, on which
employers, workers and other local interests are represented, are attached to
certain employment exchanges as advisory bodies to secure the full benefit of
local knowledge and the close co-operation of employers and workers.
The employment exchanges offer a selective service to certain groups of
employers and employees through specialised registers. All exchanges hold
a Commercial Register of situations vacant and wanted in the distributive
trades, clerical and typing posts and catering and other services. Nearly
LABOUR
Youth
Employment
Service
Disablement
Resettlement
Service
Vocational
Guidance
429
40 of the larger exchanges hold a Professional and Executive Register concerned
with posts in the professions, management, science, business and technical
employment at home and overseas. There are nearly 30 offices, in places
where there are large groups of hospitals, which have officers specially
trained to deal with the employment problems of nurses, midwives and those
in related occupations. Elsewhere nurses and their employers are dealt with
at the local employment exchange. In view of the increasing number of
older persons in the population, employment exchanges have instructions to
make special efforts to find them employment and to encourage employers
to consider older workers on their merits.
The Ministry of Labour has also started an experimental Occupational
Guidance Service for adults. Specially trained officers at 11 of the largest
employment exchanges give guidance and advice to those in doubt about their
future employment. Vocational guidance services for young people in
co-operation with local authorities (see below) and for the disabled as part of
the Disablement Resettlement Service (see below) are well established as is
the selection of candidates for the government vocational training scheme
(see p. 432). Employment exchanges holding the Professional and Executive
Register are also ready to give information about the professions and allied
occupations to young men and women considering a career and to older
people seeking a new one, such as ex-regular officers in the armed forces.
The Youth Employment Service in Great Britain is the responsibility of
the Minister of Labour, under the general direction of the Central Youth
Employment Executive (composed of senior officers of the Ministry of
Labour and the education departments) appointed by him. It is operated in
most areas through Youth Employment Officers established by local education
authorities in accordance with schemes approved by the Minister of Labour.
In the remainder it is operated by the Ministry’s local offices.
The main functions of the service are to collect and disseminate information
on careers, give vocational guidance, find suitable employment and keep
contact with young workers to help them settle down; a further function is
to help employers to fill vacancies for young people. Local youth employment
committees, made up of teachers, employers, workers and other appropriate
interests, assist the service in an advisory capacity.
In Northern Ireland the functions of the Youth Employment Service are
similar to those in Great Britain but its organisation is different in that
Parliamentary responsibility rests with the Minister of Education and the
service is operated by a statutory board composed of representatives of local
education authorities and other educational and industrial interests. Of the
board’s expenditure, 80 per cent is met by the Ministry of Education and
20 per cent by local education authorities.
The Disablement Resettlement Service is designed to help disabled persons
to get and keep suitable work. It is available to anyone over school-leaving
age who is substantially handicapped as a result of injury, disease or congenital
deformity in obtaining or keeping employment. The Ministry of Labour is
responsible for the administration of the Service and is assisted by the
National Advisory Council on the Employment of the Disabled.
The help given falls under five main headings:
Vocational guidance is given at local offices by specialised disablement
resettlement officers (DROs) in consultation, as necessary, with the local
disablement advisory committees, hospital resettlement clinics and medical

Placing in Ordinary
Employment
Industrial
Rehabilitation
Vocational

Sheltered
Employment
interviewing committees, and also in the industrial rehabilitation units (see
below).
Having regard to a disabled person’s qualifications and aptitude and to medical
guidance, and concentrating on what the person can do rather than on what
he or she cannot do, the DRO endeavours to find the work most suited to
each, with or without an intervening period of industrial rehabilitation or
vocational training. A Register of Disabled Persons is maintained, and in
mid-April 1965 the number registered was nearly 659,000; registration is
voluntary. All employers of 20 or more persons are required to employ a
quota (at present 3 per cent for all industries, except shipping, in respect
of the manning of ships) of registered disabled persons. The number
of registered disabled persons unemployed in mid-April 1966 was over
45,oo°.
There are 30 Blind Persons Resettlement Officers (BPROs) attached to
offices of the Ministry of Labour whose particular responsibility is to place
blind persons in suitable work and assist them to settle or become resettled
in the working community.
Industrial rehabilitation1 is provided at 17 units run by the Ministry of
Labour. The aim of these units is to provide the final link between sickness
and employment by enabling men and women to adjust themselves gradually
to normal working conditions and to give vocational guidance based on
skilled assessment of their aptitudes. Attendance at the unit is voluntary and
maintenance allowances are paid. The staff includes a doctor, industrial
psychologist, social worker, DRO, remedial gymnast and industrially
experienced workshop supervisors, under the general leadership of a rehabili¬
tation officer.
The Ministry gives financial assistance to two centres conducted by
voluntary organisations which provide similar facilities for the blind. It has
also approved, on an experimental basis, two schemes by voluntary organisa¬
tions for the rehabilitation of patients from mental hospitals.
There are vocational training facilities for the disabled at Government Training
Centres (see p. 432), educational institutions and employers’ establishments.
For the more seriously disabled there are special residential training colleges
run by voluntary organisations with the financial assistance and technical
help of the Ministry of Labour. There are also arrangements for the training
of special categories of disabled persons such as the blind, and for providing
grants to disabled persons who are of the appropriate educational standard
to undertake study or training for professional or comparable employment.
Remploy Ltd., a non-profit-making public company with no share capital,
provides sheltered employment for registered severely disabled people who
are unlikely to obtain work except under special conditions. At the end of
1965 it employed nearly 7,000 severely disabled men and women in 87
factories. Some 150 home workers were supplied with work from six centres.
The directors are appointed by the Minister of Labour; funds for capital
development and to meet operational costs are provided by loans and grants
from public funds.
The Ministry also gives financial assistance to local authorities and voluntary
organisations towards the cost of providing facilities for sheltered employment
for 2,000 severely disabled sighted workers and for 3>70° blind workers.
1 For an account of medical rehabilitation of the disabled, see p. 140.
LABOUR
Mobility of

Commonwealth

Employment of

other than

Industrial

431
As part of the policy of encouraging geographical mobility of labour within
Britain to balance resources and demands, the Ministry of Labour makes
grants and allowances to help with costs of fares, temporary lodging and
acquisition of and removal to the new home, in specified instances. They are
available to unemployed workers moving to new employment, and therefore
settling, in another area, to key workers transferred by a firm into a develop¬
ment area to inaugurate a new plant, and unemployed workers recruited to
new plants in development areas and sent to the parent works for preliminary
training.
Commonwealth citizens from overseas are subject to control under the Com¬
monwealth Immigrants Act 1962, which came into force on 1st July 1962
and applies, broadly, to all Commonwealth citizens1 (except for those who
were born in the United Kingdom or hold passports issued by the United
Kingdom Government). If they wish to come to Britain for full-time employ¬
ment, they must first obtain a voucher issued by the Ministry of Labour.
Vouchers are issued to Commonwealth citizens (subject to a numerical
limit laid down from time to time by the Government) on the application of
an employer who has a vacancy for a particular individual, or on their own
application if they have certain special qualifications or skills. (Commonwealth
citizens who wish to work in Northern Ireland, and who are not ‘Northern
Ireland workers’,2 need special Northern Ireland employment permits,
which are issued only in respect of definite jobs.)
Individual foreigners are admitted to the United Kingdom to take up
employment with a particular employer, provided they hold a permit issued to
the prospective employer by the Ministry of Labour (the Ministry of Health
and Social Services for Northern Ireland if the proposed employment is in
Northern Ireland): about 66,000 such permits were granted in 1965. Of these,
about 14,000 were for domestic workers in hospitals, schools, other institutions
and private households, and about 9,000 for student employees. Employment
is limited to a maximum of one year in the first instance but may be extended
on the employer’s application.
Before a permit is issued, the Ministry of Labour must be satisfied that
there is a bona fide job, that no suitable British or foreign worker already
resident in Britain for a long period is available, and that the wages and con¬
ditions of employment are not less favourable than those enjoyed by British
workers. These conditions are waived for student employees who are admitted
for limited periods in order to improve their English and to gain a wider
knowledge of their occupations. A foreigner permitted to take employment
in the United Kingdom may not change his employment, unless his pros¬
pective employer has obtained prior approval from the Ministry.
Britain, as a member of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and
Development, participates with 13 European countries in the arrangements
for assisting nationals of the countries concerned to obtain employment in
other member countries.
As part of its plans for increasing productivity in industry the Government is
fostering the expansion and improvement of industrial training. The whole
framework of training in industry was strengthened by the Industrial
1 The Commonwealth Immigrants Act applies also to citizens of the Irish Republic;
but no control is imposed on persons travelling between Ireland and Britain.
2 People qualified by birth and residence to work in Northern Ireland.

Government
Vocational
Training
Training Act 1964. Under this Act the Minister of Labour is setting up
industrial training boards to be responsible for the quantity and quality of
industrial training in the industry concerned; up to June 1966 13 boards
had been set up. Each board can provide its own training courses or arrange
for other organisations to provide training. It raises a levy from employers
and makes grants to those whose training courses it approves. The Minister
meets the initial administrative costs of each board and is making grants
towards certain other expenditure: for example, training courses for trainers
and research projects. To advise the Minister of Labour on the administration
of the Act and on industrial training questions generally, a Central Training
Council (CTC) consisting of employer and trade union members, representa¬
tives of nationalised industries, educationists, selected chairmen of training
boards and others with a special interest in industrial training has been set
up. It also advises the Minister on the running of the Industrial Training
Service (ITS), which is grant-aided by the Ministry of Labour. The work of
the ITS includes assessing training needs both for industries and individual
companies, developing training schemes, and promoting group training
schemes.
In some of the industries for which training boards have not yet been set
up, apprenticeship training is governed by agreements between employers’
associations and trade unions. Practical training is provided mainly within
the individual firm, and associated technical education is obtained by attending
a technical college. Training of operatives is usually arranged by the individual
firm but in a few industries there are agreed national or regional schemes.
Other government measures to stimulate training activity include grants
for the training of training officers on approved courses, for the appointment
of training development officers and for the promotion of group training
schemes. The number of the Government’s own training centres is also being
substantially increased (see below).
The Government Vocational Training Scheme, administered by the Ministry
of Labour, is intended to augment what industry is doing to overcome
shortages of skilled workers in industries of importance to the national
economy, as well as helping persons in special need, such as the disabled
(see p. 429) and ex-Regular Service men and women, to fit themselves for
suitable employment. Training is provided for suitable persons over 18 years
of age who are unskilled or whose prospects of employment in their existing
trade are poor. Employed persons as well as the unemployed are accepted for
training in trades of importance to the national economy. Most of the training
is provided at the 30 (being increased to 38) Government Training Centres
(GTCs), which are situated within easy reach of the main industrial centres
of the country, and between them offer courses in about 40 different trades,
with emphasis on those in which there is a shortage of skilled labour. Schemes
of training for particular trades are agreed with representatives of the employers
and workers concerned.
For the disabled and for ex-Regular Service men and women and the un¬
employed with special resettlement problems, training in other trades is also
available under the scheme at technical and commercial colleges and private
training establishments or by means of individual courses at employers’
establishments. For severely disabled persons training is provided at four
residential training colleges run by voluntary organisations with government
financial assistance.
During training, trainees are paid good allowances to maintain themselves
and their dependants. During 1965, 8,514 people were trained under the
LABOUR
Special Ministry
Services
Legislation
and
Conventions
433
scheme and about 90 per cent of them were subsequently employed in the
trade for which they had been trained.
Training can also be given in GTCs to men sponsored by their employers
where it can be fitted in with the Ministry’s other training commitments.
The employer continues to pay the trainee’s wages and is charged a fee for
the training provided.
The Ministry of Labour’s Regular Forces Resettlement Service helps
Regular officers and other ranks returning to civilian life to find suitable
employment. Nearly all those leaving the Services are successful in securing
satisfactory resettlement. The Ministry arranges special six-week business
training courses for Regulars and ex-Regulars (mainly ex-officers) at com¬
mercial and technical colleges; four-week courses in industrial supervision
are provided at the Ministry of Labour, Ebury Bridge House, London, for
non-technical warrant officers and senior NCOs (or other Service equivalent
ranks). In addition to full courses for a civilian trade, refresher courses and
conversion courses required for ex-Service men and women can be arranged
under the Vocational Training Scheme.
The Ministry is providing full-time training for a limited number of
apprentices. Instruction is given in four trades: engineering; radio and
electronics servicing; basic electrical work; and sheet and plate metal work.
The apprentices are sponsored by their employers, who pay their wages
during the course. A charge is made wffiere the appropriate Industrial
Training Board has approved the training and has instituted a system of
‘off the job’ training grants.
The Ministry also provides assistance with training for firms on first
moving into a development area or expanding an existing business there.
The assistance includes grants for training carried out by the employer and
direct training of employees on the firm’s premises by staff loaned by the
Ministry.
A special service to industry is the Ministry of Labour’s Training Within
Industry for Supervisors (TWI) scheme. Its object is to develop the skill of
supervisors in instructing others, in human relations, in improving methods
and in preventing accidents (there are separate programmes for each of
these). There are special versions of TWI, usually in courses of a week’s
duration, for supervisors employed in offices, retail distribution and hospitals.
Ministry Training Officers either give these courses or train employers’
nominees to enable them to run TWI courses in their own concerns.
In addition, courses in industrial teaching techniques for the training of
apprentices and trade instructors are available to outside firms as well as
GTC staff at the Ministry’s two Instructor Training Colleges (one in England
and one in Scotland).
Vocational training services at GTCs, TWT courses, and courses at
Instructor Training Colleges are available to trainees from overseas under
approved schemes (for instance, those of the ILO or the Colombo Plan).
TERMS OF EMPLOYMENT AND WORKING CONDITIONS
There are few restrictions in Britain on the freedom of an employer to hire
an employee on any terms which the employee will accept. Recent legislation,
however, embodies certain safeguards for the employee. The Terms and
Conditions of Employment Act 1959 provides machinery for enforcing on
an employer the observance of terms or conditions established by collective
434
Earnings
BRITAIN: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
agreement in his industry; under the Contracts of Employment Act 1963
employers are now required to give their employees written particulars of
the main terms of employment, and employees are given rights to minimum
periods of notice when their employment is to be terminated; and under the
Redundancy Payments Act 1965 employees with a minimum period of
service of two years are entitled to lump sum payments if their jobs cease
to exist (for example, because of technological improvements or because
of a fall in demand) and their employers cannot offer suitable alternative work,
the cost being partly met from a fund subscribed to by industry as a whole.
Employers are under no legal obligation to recognise a trade union, or
to refrain from refusing to employ trade unionists; nor is a collective agree¬
ment with a trade union held to be in itself a legal contract of employment,
though the terms of a collective agreement may be expressly or by implication
incorporated in an individual contract of employment. However, it is by
collective agreements that in the majority of trades and industries minimum
or standard wages, normal working hours and other terms of employment are
effectively settled. The negotiation and observance of settlements continue
to depend primarily on the strength, integrity and representative character
of the signatory organisations rather than on any legal sanction. The deter¬
mination by statute of minimum wages, holidays and holiday pay is in
principle confined to those trades and industries where the organisation of
employers or workers, or both, is inadequate to negotiate collective agree¬
ments and to ensure their observance.
The conditions of work of employees—their safety, health and welfare—
depend to a far greater extent on minimum standards established by statute
and enforced by official inspectorates. Voluntary action is, however, still
important in these matters, whether additional health, safety or welfare
requirements are the subject of collective agreements, or employers provide
higher standards on their own initiative, as many do.
The further considerations which affect workers’ satisfaction with their
jobs and promote harmony between employers and employed, which can be
summed up as ‘good human relations’ between management and individual
employees, are hardly susceptible of codification; they have been recognised
for some time and are receiving increasing attention from managements and
from voluntary and official organisations.
Minimum or standard time rates for most British manual workers, as deter¬
mined by agreements or by statutory orders, vary between 4s. 3d. and
5s. qd. an hour for men and between 3s. od. and 4s. 6d. for women. Actual
earnings are usually higher. Higher rates are sometimes paid, and piece rates,1
shift rates and overtime rates raise the level of average earnings.
On the basis of the latest survey in a series conducted half-yearly by the
Ministry of Labour into earnings and hours of work in manufacturing
industries and some leading non-manufacturing industries in Great Britain,
the average earnings of full-time male adult manual workers in October 1965
were 8s. 4d. an hour and £19 ns. qd. a week. Full-time women manual
workers at the same date earned an average of 4s. 1 id. an hour and .£9 1 is. 1 id.
a week.
Minimum time rates for women manual workers tend to be set at around
70-90 per cent of the corresponding male rate, though the gap is gradually
1 Piece rates are of declining importance in manufacturing industries, where methods
of production tend to dictate the output of a worker, not his or her own skill or energy.

A=April 0=October
closing. Women’s earnings are markedly lower than those of men, partly
because on average they work shorter hours, with less overtime paid at
premium rates, but also because a smaller proportion of women do skilled
work. The Government has announced its intention of implementing the
principle of equal pay and is having talks with the Trades Union Congress
and the Confederation of British Industry about the problems involved.
Earnings in coal mining and dock work, not covered by the Ministry of
Labour survey, are somewhat above the average; earnings are below the
average in railway work and agriculture.
Between April 1955 and October 1965 average weekly wage rates increased
by about 53 per cent and average weekly earnings by about 78 per cent. Part

of the increase has been offset by a rise in prices. The trends of manual
workers’ wage rates and earnings and retail prices from 1955 to 1965 (and
salary earnings from 1955 to 1964) are shown in the diagram on p. 435.
Remuneration in commercial, technical and professional careers is normally
by annual salary, often on a scale carrying annual increases, and such careers
generally afford opportunities for promotion to posts with higher remunera¬
tion. Starting salaries may be in the range of £600-^800 (lower for trainees
in their teens and higher for some graduates entering industry). The average
weekly earnings of male administrative, technical and clerical employees in
October 1965 were found by a Ministry of Labour survey to be £25 10s. 8d.
The average weekly figure for females was £13 15s. id.
Most of the senior posts in business, the professions and the Civil Service
are in the range of £2,750 to £7,000 a year. The posts with salaries in the
range of .£8,000 to £15,000 a year include those of Cabinet Ministers, top-
ranking judicial appointments, the highest positions in government depart¬
ments and the largest municipal authorities, editors of daily newspapers,
some persons outstanding in their professions and in the higher managerial
posts in industry, commerce and banking. A few persons in business draw
still higher salaries, while the earnings of star entertainers and certain other
very successful people exceed £25,000 a year.
Women have the same right of entry as men to nearly all public offices,
administrative posts and professions. They are paid the same salary for
doing the same work in journalism, broadcasting and architecture, and as
Ministers of the Crown, members of Parliament, salaried magistrates and
solicitors. Women in independent professions are not expected to charge
lower fees than men. The principle of equal pay applies to non-manual work
in the public sector but remains the exception in private non-manual
employment.
The average earnings of all salaried employees increased by 65 per cent
between 1955 and 1965^5 illustrated in the diagram on p. 435.
In October 1965 the number of hours actually worked by manual workers
averaged 47 for full-time men and 38-7 for women on full-time work. Agreed
weekly hours are mainly in the range 40 to 42 and may be worked as either a
five-day or a five-and-a-half-day wreek according to the industry and the rule
of the particular establishment. Hours actually worked by men are somewhat
longer owing to overtime working. While the hours of work of adult men are
not, in general, restricted by statute, normal hours of work for both sexes and
those of all ages are usually within the legal limits on the hours of women and
young persons.
National legislation in the United Kingdom limits and defines permissible
hours of work for women and young persons in a number of industries or
trades, the most permitted (with limited exceptions) being 48 hours a week
and nine a day in premises covered by the Factories Act (see p. 437) for adult
women and young people approaching 18 years. In continuous processes,
with limited exceptions, the employment of women and young persons at
night is prohibited.
With a few exceptions, manual workers (including shop assistants) in indus¬
tries covered by agreements or statutory orders are entitled to paid holidays
of at least 12 days or two weeks. Moreover, payment is made for bank or
statutory public holidays, which are as follows: in addition to Good Friday

and Christmas Day, there are Bank Holidays in most parts of England, Wales
and the Channel Islands on Easter Monday, the last Monday in May or first

weekday after Christmas (Boxing Day), and in Scotland on New Year’s Day
the last Monday in May or first in June and the last Monday in August or
